i wuz in fresno for the past 6 daze, not a lot of net access, so here's
  my belated thoughts on fnf5

serious ass-kicking all around, it was GREAT to finally see the sfraves
  crew in person; i really regret not being able to meet you all.

particularly liked the wall-painting, some REALLY nice comic book art
  was done on one of the walls (where everyone was sortof sitting on
    the ground during the ambient sets)

wish i'd known about the bloody van!!!

hats off to wbl, there performance was better than the CD i have; and
  i hope there's another being stamped as i type this....
    (i think that's _their_ performance)

don't know when i'll have another chance to come up, maybe this spring
  if i get some free time; meanwhile, if anyone's coming down for
    millenium, give me a holler!

Dave Scruton
  (also scruton@delphi.com)

From sfraves-owner  Sun Jan  1 17:59:59 1995
Return-Path: owner-sfraves

Date: Sun, 1 Jan 1995 17:59:24 -0800
From: resonate@netcom.com (resonate)
Message-Id: <199501020159.RAA11891@netcom12.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: secret NYE party BUSTED
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

The Other New Years eve ball was a blast until shut down.
The dance floors, lighting, and everything were excellent.
The WBL run ambient space had crisp quadraphonic sound and fine
performances from everyone. Our WBL multi-user sequencer worked 
for the first time it was used! The warehouse was PACKED.

About 4:30am or so police came in and told us to shut down. The party
was FULL and everything was going fine.

It doesn't bother me to get shut down- this happens sometimes.

The problem did arise when people refused to leave and started yelling
at the cops. The cops just wanted everyone out of the warehouse and were
gonna take off. They did arrest a few of the party promoters though but
they were cited and released.

The people kept shouting and arguing with the police and got them angry
enough that several people were arrested. A friend of ours was taking
pictures and wa also hauled in.

The police were really fascinated by the mac that was plugged into the
Net- looking for any evidence that it was used to advertise the party.

The whole problem was that, though the party was legally permitted and
insured, they were not supposed to charge admission at the door yet
they wound up doing so. This was probably the thing that started the plice
to shut it down and the angry mob type behavior finished it off.



From sfraves-owner  Sun Jan  1 20:11:08 1995

From: Nick Radov <nradov@netcom.com>
Subject: Cloud Factory/Coherent Light report
To: SFraves Mailing List <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9501011913.A22612-0100000@netcom14>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I didn't feel up to driving all the way to SF (from Watsonville) so I 
decided to head to the Cloud Factory party in Monterey.  I got in about 
10:30 and at that point some local industrial act was on.  This wasn't at 
all what I'd been expecting and the 10 or so people on the dancefloor 
were kicking around a couple full size blow-up dolls and a mannakin's 
head.  At this point I was getting a real negative feeling from the whole 
affair and almost headed back to a private party in Santa Cruz.

Luckily I stuck it out until the DJs came on at around 11:20; they had 
about four guys rotating around five turntables and ended up with a 
pretty cool effect.  The light show was good as well.  I was kind of 
disapointed that more people weren't dancing; a lot of them just sort of 
sat there.  There probably weren't more than 60 people on the dancefloor 
at a time.  The promoters were totally cool.  Cheap admission, no security, 
and free oranges for everyone.

I also ran into a bunch of people I hadn't seen since high school which 
was also totally cool.  Well, back to LA soon...

I'm sorry to hear that you didn't have an excellent time at the cloud
factory, nick.  But I've got to say that it was a spectacular New Year's for
me.  Granted, the industrial stuff wasn't my style but after the music
started flowing there wasn't any stopping it.  Yes, there were yer
hunter/gatherer  types but pleez, it's Monterey!  Our vibes tend to be a bit
different from sf or Santa Cruz vibes.  And if you stayed around long enough,
you could see that that core  group of people danced until the last song.
 Didn't you see Milton in his blaze of glory, or should I say Carmen Miranda
get up?  I'm not the most knowledgeable person about music but I can say that
I loved it.  
     You have to understand too that a lot of those people there have never
been to raves before and do feel self conscious about dancing don't really
know what to do.  I was completely overwhelmed at my first rave and just
wanted to get a feel for things.  And when I finally felt at ease, it changed
my life.  My friend Jodi who is really into punk  never saw what an actual
vibe was like until she had a run in with Milton and several other very
awesome people.  She said she finally understood why I go to raves and love
to dance so much.  So once again I'm sorry to hear that you didn't feel the
energy I did, I hope that you will continue to support the cloud factory
because its people like you who know what a rave IS, that we need to spread
the love.  If you saw a dude in an "I'm a pepper" t-shirt that was me... ...
.. .any others sfravers who where there care to comment (bryce, deaks, elmo)?
 
peace to ya'all and milton I hope someone found the e-bee!
Brian

From: Josh Bates <unknown@nexsys.nexsys.net>
Subject: New Years (hell -> heaven)
To: SFraves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>

Holy Shit, what a night. For some reason I had a very stupid fantasy that
wicked would go off. I got there around 7pm & had to uncomfortably hide
from those under 21 killers for a couple hours. The production was quit
cool, but other than that meaningless detail it SUCKED SHIT. I'v never
seen so many suits & ties at party in my life, no vibe, no dancing, no
good music, nutin'. At about 3 I got news that begin again was pretty
close. So I just ran there by myself. What a change of moods, being totaly
bummed about not having the spectacular n.y. I had hoped for, to instantly
turning around 180 degrees to have the time of my life. Great music, great
underground space, wonderfull people & a *great* vibe, this was definatly one
of my all time parties. Solar ripped it up, yellin & screaming along with
everybody else, this guy is one of my new found fav's. Galon brought me
into complete ectasy with the all time SF "papua new guanea" and
"midnight". It's funny how these guys with less experience & records then
the wicked(etc..) boys blow them away musicaly, as they still have gutts
to play what they realy like. Another thing I found amusing was that it
was a pretty young croud & had much more energy & maturaty then the 21+
wicked, lacking the "I know so & so" attitude that lots of older parties
are plagued with. Underground at it's FINEST. HAPPY NEW YEARS :)
			josh b

From sfraves-owner  Mon Jan  2 13:16:55 1995

Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Mon, 2 Jan 1995 12:57:08 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: birdsong@uclink2.berkeley.edu (William H. Birdsong)
Subject: Heaven->Hell->Heaven
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

The night started out kinda strange.  My wife had to work and I started out
with a friend who has never been to a rave before.  I really wanted her to
experience a good vibe and I have to admit I felt a little pressure to find
a cool party.  We started out by going to the "Warehouse Session" at around
11:30.  There was a gang o' cops out front and within minutes they were
closing the place down.  Someone out front said "I can't believe they would
do this without a permit."  Lucky we didn't pay to go in.

Then it was off to "The Other New Year's Ball."  This production had a nice
feel.  I had heard thet Weird Blinking Lights did good work and I was
impressed (although I kinda expected lasers or some lights that actually
blinked and there weren't any).  There were two dance floors.  One played
trippy disco and fab 70's stuff.  Someone had gone to alot of trouble to
make that mix because the tunes were almost all recognizable from days gone
by but they had a really strange effect in 1994-5.  The other dance floor
was a large airplane-hanger like room with lots of psychadelic lights and
rear screen projections but no lasers or BLINKING LIGHTS.  There were two
chill rooms.  One was bright and colorful and way too crowded.  The other
had straw all over the floors and videos that someone described as
psychahomoerotic.  We were hanging out in that room yakking and thinking we
were watching the time when we decided that it was getting close to two and
it was time to pick up Bobbie.  We walked back toward the coat check and
asked someone what time it was and he said "two-ten."

OH MY GOD!!!  She's gonna kill me!  I positively freaked.  I had been late
before and I had promised not to be late again.  It's worse when I'm out
partying and she's working too.  I asked my friend what to do and she said
to just run to the car and go get her and don't forget to come back.  I
raced into the rain, jumped into the car and screeched through the streets
of SF at 2:15 which was surreal given the contrast between my panic and
everyone else pouring out of the bars and staggering into the street.  It's
a wonder I didn't skid out and have an accident.  All I could do was hope
Bobbie hadn't taken a cab back to the east bay and that she wouldn't be too
mad.  One thing was for sure, she would be in no mood to go out after work
as we had planned!

To my complete surprise, she was standing on the curb with a friend
smiling.  Smiling!  Oh happy day!  She said that she had gotten off work
early and had spent the last hour at her friend's house and that she hadn't
been standing in the rain waiting for me all alone (talk about lucky
breaks!)  The really lucky part was that she had heard about a party at 340
Bryant.

We went back to "The Other New Years" and grabbed our friend and went to
340 Bryant.  I got a good feeling as soon as we found the location, at the
very end of Bryant practically under the Bay Bridge.  Water was cascading
off of the lower deck into the street and it was positively gothic!  The
location was superb.  This space was all partitioned and there were several
rooms.  One medium sized dance floor played raging techno and had lasers
(hooray, I love lasers).  Another had cushions and a bunch of toys in the
middle which we played with.  Another alternated between ambient  and dance
music.  The crowd was great and we met several people and saw some friends.
Hi Allen and holo at netcom!  Wasn't that a great party?  Happy New Year
everyone!

birdsong@uclink2.berkeley.edu

Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id PAA12725; Mon, 2 Jan 1995 15:23:54 -0800
Received: from netcom4.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with ESMTP id PAA12719; Mon, 2 Jan 1995 15:23:51 -0800
Received: by netcom4.netcom.com (8.6.9/Netcom)
	id PAA23059; Mon, 2 Jan 1995 15:06:15 -0800
Date: Mon, 2 Jan 1995 15:06:15 -0800
From: crunch@netcom.com (John Draper)
Message-Id: <199501022306.PAA23059@netcom4.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: New Years Rave report
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

New Years Rave report
=====================

Well,   I started my NY partying kinda early,  and also was sorta fragmented
over the last few days.     Letrs atart off with Tribal Funk on Wed.

Tribal Funk report
==================

This Wed,   I get word that Tribal Funk is happening.   We call the info
line and learn that it starts EARLY.    I mean "super early".    We also
learn that if we arrive before 7:30,  we get in for $5,  so Radion and
a few Local Mill Valley kids all head into SF to a new (As yet unknown)
venue which turned out to be a band practive studio.   More on the venue
later.

We arrive just at 7:30,  was able to talk the person taking our money
to let us in for $5.    When we arrived,  there was about 150 people,
and Carlos was spinning.    They had a very nice chill area set up in
several rooms,   and the main dance area,    somewhat small,  with a
stage area where the DJ sits.

Carlos let loose some incredable music,   skillfully mixing in some
Double Dutch Bus and went right into Funkey Town...  WOW!!   incredable.
He also went insane scratching up a storm,  using the siren sounds,
speeding up and slowing it down,   causing some intense psychodelic 
audio imput that twisted my mind, body and soul.

Dj Utopia followed Carlos,   mixing in some good house variaty,  along
with some really trancey stuff.    Jeno finally got on,  and ripped the
place up BIG TIME.   WOW!! everyone was hooting and shouting to Jeno's
set.   It was totally insane!!!

The goon factor,  I'm sorry to say,  really spoiled the very good vibe,  
and it shut down early (2am) as usual,  due to our fascist laws about 
partying after 2 am.    The place was so filled with smoke that I had 
to take a double dose of anti-tobacco medication, which sorta spoiled 
my high.    Even Radion complained that he couldn't dance anymore because 
of the cigerette smoke,  and he isn't allergic like I am.     

Naturally,  security had the place closed tighter than a sealed box,
not letting in ANY fresh air until the front door ocassionally opened
as people were coming and leaving.    There were NO ins-and-outs allowed
of course.     I would say it was worse than 174 King St or the old
16th and Harrison Hayes Theator.

I say to all of you who plan on attending future parties there,  to please
let the venue managers know about the following concerns both for safety
and for comfort.

They need ...    a) Better ventilation or to ban smoking in the dance area
                 b) A few floor fans to circulate the air.
                 c) better and more reasonable security.

Other than the fucked venue,   I enjoyed myself,   but my throat and eyes
still ache to the point where I couldn't see the computer screen very easily
to do my work.

Most of Thursday and Friday,  thanx in part to the overdose of smoke,  it
has triggered my alergies to the point where my head was so congested that
I didn't think I would really enjoy INFINITY,  mostly in part because it
was held at same venue as Tribal Funk,  so I stayed in to recover and
try to get my congestion down to reaonable tolerances.   I wanted to be 
in top shape for New Years partying.   I spent a longer than normal time
for exercises, Yoga, Pagua and Thai chi..     WOW!!  I did 3 hours of it on
Thursday and it actually helped my congestion immensly,  on Friday,  I
recovered enough to visit the health club to learn they just installed
my favorite exercise machine (A Versa-Climber).   So,  after spending
1 extra hour in the health club,   I finally felt pretty good again
by Friday evening.   It's amazing what exercises can do for congestion.

On saturday afternoon,   I continued physically preparing myself for the
big NY Eves party,  pondering my choices for the evening.    These were...

Cool World - The Mega,  highly commercialized,  5 arena extravanganza
  that was surly guarenteed to be a total ZOO.   I had Comp tickets
  at Will call waiting for me,  but even getting in for free,  wasn't
  incentive enough to deal with the hassles of getting there,  and I
  didn't really want to drive,   because I wanted to get totally hosed
  that evening,  and driving wasn't on my activity list.
  
Wicked - I think the wet rainey weather was ONE of the reasons why I
  eliminated this choice,   but the DV8 (55 natoma) venue vibe can
  sometimes subtract from a good vibe.   ANd (of course the promoters
  greed)  $25 admission...  C'm on you guys,  GET REAL!!  I've heard
  frokm unconfirmed sources that on one side,   they were charging
  $35,  and $25 on the other side.    Sheesh!!  talk about inconsistancy.
  
The other New Years Ball - This one was one of the ones I had planned
  on visiting,   and even showed up before the party started to check out
  the venue.   WOW!!  It was really set up nicely.   So I planned to check
  it out sometime later.
  
Begain Again - Finally won out as the first party to attend.   Mostly in
  part,  because Dan Mapes (the venue owner) was a friend of mime,   and 
  they were going to have an internet connection to connect to the 
  International Cafe and man other spots all over the world.
  
Begin Again
-----------

It was strange...   Info line says to go to Mission Rock..  So we get there
and find nothing.    We meet other confused dedicated ravers and finally
meet up with someone who says this was a map point.

I had called for Dan Mapes earlier in the day,  and got word that it was
to be held at the Cyberlab 7 offices.   Later on that day,  one of the
people working there said the venue was changed to Mission Rock area.
I thought that it was because they were anticipating a larger crowd and
moved to a bigger space.   I also learned that people were then sent to 
yet another map point located at Komotion.

When I talked to the map point person,  I told him I was on the guest list
so he wispered in my ear....   340 Bryant,  and we were off.

We get there about a half hour early,  about 8 pm,  as they were setting up.
Thanks go to Frank and Craig and Denise for driving me around,   and romping 
from map point to map point.    Just about then,  the rain started....

Things started a tad late,   but soon the music was to start,  and after
the sound system finally got tuned up,  things were starting.    Naturally,
I was one of the first persons out on the dance floor,  warming up for
an intense amount of dancing,  schmoozing and plain pure partying.

Solar literally ripped it up with his acid trancey sounds,  soon there
was harly enough room to dance,   but I found a reaonably dry spot to 
dance in.   WOW!! the energy was totally insane,  almost like Friends
and Family.    The SFRave quotent was pretty high,   and it went on
all evening without any problems from the police.   Although it was hot
and humid on the dance floor,   I was able to find adequate places
to cool down.

Soon,  after 2 am,   people were coming in who had been to Cool World
and confirmed that it was more of a zoo than I had even imagined.   Huge
long lines in the rain,  and I even got word that the police shut down
a portion of the rave.     No confirmation on that,  though.

At about 3 am,  things at Begin Again were going so well that I didn't 
want to leave in the pouring rain and head over to The Other New Years
ball,  even though it was within walking distance.  I was having too
much fun at Cyberlab 7.    By the way,  the internet connection to
International Cafe never went off.

Finally at about 5 am,  the rain stopped,  and just as I was about to check 
out the "Ball",   I met someone who just came from there, and said that
it got shut down by the police.  Wicked ended at 4:30 (Fairly early).

So,  I was content,  fat dumb and happy to stay at Begin Again until the
very end,  happy as "pig in shit" dancing around like a lunetic.

At about 8 am,  the music in the main room stopped,   but the chill and
ambient was till going strong and the DJ was actually playing some good
dancable music.    There were a few die hards left dancing,  but then
when the dj put on some insanely fast Jungle,   I went totally beserk.
WOW!!  What a way to end a rave...   Firing it up to the very end....
Finally,  at about 9:15,   we leave,  as things were shutting down.

After that,  we ate a big breakfast at the Pork shop Cafe on 5th st,
and meet these dudes from LA.    I then went off with them,  introducing
then to our superb vibe,  and eventually make it over to another party
in the Haight.    We stayed there throughout the afternoon,  dancing to
acid Jazz (Welcome change),  then tried to make it over to Spundae...

When we got there,  things were pretty dead...  We head back to Haight
party at which time the DJ from London who had just brought back some
of the most hidious,  twisted jungle stuff I've herd yet....  and
continued dancing like a mad man...   Although no effort was made in
beat matching,   it offered me some breaks from dancing to schmooze and
do some yoga at the party.    Finally,  at about 1:30 am on Sunday,
my partying finally came to an end.    WOW!!  this morning I wake up,
feeling really loose,   not sore,  dispite the 12 hours of solid
dancing at Begin Again,  where the most time I spent OFF the dance
floor was about 20 minutes.   Even at 1:30 am on Sunday,  I was thinking
of trying to find some place open to do more dancing....   :-)

GREAT PARTY!!  Sorry for all those that missed it,  and had to deal 
with piggies and other hassles at the other parties.

Cheers - have a Great New Year...

C. Crunch

> it turns out that the story i heard from police about why they shut down
> the Other New Years Ball was false.
> 
> they did not shut it down for door admission. they shut it down because they
> fucked up and everything at that party was in order so far as we can tell.

Listen people, I don't want to bring anybody down here, but this is serious. 
You know what's gonna happen to those police officers for this wrongful
arrest?  Zippo.  Do you know what it cost us as a community?  A lot of
people paid to get in, a lot of money was spent setting it up, a few people
suffered a lot of grief.  None of this money will be returned to its
rightful owners.  Supposedly, this is the price we pay freedom.  Umm...what?
This doesn't make sense.

I'm not a government major, but I thought our system was based on checks and
balances.  Who keeps the police in check?  It's not like one of us can pull
them over for going 85 down a highway.  Who is making sure they're doing
their job.  Don't get me wrong, there a lot of honest, good-hearted, people
who dedicate their lives to protecting the public from those who will take
advantage of us.  But who protects us from the police who take advantage of
their authority?  When you're wrongfully arrested, you go to jail, have to
post your own bail, and have to pay for legal costs: this is money out of
your own pocket that you'll never see again, even if you're innocent.  This
just doesn't seem right.

I'm sorry if I'm bitching, but as a community, we're starting to gain some
strength here.  Let's remember to focus this energy in a positive direction
whenever possible.  Our government needs an overhaul of revolutionary
proportions.  This is not a matter of republican vs. democrat ideology. 
This country has changed a lot in 200+ years, unfortuneately, government has
not.  We can't expect change to come overnight, but we can start demanding
some answers.  Shouting at the police is only going to make them carry a
bigger stick.  Just do something when you can, and when you can't remember
what's important about life and being here on this planet right now.

Some people will pay for the rest of their lives for one mistake.  Police
have been given the right to not have to pay for their mistakes in most
instances.  Keep up the positive energy and I know something good will
happen soon.  Happy New Year to everyone!  Sorry for the darkness, but I'm
only doing it cause I don't want to see anyone else get hurt.  God, I *hate*
politics but I hate injustice more.  Take care.

vibrating at the speed of love

solarvibe

From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)

Subject: Begin Again!

Precedence: bulk

I've never been enamored by the whole New Year's Eve thing; i.e. allowing
some arbitrary date on a Roman Calender to tell me when it's time to party
hard.  And since most human automatons seem to like being told when it's
OK to feel good, most parties on New Year's Eve tend be, uh, New Year's Eve 
parties.  Anyway, I knew that if any party had a chance to be magical
on its own, it would the totally unhyped Pacific production.  Being aware
of the incredible DJ lineup, Janie & I were looking forward to enjoying a
straightforward basic underground warehouse event.

Well, this party was anything but "basic".  It was a rather incredible
setup.  We got there around 8pm to help with some of the sound 
equipment.  The space, Cyberlab7's big video production warehouse, was 
something from an urban technoshaman's vision.  A small army (including
many SFRavers) where still putting video equipment and a multitude of
imaginative decorations in place.  There were a bunch of interactive 
alters everywhere, computers, banners, hanging tubes, candles... too
much stuff to describe here.  The Cyberlab7 folks went nuts with the
opportunity to show off their video production talents.  There were a lot
of screens with some fantastic computer-manipulated projections and 
two very nice lazer setups.  The main chill area was huge, with mattresses
chairs and a dance area.  When we got there, Polliwog was already spinning
some nice dancey ethno-funk-hiphop stuff.  People were dancing there all
night in addition to the main dance room which never got too crowded, but
was almost always full and going off.

The vibe was pretty good for New Year's, much better than I had hoped for.  
Lot's of friendly exchanges, free hugs and candy offerings.  Sure, there
was a percentage of non-ravers who were just there to be out with their 
friends but it still felt like a rave to me.  Ceril started things off with
some trance.  Tracy really got things hopping at around 10:30.  Markie
Markie and then John Williams followed with some really nice sets, after 
which we took time out to recharge our batteries. 

The end of the party seemed especially moving: as Galen finished
up you could just sense the overwhelming emotion he and the rest of the
Pacific people were feeling.  This was a pinnacle for them, the cap to
a great year.  Mostly they just seemed so grateful for all the love and
good luck that seems to have come their way.  Needless to say that they
deserve every single bit of it.  And thanks also to Cyberlab7 who exposed
tons of expensive hardware to a party atmosphere for a celebration of
technology fun.

Lee
____________________________________________________________________________
lxfogel@pacbell.com   (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )    lee@hyperreal.com
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

From: anthrax@uclink.berkeley.edu (Ann Elizabeth Loraine)

begin again was a very cloak and dagger affair, requiring stops at no less
than 2 map points to get tickets and location of the party.  several people
said they liked that part, even someone who didn't have a car but who got
a ride with some others who demonstrated true raver vibe...

since we were helping with the ambient room, though, we got to the party kindof
early to set up.  the spot was a warehouse in basically the heart of soma, i
guess, which was one reason for the extreme caution utilized by the promoters.
there were no lines outside and the doorguy was very nice but firm, making
sure nobody was hanging around outside to attract official attention.  and
there were ALOT of cop cars circulating that night.  BIG SIGH of relieve that
it didn't get busted!

eenyway, it was basically a three room setup, with one room in the middle filled
with computers, one room with the main systems and dance floor, and then the
ambient/chill space, which was carpeted.  we brought lots of doodads, toys,
paint, cushioning, a carpet, a fouton, etc. in hopes of achieving the afore-
mentioned "chill-so-deep-it-sucks-you-in-and-you-can't-get-out..." feeling.
one nice "trick" is to put a fouton on a frame and then cover the whole thing
with an enormous carpet, creating a mound effect.  also, there were lots of
video projectors and a largist middle room with a sand pit where people were
filling up with little clay figurines freshly molded from a bag of wet clay.

the neatest thing about this party, however, was the absolutely incredible
vibe...everyone was smiling and happy and completely INTO it.  i guess it's just
that people were feeling very proud to be part of this underground scene that
really DOES do better parties, have better music, and generally more CONTENT
than those big commercial parties.  (with some notable exceptiosn, of course!)

i'm really glad i got to be with the raving peoples newyears eve and celebrate
a chance to begin again.

seeya,

ann/thrax

This was a very special New Year's for me , my first one in SF.

This party was even more than I expected and I expected alot. To begin it 
might be appropriate to briefly discuss the genesis of this party since I 
was there from when we started to plan it until we began again. 

The actual planning and execution of the party took about 7 weeks which 
was not too much time but just enough to let everything fall in place.
The dynamics of how this party came to be is very special and is what 
made the actual party "magical".

I had been going to the Sunset parties since they started late last 
spring but I didn't get to know the Pacific guys (Galen,Solar,Cyril,Jason 
& Lorien) until the middle of September. We quickly became friends and 
started hanging out together. 

I met Dan Mapes at a party in the middle of October at the old Cyberlab 
studios. I had been referred to Dan from a friend at Matthew Fox's, 
Institute in Culture & Creation Spirituality where Dan was teaching a 
class on technology & ritual. The night after the first party I saw Dan & 
his wife Claudia at the Ambient Jungle party in GG Park and we talked for 
awhile and realized that we were both into throwing parties for similar 
reasons, community & ecstasy (not the drug per se).
 Somewhere around the time of the rave mass 
in late October I approached Dan about doing a party and he suggested we 
do a big New Year's party. This was a great idea and I suggested that 
Pacific come on board to help produce the event since they have been 
responsible for helping cultivate the deep underground SF vibe. I ran the 
idea by the Pacific guys , it was a match and we started working on details.

A diverse group of people who did not previosly know eachother came 
together to produce an amazingly powerful event. Initially we considered 
doing a completely above ground event with big money at the Fashion 
Center but decided against that after Dan and Claudia met with the police 
and they told them that we'd have to turn the lights on at 2AM and kick out 
everyone under 21. With that option eliminated we moved to plan B which 
we were more comfortable with which was to do an underground event. Of 
course we were worried about the police and that is why we had a double 
map point.

The two primary reasons why this party was such a success was because the 
producers are committed to a set of values that see raves and 
celebrations as more than just entertainment but as events that build 
community and foster healing and because the community that attended the 
event were co-producers of it.

I am proud that I was able to help bring forth such a beautiful party and 
am even more thankful for the deeply meaningful experiences of 
teamwork,cooperation and love that I shared with my co-producers. I will 
never forget making the last stop at the business office right at 
midnight with Galen and when he later in the morning said to me "that was a 
good bonding experience Ronan". Or when Cyril hugged me and said "peace 
brother". Or at the end of the party when Solar was leaving and I looked 
deep in his eyes and said "I love you". Dan, Claudia, Zoe and everyone 
else, what can I say? Thanx.

May we have many more such events. We can heal our communities and world 
through celebration and genuine love.

All the Best for '95,
Ronan

"Let the times fulfill humanities most ancient hopes.
 We cannot say it shall not be." T&D.McK

My TV happened to be on the USA (cable) channel when i turned it on
last night.... As the scan-lines bloomed forth from dormancy (like
cancerous buds of disinformation) a zoom-in on some cheezy rave flyers
on the wall emerged. For some reason, this caught my eye (ouch!) and I 
watched... (duped again!).

Turns out TV is yet again trying to induce a negative response to
raves, this time via some stupid "world premiere USA channel movie".
All I can say is that when it comes time for more stimulus/response of
this sort, Pavlov-Doggie-Dog ain't gonna roll over or play fetch...

The EXecutive Summary:

	* Evil, violent Irish guy in a leather jacket is running raves
	  in a club.
	* Apparently said Irish guy is the ringleader of a drug-dealing
	  group o thugs that both sell drugs and run raves.
	* Evil irish guy kills people and eventually gets apprehended.
	* Evil irish guy is framing the protagonist, a do-gooder law
	  professor doing a little "research" on his comely-blond
	  neighbor. Professor catches evil irish guy committing murder 
	  on video tape.
	* Framed professor escapes from police clutches to prove
	  he didn't do it; climactic denouement happens during a rave.
	* THe movie basically used raves as the "seedy underbelly" of the
	  story, attempting to lend atmosphere to an otherwise silly murder
	  mystery. Analysed any other way, the whole rave thing was a 
	  big "loose end" in the story.
	* The rave looked like a rave, except that a greater percentage
	  of the audience was showing more skin than you normally see
	  at raves.
	* There was a chill room, where drugs were being sold. X, Speed, etc.

1 dead corpse in dumpster, 1 strangulation,  1 fall-to-death-through-
club-slylights, 333 breasts, voyeur divorcee law-professor fu, 1
cliff-hanger from skylight of club,  head-butt-to-the-nose fu, motor
scooter chase, car chase,  Body-Double rip-off factor 57%. Niels-Bob
says don't check it out.

(PS: Sorry, I couldn't take any pictures of this and put it on the web
like I did with the 90210 "rave" page I advertiszed a while back ... I
happened to be doing major surgery on the Web Authoring application I'm
writing (wwweasel) and it just wasn't up for running right then...)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==           Niels Mayer -- netcom!mayer -- mayer@netcom.com               ==

From sfraves-owner  Tue Jan  3 11:56:46 1995
Return-Path: owner-sfraves
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id LAA12269; Tue, 3 Jan 1995 11:56:46 -0800
Received: from bethe.ucdavis.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with SMTP id LAA12263; Tue, 3 Jan 1995 11:56:39 -0800
Received: by bethe.ucdavis.edu (4.1/UCD2.05)
	id AA03163; Tue, 3 Jan 95 11:56:28 PST
From: alves@bethe.ucdavis.edu (David Alves)
Date: Tue, 3 Jan 95 11:56:28 PST
Message-Id: <9501031956.AA03163@bethe.ucdavis.edu>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: nye
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


party #1

Lawyers and Scientists.  Lacking a tux I was severely underdressed.
Hot gossip on which local judges are sleeping with their law students. 

party #2

Small house party in the city.  Meeting point for large group of
friends who want to go dancing.  Dick Clark has still got the magic.
Visiting Londoners were confused by lighted ball.


party #3 (Wicked)

Took me almost an hour to cross town and get totally lost near
55 Natoma.  Arriving around 1:30 our large party reconvened in a
happy, indecisive, unfocused manner.  

Superstar Rave Sweethearts Ali and Tracy 
gave me the official word - " it's Bunk !! "

We began walking toward Begin Again.  I was a bit concerned about
bypassing the map point but Wicked looked absolutely hopeless.
I was definitely on the sober side of things and feeling
somewhat responsible to get us *somewhere* before 
anyone noticed that we weren't there yet.


party #4 (Pacific)

New Year's Eve Raver Angel smiled upon our joyous group 
and convinced the doorman to let us in without tickets - this
was close to 3 (we weren't moving too fast ...)  

After what felt like eons of running around I was actually
skeptical anything was happening at the party because it was
it was Sooo Quiet at the door.  Raver girl with lollipop
reassured me that there was dancing and music upstairs.

Turns out we found what had to be the best party in town. 

It was fantastic.  Tons of happy people.  Funky chill
dancing.  Harder techno trance room.  Computer lounge room.
Underwater sauna playdough room.  Rave market hallway.  
Free water and ice.  Donations for cups and fruit.

costumes/fashion - that made my knees weak (butterflys)
Satin Satin Satin, girls - skirts and suits with colors
The oversized Cartoon Eyelashes and pale eyes are also a 
personal fave.  Think Audrey Hepburn multiplied by a hundred ...
Mmmm, I am a jelly roll just thinking about it - Gorgeous!!

music - the funky chill room was really great although I was in
the mood for the louder room.  The techno trance end of things isn't
my favorite.  It is so aggressive (football bores me) anyway, this
didn't stop me from really getting into it.  I dug this one song
that had all these Loud Crashing sounds.  I woulda guessed it
was Ethan ... but I usually have no idea who spins when.

sweat - was all over the floor.  my friend, Erica, bit it in a most
comical manner - she just got swept away by the music and her legs
flew out from under her ... spectacular!

I set an early benchmark for unraverly behavior in 95
by cutting in front of 20 high people to use a porta-potty
(where is the fucking mayonaise)
Happy New Years to everyone
and apologies to those confused people 
trying to use the bathroom ...

Love ya,
Dave




From sfraves-owner  Tue Jan  3 12:35:00 1995

	id AA09195; Tue, 3 Jan 95 12:34:35 PST

	id AA14486; Tue, 3 Jan 95 12:34:28 PST
Date: Tue, 3 Jan 95 12:34:28 PST
From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Message-Id: <9501032034.AA14486@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: 1994 in Review 
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Finding nostalgia a rather stale state of mind, I normally don't like to 
dwell on the past, but what the hell, 94 was a good year so I'll indulge
in the memories one last time... 
 
*  *  *
 
My Favorite Parties:
 
For a variety of reasons, I didn't go out as much in 94, especially in 
the 2nd half.  Janie and I also tended to shy away from the hot crowded 
indoor parties that lots of people love, so my list will have some glaring
ommisions to many of you.   
 
Jan 1 - Boogie Buffet - 1015 Folsom - This New Year's day party was the 
final climax of the 1993 Boogie Buffet weekly Sunday parties that had 
fueled a rather unique acid jazz/house scene over the previous year.  
Everybody was still nuts from the nite before, and things only got crazier.
Seems like ancient history now.
 
Feb 5  - The Gathering - Richmond Civic Auditorium - Not especially
spectacular - just a big, good, happy party with sound quality that
was amazing for such a big venue.  Tony, Jon Williams, Spun, & Josh
delivered great fresh-sounding sets for the occasion, along with a
separate sound system in the front, and a great chill room.
 
March 26 - Full Moon Rave - The final Bonny Doon FMR was the biggest, and
it took a while to settle down. Things were a little messy with a crowd
of about 3,000.  But from about 8:30am to 1:30pm, amazing sets by Markie &
Jeno took things to a higher plane for a totally tribal, tanscendental
experience by the ocean.  I will always remember Bonnie Doon Beach as the
most spiritual of rave sites that I have ever experienced.
 
May 28 - In The Light - Golden Gate Park - As the main organizer and
"promoter" of this party, this was a very fulfilling experience for me.  
Thanks to contributions from many SFRavers the party was a great success 
and the realization of a personal vision.   Bryce, Laura, and Markie 
DJed to a sun-drenched crowd that was kinda like F&F meets Wicked in public. 
 
July 2nd - Freedom - Livermore Race Track -  Sometimes I think that 
nothing beats a large happy outdoor no-hassle big sound party.  I will
always remember the finale with the 300 who remained, holding hands in 
a giant circle under the rising sun.  It was a goofy and sincerely special 
moment that we will never forget.
 
May thru October - Sunset - Berkely Marina - This party is what made the
year truly wonderful for us.  From the initial intimate 50 person get 
togethers, to the later semi-massives, we managed to go to almost all
of them.  5 months, almost every weekend -  Much Thanx to Galen & Pacific;
Sunset provided the vibe-glue in 94 that helped keep the scene on track.
 
December 31 - Begin Again - Cyberlab 7 - It was great to be a part of such
a well produced communal PLUR-meets-technology party - it felt like a
year's worth of good karma was watching over this one.
 
*  *  *
 
Favorite DJs of 1994 - I only considered DJs that I heard spin at least 3 
times during the year.  In no particular order, the DJs whose
spinning consistantly managed to take me into the highest orbit were:
Jeno, Markie, Tracy, Galen.
 
Favorite New DJ of 1994 - An Easy pick - Tracy.  Looking forward to hearing 
a lot more of her.  Runner-up: Solar.
 
*  *  *
 
1994 Chutzpah Achievement Award:
 
A confession: Weeks ago, I went early to Pacific's renegade "Down to Earth"
party and saw the police van arrive and a nearby security guard scowling
at the carloads of ravers who had started to show up.  Certain bust, I
thought, and home I went.  Oh yee of little faith!  As we now know, some 
smooth talking and palm greasing by the Pacific crew salvaged the evening,
and I ended up missing what was reported to be a great party.  Thinking 
back to the two Sunsets in the Presidio and their successful handling of 
the Berkeley Marina site, I should have realized that these guys had enough 
magic in their blood to make "Down to Earth" go off.  Then they top things 
by teaming with Cyberlab 7 for an undergound all ages party that went 
totally off while New Year's Eve parties throughout the city were getting 
shut down.  
 
In general, I really don't think Pacific had their shit together in '94
*that* much more than many of the other renegade sound systems around here.
But they seem to be plugged into some kind of positive karma, and they are
not afraid to keep putting it to the test.  In this scene, being in tune
to the forces around us and having the guts to follow one's intuition 
in the face of possible failure is what it takes to make great things 
happen.
 
*  *  *
 
Some General Observations:
 
While some people have dropped out, there's also been a large influx 
of new blood into the scene, and this fresh enthusiasm has really vitalized
things.  Less DJ worship, more vibe participation.  People are getting
back into sharing and smiling. We're starting to see a greater variety 
of DJs and a little more musical variety as well.  There are a lot of
renegade sound systems doing it out of love.  And we still have a handful 
of savy promoters who can consistantly throw larger quality parties as well.

Over the year, we've seen how it is possible for small grassroots promoters
with a community focus can build a following by throwing a series of
small undergrounds with little or no hype, and over the course of a year
rise up in the scene to become a powerful and positive force.  The most
obvious examples are Friends & Family, Tribal Funk, and Pacific.  Contrast
this with the failure of the Zippies (Megatripolis) who came into town 
with a loud splash, only to collapse under the weight of their own
pretensiousness.  Which was a shame, really, because I do think they had
some good ideas and a fresh zaniness to them.  Ideas and Hype, though, are 
no substitute for Heart.
 
We seem to finally be getting more environmentally aware.  And there's 
been *some* success working with local authorities, but plenty of nasty 
busts as well.  The few cases of violence against ravers were
very minor compared to the number of parties that went off without 
incident.  The same with chemicals..  People are still doing them of
course, but the number of accidents or freakouts remain astonishingly 
small -  as far as I can tell, anyway.  People seem to be looking out for 
and taking care of each other as raves continue to provide a supportive and 
safe setting for people to experience altered states of consciousness.
 
SFRaves also seems to be revitalized lately.  The occasional spat has not
detracted from the new enthusiasm and sense of fun here.  A lot of us are
going out and posting about our experiences.  This exchange of information
continues to help build our community.  And we're even getting to meet
each other and participate in some wonderfully successful events like
Friends & Family, New Moon, & Begin Again.
 
Hyperreal, our host computer, has been getting noticed in the World Wide 
Web universe.  I encourage everyone to try to get WWW access and explore
what hyperreal (and other sites) have to offer.  Our SFRaves vibe has 
gone global in a major way.
 
Janie & I want to thank to everyone for sharing and spreading positive 
energy in 94.  No longer a fad, it is clear that the rave/house culture is 
here to stay.  We look forward to being a part of it with you in 1995. :) 
 
Lee
____________________________________________________________________________
lxfogel@pacbell.com   (    (   (  ( ((*)) )  )   )    )    lee@hyperreal.com
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

This Area 51 stuff seems like a similar hoax, the secrecy behind
military "black ops" are a perfect breeding ground for conspiracies.
If anything I get a little annoyed at this because there are real and
important "conspiracies" that people should be paying more attention to
but are wasting their energies chasing this sci-fi stuff, e.g the
entombed experimental liquid sodium nuclear reactor (dormant since '68)
in Tenessee that nearly blew up last november (a single article on it
buried in the middle of the NYT mentioning they didn't know how they
were going to prevent this reactor from blowing in the future, that it
was too "hot" for  humans to be near, and that they were scrambling to
build custom robots to attempt to mediate the runaway nuclear
reaction... not a word on this in the papers ever since). (2) global
warming happening at an alarming rate, with recent findings showing
ocean levels rising much faster than expected and the behring glacier
sliding towards the ocean at an alarming rate because it is gliding on
a pillow of water....

But nobody in the news ever mentions this might be a problem -- don't
want to spoil an economic recovery with news that we'll face an
ecological armageddon unless we realize that striving for a strong,
energy-based economy is tantamount to ecological murder.

Nope. You shouldn't be thinking about stuff like this. Better to be
blissed out on extacy engaging in sci-fi fantasies about the
governments secret deals with aliens. 

But hey, I'll be happy to dance and shmooze at "Area 51" but don't
expect me to take all this UFO stuff w/o some humor and doubt. Hopefully,
the promoters won't go over the top on seriousness and just make this
event "fun" and "educational" ... I'm a proud owner of
"Eat Static's" 'Abduction' CD but I think it's just good music, and
interesting chill-room conversation, but that's about it...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==           Niels Mayer -- netcom!mayer -- mayer@netcom.com               ==
==	"I wanted to be a space man, that's what I wanted to be"           ==
==				 -- H.Nilssen (RIP)			   ==

Today's Examiner reports that the Dept. of Alcoholic Beverage Control
suspended the liquor licenses of DV8 and The Oasis a the request of the
SFPD who claimed violence in SOMA was causing them to deploy a
disproportionate amount of officers to the area.

DV8 at least will reopen w/o alochol on Thur.

Ironically, the SFPD admit that problems have decreased in the past 6 months.

_____

I'm fairly ignorant of licensing laws here in SF, but would the lack of
alcohol sales permit them to allow 18 and up, or possibly all ages during
the term of the suspension? Or is it more than just alcohol availability
that determines age restrictions?

wowzers, what a new year as opposed to last year.  

last year, i was one of many that ended up at the dv8 hall of messiness 
and got home to find out i was feeling so crappy all night because i got 
a 103 fever that night.  

this year, the fever came a few days early.  but i thought i wouldn't be 
able to go out if i was too sick.  by new years eve i was borderline, 
held up by ecinacea, goldenseal, ganmaoling tablets, and curing pill.  
when the clock struck midnight i was spinning a private party at Ken's 
house (non-sfr).  I believe I spun till around 1:15 am.  Then I started 
to feel a little sick again, so i juiced up once again.  Then around 3:15 
I took my "e", remembering back to a time when I was sicker and had taken 
it and it got rid of the chills.  So I stayed up all night and danced and 
played some more records in the early morning and fell asleep. The next 
morning all of my cold symptoms were completely GONE!

I just found it rather amusing because I was sick so instead of resting I 
stayed up all night and somehow cured my cold.  I am beginning to suspect 
that ecstacy has some medicinal qualities.  

Has anyone else had this type of experience?  

--->deepfog

The first time I took e I had a cold, the very next day, my cold was gone.
In fact, this new years eve I was suffering from the sniffles too, and I
took e, the next day I was fine again. Personally, I doubt that e has cold
curing abilities, however, it is well known that sweating is a good way of
getting rid of colds (as long as one doesn't sweat in cold weather),
therefore, e allows a person to sweat much (especially when in a warm
environment such as at a crowded party) and get rid much of the cold.

Sincerely,
"dragonfly"

How bout this theory? MDMA is an amphetamine derevative. Now amphetamines 
have a tendancy to kill bugs(the biological kind.) So I find this result 
quite reasonable. However on the down side, amphetamines and *SIGH* even 
e will weaken the immune system over the long term.
I must admit though the idea of running to the drug store to get some E 
for that nasty cold is much more appealing than Sudafed.... :)

Date: Sun, 1 Jan 1995 08:59:37 -48000
From: Brian Darkness <brianv@liberty.liberty.com>
Subject: Begin Again from the Heart and Soul of a Newbie

Dear Sfraves HI and Happy Happy;

	Well my end of the year went with an unusual twist of fate. I had
a ticket to go to cool world; but i blew it off and went to begin again
instead. Why throw away $26; becuase it was worth it from my perspective
at least. I had $700 on me; these things happen sometimes; didn't know a
sole and the fuzz was out in force; i'm an x-easterner, not use to covert
traffic operations; pretty scarey; anyhow. Getting back to begin again no
pun intented; but I thought it was a great party. The sand mondala in the
old computer room was really cool; the computer room was really cool in
itself; were else can you go and be surrounded my sooo much grounding and
the alter was outta site; i felt a little linguring catholic remorse; 
like i should offer up a pray or something; it was quite inspiring. 
Personnal note lose all catholic guilt for 1995. So here I find myself at
this wonderful intimate party with a bunch of people I don't know; 
rolling my brains out; and I felt perfectly at home. Of course the
music was great; I do not know west coast dj enough to comment whether a
particular dj had a good or bad night; so I won't. I guess for me the 
most cosmic part was when I walked outside the building at about 8am to go 
and type this document for yous; Was that I realized it was New Year Day, 
1995 and that I had finally arrived here in san francisco. It was at that 
moment that this very different and strange place became home to me. 
Happy New Year Everyone it feels good to be home :)!!!!!!! Opps also my 
thanks to whomever put that wonderfull party together.

						Peace & Love
						brianv@liberty.com
						aka Brian Darkness

PS My other New Years Resolutions:

	1. To continue to fight all forms of opression were I find it.
	2. To find more time to hug the people I love; like; and even 
		more important; the people I don't. 
	3. Jettsion all excess emotional bagage and leave it were it 
		belongs it the past.
	4. To continue to increase my overall awareness about whats 
		really going on out there.

See ya on the bit stream!!!!!

yowza!  Thanks again to the avid readers (and writers!) of sfraves, for the
   recommendation on Begin Again, which just totally kicked:
 - amazing, phat tunes - _all_ the dj's I heard were just on.
 - how many rooms? something like 7-10, well connected... nice space.
   gorgeous decorations...
 - friendly food/drink bar, some munchies in the am... plenty o water...
 - very, very nice light show and video setup.  hats off!
 - amazing vibe.  Little paranoia baloney- lotsa do-your-own-thing...
   especially in the chill room... (although the chill room didn't have the
   tunes like some other parties have had :-(... but it _was_ in a machine
   room, which made up for it... very tempted to lift up one of the tiles...
   For the record, it was "only" 84 degrees in there, even though it felt
   much worse.

I only saw crunch there - sorry I missed the rest of you guys!  arrived at
   midnight, stayed til 6am... friend from out of town (newbie raver)
   totally flew with it.  Just "stunned for three rounds" on the whole
   scene.

peace and choice,
adam

---------- Forwarded message ----------
From: Jason Sydes <jsydes@osiris.ac.hmc.edu>
Subject: cool world riot? (fwd)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Tue, 3 Jan 1995 03:24:54 -0800 (PST)

Ann Elizabeth Loraine wrote:
> 
> 
> one of many rumors circulating was that there was a riot at cool world on
> newyearseve.  does anybody know what happened?  
> 
> -ann
> 



Very true. As all of my friends had already bought (expensive) tickets to
your typical massive, I got dragged into doing the same, and missing what I
had told them was going to be a great party at Begin Again (I'm even sadder
now that I've read today's posts).

The line to get in was probably half a mile long, a dozen people wide, and
moving at snail pace. Fortunately I found old friends at the very front, and
probably saved us an hour. Another friend of mine was at the front when they
told everyone to get in single file around 11:30??. People started yelling
and rushed the security, after which they closed the doors. Great way to
generate a good vibe!  :(

I was able to salvage a pitiful night when I headed out of the shit music
room (they started playing that eeny-wheeny penis song, entertaining, but
hardly belonging at a good rave) and into the techno room. The music here
was actually really decent, and had a rather good vibe, until they ran into
technical problems. 

I missed Amy Starkey, who I met at the Gathering (wazup Amy! BTW Amy, I ran
into that girl who was REALLY happy last time, and her boyfriend
too. Needless to say, her eyes weren't as wide this time.)

Overall the party was ok, but definitely not $20 ok. That is by far the 1st
and LAST Cool World I will ever hit. I'll speak my mind a bit louder next
time and stick with the underground and (from what I hear) positive.


Luv ya SF

Jason


Jason_Sydes@hmc.edu

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Subject: Re: NYE: the real story
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Tue, 3 Jan 1995 14:04:22 -0800 (PST)
From: JUMP IN THE FIRE <grigsby@agames.com>

Quoth resonate:

> it turns out that the story i heard from police about why they shut down
> the Other New Years Ball was false.
> 
> they did not shut it down for door admission. they shut it down because they
> fucked up and everything at that party was in order so far as we can tell.

Since there are rather large monetary damages involved (loss of
investment, loss of potential income, loss of reputation, time,
etc.), the promoters could likely find a lawyer who would take the
case on spec.  A class-action suit against the police filed by
everyone who attended and got kicked out (filed by the same lawyer)
would also be possible.

If the party was truly 100% legal than the police dept. deserves to
get smacked around.  Indeed, the only way to prevent further abuses of
the sort is to bite them back -- otherwise they will continue to shut
down parties based on doubtful evidence, because they know there is no
consequence to them for doing so.

If I were the promoter and I was sure I had my house in order, I would 
get a few consultations from various law firms to see what I could do.

// g

Subject: police brutality 

Hello.

I'm sending this to you because you are involved with a rave 
mailing list, although I don't know the name or how to 
subscribe.  Is it rave-net?
I'm sending you a little info and perhaps you have some 
ideas...

--gabriel


The following is a copy of a letter to the editor of several 
local
papers regarding a brutal illegal police raid on an AIDS 
benefit 
party.  We understand that police cracked down on several 
parties
and raves New Years Eve, and we need your support in 
documenting
police brutality, hate crimes, and other abuses -- particularly
at the Visual Aid benefit held at 938 Harrison on New Years 
Eve.
Please call 415-267-6142 if you have any related information 
and tell anyone you know who attended it is critical to 
document
this immediately.


===============================================================

We were at a New Years Eve benefit for Visual Aid, a nonprofit
organization which gives art supplies to artists with AIDS, 
when
police suddenly shut down the event without explanation.  We 
had
just commented on what a wonderful event the night turned out 
to be
-- a celebration of diversity, community, and hope for 1995 in 
a
safe, alcohol-free environment -- when police stormed the 
building.

The organizers immediately turned off the music and announced 
that
the party was over.  After arresting the organizers, the police
moved in, pushing and shoving the crowd towards the door 
without
allowing people time to retrieve their belongings, causing a
panicked rush to the coat room and forcing HIV positive 
individuals
out into the rain.

We saw no resistance from any of the attendees, but we did 
witness
the police using unnecessary force in clear disregard of the 
law
and of our safety.  We saw a man asking an officer for his 
badge
number thrown to the floor onto his face.  A woman 
photographing
this incident was tackled by a group of officers, thrown 
against a
wall, and arrested.  Hundreds of people witnessed officers 
laughing
and jeering, making statements such as "I've never seen so many
freaks in my life" and "Let's clear these faggots out of here."

We are appalled and outraged by the conduct of the San 
Francisco
Police Department.  We do not believe the citizens of San 
Francisco
support wasting tax money on harassing private benefits.  The 
gay
community, for one, will not stand by while our people are
brutalized.

Peter Veilleux and Gabriel Plumlee

Hello.  
Here are some updates about the SFPD raid on the Visual Aid benefit on New Years Eve.  

Witnesses of Hate Crimes, brutality, and other illegal actions by police at the Visual Aid benefit should call 415-267-6142.

To report Hate Crimes in particular at any event, call Community United Against Violence (CUAV) at 415-777-5500.

It is very important to immediately write down what you saw, including details such as the color of uniforms and badges, and mannerisms or features of officers like hair color, facial hair, height, glasses, and expression.  Do this now while the image is fresh.

11 am at city hall...(for updates or info call 267 6142) I have a feeling

(also fyi the major nye party on the east coast "Heaven" also got busted)

This artical is taken from tuesday jan 3, 1995 (cool i remembered to type 
1995 and not 1994...good karma for the new year) SF Chronicle

 COMPLAINT OVER POLICE RAID ON AIDS BENEFIT
by J.L. Pimsleur

     A group of 30 gay men and women said last night that they are 
filling charges with the Office of Citizen Complaints in connection with 
what they termed a "violent and totally unjustified" raid by San 
Francisco police on a private New Year's Eve party.

     Raymond Liberti, one of the organizers of the party, said that 
shortly after 4 a.m. Sunday, at least 40 police officers, wearing 
windbreakers that obsured their badges, "agressively invaded" a private, 
invitation-only benefit for an AIDS support group attended by about 500 
people.

     According to Liberti, no fees were charged to enter the party and no 
alcoholic beverages were served.  Donations for the fundraiser wer 
voluntary, he said.

     The police version the incident differed sharply from that of the 
party organizers.  Eleven people were arrested on a variety of charges, 
including narcotics possession, drunk and disorderly conduct, and 
resisting arrest, according to police.

     A police source said last night that Alcoholic Bererage Control Board 
agents were present at the event and that the raid took place because the 
ABC agents "had resaon to believe" alcohol was being served at te event, 
fees were bing charged and no permit had been granted for such a party.  
The source declined to elaborate on further police action at the event.

     The benefit, held in a warehouse at 938 Harrison Street, was a 
fund-raiser for Visual Aid, a nonprofit organization that helps artists 
with AIDS.

     Liberti said police burst in and ordered the party closed.

     "Within moements--and without offical public orders to 
disperse--many individuals were brutally hearded into police vans, while 
being subjected to a barrage of anti-homosexual remarks," Liberti said.

     He also said officers injured about a dozen people by punching, 
choking and using police batons on party-goers.  Liberti also said police 
confiscasted a cash register containing $600, the proceeds from the juice 
and soda sales, as well as thousands of dollars worth of stereo 
equiptment and personal property--without issuing any receipts.

     Oraganizers said the only reason the police knew of the event at al 
was because the group "followed all the correct procedures,": informed 
authoriites of the time and place of the event and asked if the party 
needed a permit.

     According to Liberti, the organizers were told they did not need a 
permit if they did not serve liquor and did not charge a door fee to get in.
     
     He and other events organizers said that in addition to filing the 
OCC complaint, the group intentds to voce its protest in a news 
conference at City Hall this week.  Group members also plan to sue the 
city and lodge a protest before the Police Commision and the Board of 
Supervisors.

     According to party oraganizers, the event wouldn up losing money, 
after factoring in the $10,000 it cost to bail out the 11 people who were 
arrested.

Message-Id: <199501041727.JAA18646@taz.hyperreal.com>
Subject: Call for Help at Komotion
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Wed, 4 Jan 1995 09:33:35 -0800 (PST)
From: "Bryce Ryan" <brycer@ultima.org>
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
Content-Type: text
Content-Length: 2244
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Greetings, ravers!

As some of you know, Komotion (the location for the past 3 Friends and
Family parties, and scene of many other fine, community based music and
art events) is in the process of negotiations with various authorities
and organizations in an effort to continue doing the fine work they do
in their current space.

As many of you who attended the last event may have noticed (and this 
happened at the one before it, too), a *lot* of graffiti and general
thrashing are now on the walls.  Also, many of the events that are held
in the space cause wear and tear and cosmetic damage to the building's
interior and exterior.

Given upcoming visits by various members of various bureaucracies, and
in an effort to keep the place neat and clean, a series of work parties
are scheduled during this month at Komotion.  WE REALLY NEED YOU TO COME
DOWN AND HELP US MAINTAIN THE SPACE! 

On Saturday, January 7, and Saturday, January 14th, Komotion will be open
from 10AM to 4PM to clean up, paint, tidy up, and generally improve the
space. Also, on Sunday, January 22nd, there will be a clean up
party (the time is a little more vague).  Paint, cleaning supplies,
music, and friends will all be there to help restore the building to its
original luster.

Please, if *any* of you have *any* time during those days to help clean
up Komotion, and help us maintain this valuable community space that
has been such a gracious host to the SFRaves community, stop by and lend
your efforts.  Komotion is an entirely volunteer supported arts collective
that has been supporting the underground community in the Bay Area for
almost ten years.  They have opened their doors and hearts to support us
over the past year, and really need our help and support.  No scheduling
or contact on your part are needed, and any efforts on your part will
be appreciated. You will also be able to meet the other members of
Komotion, and other members of SFRaves.

Thank you for your support in the past...help us keep Komotion available
to us, and the rest of the underground community, for a long time to come.

Komotion is located at 2779 16th Street, at Folsom, in San Francisco.

-- 
====== Bryce Ryan ========== AMBIANCE ========= brycer@ultima.org =========

> places including the sound factory are under investigation...according to 
> bay tv this morning...with some wacky footage of the putting up the 
> suspention order...soma seems to be under attack...(one soma gas station 
> owner in the story complained that the crowds outside the clubs were 
> unruley...which leads me to believe that club owners have a 
> responsibility to help maintain the area around the club...and that kids 
> need something productive...oh such as music appreciation and 
> dancing...and not being left out on the street) hmmmm
> 
> susie (:

Down here, about a year ago, there was an all ages 
(read mostly high school age attendees) 
club in a pretty bad part of town.  
While the club was going on the crime rate in the area dropped immensely
because of the amount of security that the club had in the area
around the club and the police had thanked them for this.
When the club stopped, parents and grandparents called up asking
that they open up again so that they're children and grandchildren
would have something to do besides roam the street.

Problem is that the club stopped becuase someone said they were serving
alcohol to minors. (There was no alcohol in the club when the
police came in to shut it down and there never had been any alcohol
being served behind a bar or anythign)

I don't really know what the point of this story is...
on the one hand, i think it's to say that even as a group of people
that likes to party all nite doing whatever else,
we can show that there can be a benefit in this by keepign kids
off the street and what not...

But on teh other hand, its when we do that that people seem 
to get even more upset and start lying and getting more abusive
of their power.

 ,
dana

"Get your mind set in the groove it should follow."

Subject: Begin Again or WOWIE ZOWIE (a.long.gush!!)

Wowie Zowie!!!!!!! There's a yuletide expletive you probably didn't hear
during the holidays.  But, I need a BIG BRAND NEW Happy New Year adjective to
tell you about how much fun I had at...BEGIN AGAIN------

Now, I am particular to the Digital Media boyz.

  They're in part,  responsible for getting this once rapidly aging person's
butt a' gyratin' on the dance floor like a demented whirlin' dervish... (I
know some of you shield your eyes and turn away in horror and flee scrreaming
into the night!!!!) The very thought of over-forty flesh giggling about,
trying keep time to the thumpin' BPM's is enough to disturb any sensible
person.


We made some bigtime fun at BEGIN AGAIN. If you were there, you helped to
create it--a big THANK YOU to everyone!!! I'm finally gettin exactly what
Ethan means when he says, "We couldn't have done it without you!!!!" You knew
the moment you got there, "DIS MUS BE DA PLACZ"..........

 ...... cool, well-lit, separate environments you could drift in and out of
easily banks of.computers , walls alive and pulsating..with color and
motion....people lying all along the walls..a warm tremoulous humm of talking
and laughter-friendly faces looking up at you- AND

  --Friendly Guys at the Door.!!!!  Who were those guys? (When was the last
time someone at the door said "Hi!!!Welcome...have a great time"  I am sorry
I didn't acknowlege and tip those guys.( We should reward the good guys and
shun some of the underworld security trolls.....)  You could move easily from
environment to environment -through an oozing sea of schmooooozy smiley
faces.

 People were definately happy. We were all winning game show contests who
selected "the cool party behind curtain number 4...instead of the buckett of
shit behind door number 1)..............and no lovely parting gift to take
the stink away.....

 Lotz of Sfravers there. I walked in right into a big hug from Geoff W.-- Big
Howdies and hugs from all the other SFravERS who were

there........LeeJanieGregCINDYGregAnnTOddTODDDaveMarkTraciCrUnchAlleNethanM...
......
and all the you I'm talking to who waz there!!!!!!! My only regret is that
the raveFearless compadre Lane-O, the frabulous beaker boy Grad Vunderkid
from the uc Davis wing of the rave party...choose (.........drumroll
please............)

Curtain Number 3......and was not there "to assist me withal" in the
beheading of Father Time.

Where was Senior Brian--the huggy bear from the Sac attack squad?

It is my fondest wish that Ya'll "flamed mightily where ever your torch cast
its glowing beacon of light."........ (I mean,.... I hope you had a real good
time where ever you were)

I met Dan Mapes (Digital Media) two years ago when they worked out of these
funky collection of barns in Santa Cruz/Soquel. (..compare to the 340 Bryant
digs!!!!!!) 

My friend Forest, the slightly balding, jolly Scootish looking guy in the
polka-dot vest-the Walter "Grand Pappy" Brennen of Ravin'-invited me to see
their hippy dippy looking garage "offices".    Kinda dumpy lookin' sheds and
hovels,  peopled with computer dweeds in tye-dye.... .Hoping they could do
some consulting,  or training for my work on an Amiga-2000 video editing
station, as I began work on a video yearbook at the re-structured high school
where I work. Little did I know they had more to show me than 3-D modeling,
 graphic pix-mixing for psychedelic video effects. The obvious similarity
between certain video effects and various states of altered consciousness,
should have been my first "red flag," that I would soon be "tip-toeing
through the tulips" of my mind again. 

After they had boot me, bedazzled me, fantazmagorized me, and made computer
graphic linguini of my eyeballs--they invited me to attend a "party" where 
they would be doing a computer generated light and laser show -while a "Dj
will play records....... ("you mean like one of those MTV guys I hate"--I
asked ever so delicately and intelligently) .........But,... I
digress.........indulge me coz........

I like reading other personal vignettes which reveal how we were each
ensnared or kidnapped (at first, no doubt, unwillingly)--by friends intent on
dragging us down into the vice-ridden vinyl netherworlds.........

So. BEGIN AGAIN was one of my all-time best parties that I attended in my
short year and 9 months of revelling and raving. As an AIDS benefit, as a
Company committed to its community-as a Mixed-Age crowd--Every heart and Hand
there seemed to be pumpin'  in sinc, warm and open.   AND   (.........why was
everyone's hand sooooooo sweaty?)

 Great friends, Great dancers, Great costumes... and "music to make the
heavens open up and weep angelic tears........(I wish I had said that...) To
Pacific..and all Mad Music Minions (Dj's)--& crew--We give you the coveted,
."Kicked it"  award for outstanding Butt Thumpin music all night......(You
(deejays) danced the whole enchilada out of this dripping Amigo)

Thanks to all for making LAST year a Happy New Year--Let's have BEGIN AGAIN
and
F&FV set the standard for all parties in the upcoming year. My New Year's
resolution is to "Accept No Substitutues."---

" This is the real thing, the real thing..the real thing..the real
thing.......vocal sample ad infinitum...........................a jingle-bell
techno-Christmas Carol for the future.....or maybe I'll keep muttering 'Wowie
Zowie Wowie Zowie" to myself, everytime I think about that BEGIN AGAIN.

                                                             Joyfully Yours
from 94...................robertj 
                                                             Still wet in the
drawers          
                                                             How bout Yours?

from the chron today wed jan 4....
(i will type in the others later after i give my wrists a rest)

RIBERA PLANS INQUIRY INTO PARTY RAID

Thaai Walker
     San Francisco Police Chief Anthony  Ribera said yesterday that his 
department will conduct an investigation into a New Year's party raid that 
critics have labeled a gay-bashing incident.

     The department's internal affairs unit will look into allegations 
that officers used excessive force and anti-gay epithets while closing 
down the party at 4 a.m. Sunday in the South of Market area, Ribera said.

     "If those allegations are found to be true, the department will take 
appropriate action," the chief said in a news conference.  "We will not 
tolerate that type of activity."

     Organizers of the event and party-goers, who say they plan to file a 
complaint with the Office of Citizen Complaints, claim that police 
punched people in the face, used choke holds, covered or refused to show 
badges, unlawfully searched and seized property, and made false arrests 
and unlawful detentions--in addition to subjecting several party-goers to 
ani-gay slurs.

     About 600 people attended the party, which organizers described as 
an invitation-only benefit for Visual Aid, a support group for artists 
living with AIDS.

    Eleven people, including some party organizers, were arrested in the 
raid and booked on charges that included narcotics possession, drunk and 
disorderly conduct, and resisting arrest.
     
     The raid was "the biggest human rights outrage against queers and 
people with AIDS since the Castro Street Sweep in 1989," said gay rights 
activist Gerard Koshovich, who did not attend the party but was contacted 
by the organizers after the raid.

     In the 1989 sweep, officers were accused of using excessive force 
and hurling anti-gay slurs in a violent confrontation that grew out of a 
demonstration in the Castro district.  More than three dozen allegations 
of police misconduct were filed with the Office of Citizen Complaints, 
the city's police watchdog agency.  Several other people sued the 
department and the city because of the fracas.

     Yesterday, supervisors Angela Alioto, Terence Hallinan and Carole 
Migden called for a board hearing on the Sunday morning raid.

     "I am shocked by the many reports I have received from people who 
attended this event," Hallinan said. "I question why it was necessary for 
dozens of police officers to storm this private event."

     Police denied party-goers' claims that the gay community was 
targeted in the raid and said officers were simply closing down an 
unlawful party.

     "What concerns me is a perception that this was a police vs. gays 
issue--at this time, I don't believe it was," Ribera said.

     Southern Police Station Captain Michael Yalon, who headed the raid, 
said: "In closing this club we had no idea that this was a gay event.  
The closure of this illegal nightclub was not any different from any 
others we did that night or have done any other weekend."

     According to Yalon, about 40 police officers and state Alcohol and 
Beverage Control agents raided the party in a warehouse at 938 Harrison 
Street because the event  was held without proper police permits.  Yalon 
said organizers did not have alcohol, dancing or entertainment permits 
and did not have permission to hold an event that continued after 2 a.m.

     Police said they were told of the party Friday by fire department 
officials who learned of it through a South of Market nightclub owner.

     Yalon said Officer Dan O'Shea, who is in charge of issuing permitts to 
nightclubs, contacted the party organizers and told them they could not 
hold the party without the proper permits.

     But organizers contend O'Shea told them it would be all right to hold 
the party as long as liquor was not served and no entry fee was 
charged.  They said they abided by the rules.

     According to the police report, officers who raided the warehouse 
found "numerous bottles of beer and champagne," but did not confiscate 
the bottles.  The report also stated that offices observed "numerous acts 
of oral copulation," and sodomy talking place inside the warehouse.

     The raid was "the biggest human rights outrage against queers and
people with AIDS since the Castro Street Sweep in 1989," said gay rights
activist Gerard Koshovich, who did not attend the party but was contacted
by the organizers after the raid.
-----------------------

And we all know how the shit hit the fan over that Castro street sweep,
right?  Correct, we *DO* know what happened; the people of San Francisco,
in a vain decision to spite Agnos, decided to elect the man apparently
responsible (along with his brother, so the story goes) for the Castro
street sweep as *MAYOR*.  So it's a big surprise that the police department
is acting up again, correct?  WRONG!!!!  Perhaps these facts need to be
made more popularly known...

lat,

*

I find this thread quite interesting. I had a somewhat similar 
experience. I had some blisters and I bit my tongue a little due to some 
medicinal side effects but I had had such an amazing experience when I 
woke up after some sleep my tongue was fine.

My friend Morgan calls a good rave or celeberation "Public Health". The 
benefical psychological effects of a good party definitely help the body. 
The mind and body are connceted! Though we in the West tend to forget this.

I hope these kind of insights can help us build ecstatic and healing 
communities.

Peace,
ronan
