I'll send this today, hoping to keep the flames in the old year :)


We are looking for a person with expertise in (preferably more than) one of
the following fields: Windows, Unix, Mac, GUI, WWW and other Internet protocols
(did I covered almost everything in the SW world ? :) to help me to complete a
product related to the Internet (sorry, I cannot be more specific now).

It can be a part-time job, with the possibility to become full-time.

What do we offer:

* A nice office in the heart of the Silicon Valley :( :( :(
* A techno/rave-friendly ambient: 30% of the company (: me :) is rave-addicted,
	but with your help we'll be 50% :)
* Hopefully soon a fast Internet connection, to download tons of junk :( tired
	to browse the net at 14Kb ):
* The possibility to become rich and famous (: at least a bit richer and
	more known :)
* Some money, too :)

PLEEZE, PLEEZE, HELP ME, otherwise next year I will have no time
to go out and party :( :( :(

If U are interested, give me a call to one of the following number or send me
e-mail at raffs@netcom.com.


In the mean time I wish U ALL a 

	Very Happy Raving New Year full of Peace, Love and Great Parties.

-- Raffaele

Responding to msg by anthrax@uclink.berkeley.edu (Ann Elizabeth 
Loraine) on Mon, 2 Jan  8:23 PM

>
>one of many rumors circulating was that there was a 
>riot at cool world on  newyearseve.  does anybody know 
>what happened?  
>
>-ann

I can confirm what exactly happened.  The Cow Palace really 
screwed over Cool World on Saturday, and they were highly 
understaffed.  People were getting angry about being out in the 
rain, so, to avoid any further troubles, Cool World opened the 
doors and let in close to 3,000 people for free to make up for 
the problem.  It wasn't a riot, but would have been if everyone 
hadn't gotten in.

Dj Dave Alga

Subject: This Week's SF Rave Guide!
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com (SFRaves)

I haven't read all of my mail so I might have missed something anyone has
sent me, but I seem to have some stuff anyway.  Move! earns its name by
moving to Il Pirata this week (don't know if that's permanent), and a small
crowd (a large gathering?) grooved to some good sets from Spun and Garth.
Last night Come/Unity was packed, and seemed to achieve critical mass for
a small nuclear explosion :).  Friday, 1015 Folsom might be a good destination
again (if you can handle the usual Friday yuppies), or Hotbox as an 
unpretentious underground.  Saturday brings Mixmaster Morris to the San
Francisco Bay, check it out if you're an ambient musique fan...

    ----------------------
==== THE SFRAVES CALENDAR ==================================================
    ----------------------

Friday, January 6th - THC presents Hotbox
        Kevin  Rob Doten  Rob Drake  Malcolm  
        Free all night - 10pm-6am.
        510.287.5545

Friday, January 6th - Evolving Times presents Tribal Trance Dance
        Special quests : SAHAR (performing live)
        DJ Rig-A-Tony and Voice Toning by Gina Beck. 
        Eastern Star Temple, 2719 K Street. (across from sutters Fort)
        8PM to 1 AM, $10 cover, for more info call 916.737.8463. 
        Ethnic vendors, smart products, tribal body painting
        performing arts, live african dance lessons, tribal rhythm circles.

Saturday, January 7th - Ambient Jungle cruise on the bay w/MixMaster Morris
        + SpaceTime Continuum & DJs Thomas & Nick Philip
        $25; only 200 tickets available.  Tix @ Housewares, 1332 Haight.
        415.241.1560

Saturday, January 7th - buger*down Productions presents Masjestic
        415.764.0288

Saturday, January 7th - Deep Dish
        Joe Rice & others
        Sonoma County, 415.789.8452

Wednesday, January 11th - Blueprint
        Crunch  YT  Corey Black  Jason Boyd
        1015 Folsom, 10p-6a.  21+, $5.

Wednesday, January 11th - A Party from the People
        415.995.9622

Saturday, January 14th - Area 51 
        Carlos  Dutch  Christophe  Josh Wink (Phila.)  Taylor (LA)
        Tiga (Montreal)  Simon  Jeno  Garth  Markie  Thomas
        visuals by Synergy and Optica Lux
        $20 w/canned food for Project Open Hand
        415.615.8559   510.273.9329  408.491.9220  707.523.8783

Sunday, January 15th - MLK Spundae
        Tony Humphries  C.J.Macintosh
        Jay-J  DJ Dan  Simon  Carlos  Garth  Jeno  Markie  Henrik  Mark Farina
        Utopia  Josh  Miguel  John Howard  Suiki
        1015 Folsom @ 6th.  9pm-8am, 21+
        415.974.9389

Friday, January 20th - Organic presents Hardkiss - the Hardkiss family
        Delusions of Grandeur Tour Preview
        Live and Direct: Rabbit in the Moon and Hawke
        Plus DJs Robbie and Scott Hardkiss with 
        notorious sidekicks Keoki, Derrick Carter, Mark Farina, Galen,
                Wade Randolph Hampton
        415.266.8215

        Jeno  Garth  Scott Hardkiss  Reese  Taj  Markie  Robbie Hardkiss  
        Thomas  Skylab  Gavin Hardkiss  Jonah Sharpe  Charles Uzell Edwards
        Darkhorse  Professor Smith  Jon Williams  John Howard  Raymond Roker
        Wade Randolph Hampton
        1015 Folsom, SF.  415.979.8444

        the San Francisco House Movement comes together to benefit Project
        Open Hand at 1015 Folsom, Planet San Francisco
        admission - 3 cans of organic food
        415.435.8675

I have had many reports on the COOL WORLD debacle/rave and I have always 
tried to stay supportive of cool world (except for the cheezy flyers 
which I have always hated). I was given two tickets and decided to visit 
cool world since I give out so much advice at ameba as to which rave to 
go to. I went paid my six bucks parking at 11:20 pm and found a line far 
bigger than anything I had ever seen except maybe the gay parade. It was 
raining. They were raising and lowering a board as groups of fifty 
scuried to get searched. The line looked like a few hours wait. I could 
not get in because I did not have a line pass. Thanx for the tickets ,I 
gave them away.

Many people at cool world who arrived before 10pm got in and some had a 
pretty good time. One person described how they went inside the ticketing 
area to buy tickets and the gates closed and they were trapped. the 
security told them that they were rioting outside and they would have to 
wait.
All those people in line had tickets. Cops making arrests and asking 
people to stop flashing colors.

Some have said cool world got nervous as sales of tickets were smalla 
couple days before the event so they let go of a large amount of security 
personel. ticket sales on the last day went up and replacements could not 
be found. Perhaps one could argue cow palace bad/cool world good . I have 
heard the cool world takes pride in providing all ages large raves.

I think tthe cool world flyers promis sex to adolescent males and are 
targeting them in the same way that Rambo movies target adolescent males.
I think they gamble more than they should with the well being of the 
hords they attract.

>From what I saw with my own eyes was a CRUEL WORLD
salutations, allen@ameba

I remember taking a class on comedy and we talked at great length about
the power of laughter and humour.  Remember the terms, "He is in ill-
humour," etc?  Or someone can feel "Out of humour"...of course,
in the old days the humours referred to the liquids in the body, blood,
water, sweat (and some others, but you get the idea -- i think these 
are the right ones)--if you got out of humour, you had an imbalance in
your system, and they tried to bleed it out of you. 
It has been shown that people feel better after a good laugh--good humour--
which involves good, positive energy, like the kind you discover at a
truly good party.  You body takes in this energy, this humour, and cleanses
itself with it.  It's truly cool.  My teacher worked with criticaly ill
AIDS patients, using humour therapy to get them through their last days,
"before they got invited to the other side."

So I believe any healing people are getting is the mixture of the e letting
you free your humours and the vibe of a really good party...

just my $.02..

have a good weekend!

m

(and keep in good humour!)

Subject: gender damage

Excuse me for getting cranky and stuck in gender issues, but i still 
wanna know why house/dance/ambient etc. djs are almost all men!!??

This is part of why i dropped out of your scene with its 
egalitarian/utopian aims (or hollow pretensions?).
Someone please tell me i'm wrong, that there's plenty of female or 
transgender djs out there...or that Your Sister's House is still active.

Are the dancers and partyersapprox half women- if not, why aren't they on 
the decks?  The finest djs just happen to be men, is that it? (Or is the 
whole electro culture thing mostly appealing to men? If so then i'll shut 
up and things might make sense.)
I haven't been out since March, so i'm out of it- please tell me if i'm 
way off!!  

Claiming to be healers (and many of you) Gaia-centric, or amorphous 
androgynous and ecstatic and the whole wonderful, loopy story, i still 
think you're controlled, or at least lead, by men.
Am i wrong to point fingers- dj opportunities have been wide open for 
women, they just haven't come forward?..i'm getting redundant now, but i 
just wonder what the real reasons are, if they're determinable, and if 
anything is wrong or not.   ??????????
I have waited, for years and years, for things to change and they haven't
(and if this is old news on the list, forgive me, i've never subscribed 
regularly)
"Is this what you wanted, is this how you wanted things to be, i wanna 
know, i wanna know, i wanna know..."(Meat Beat Manifesto)
thankyou my sweet delirious kittens, tinydancer

>I can confirm what exactly happened.  The Cow Palace really 
>screwed over Cool World on Saturday, and they were highly 
>understaffed.  People were getting angry about being out in the 
>rain, so, to avoid any further troubles, Cool World opened the 
>doors and let in close to 3,000 people for free to make up for 
>the problem.  It wasn't a riot, but would have been if everyone 
>hadn't gotten in.
>
>Dj Dave Alga
>

I do not understand how the cow palace could have 
screwed over cool world ?? doesn't the promoter 
hire the security ?? you are correct they were 
very understaffed.  being new years there should have been 
alot more security searching people to let them in 
quicker.  also the guys in the yellow jackets "event staff"
were very, very and I repeat very unfriendly, they were 
shoving people yelling at them and slamming the doors on 
them.  the reason people stormed the doors is there were 
only two doors opened.  no direction as towhat was happening.
over 3,000 people in line past 12:00.  happy new year spent standing in 
the rain.  

another thing I think cool world bowed down to greed and 
the mighty buck $$$$$$$.  what happened to the doors opening 
at 9:00 pm ???
cool worl did not let 3,000 people in for free everyone in 
line were ticket holders and at an outrageous $30.00 (greed-greed)
what fantastic thing did cool world have that warranteed 
a $30. admission.  please don't try to pass off that klf was there
we already read about that, it was only the back up singer wanda dee.
cool world capitalized on the evening.

but they were not the only one.   I am happy to see that dv8 lost
their license for 3 weeks.  maybe they will lose all the money the
unrightfully charged on new years.  $35.00 to stand in line for 3 hours
only to make it inside another cattle-like holding area.  which was better 
than making it inside to the death trap.  several friends of mine made
it inside.  once inside could not even get a drink, hot, smokey no 
ventilation people were crammed together miserable and angery.
the staff there were also very rude.

I think both promotors lost sight of what these parties were to 
be about.  bringing in the new year with family and friends 
getting together with fellow ravers and having a great time.
I agree they should make money at this,  it does take time and alot 
of effort to pull together.  but they should not only see the $$$$
to the point were people lives are endangered, the fun is taken out
of it.  those ticket prices are too outrageous.  

it seems to me that friends and family is the way to go... 
I still have not been to one but that is my new years resolution
to avoid commercialized money hungry raves and only go to those 
that truly care about everyone having a great time and not taking 
away hard earned money.
  
well, now that that is off my chest.... on with another year 
its all behind me now.  move forward, shifting gears, putting 
on a happy face and attitude on life.

grins and smiles......

I'd have to agree that there aren't that many female DJs out there, but I
think (correct me if I'm wrong, I'm a commuter SFRaver and LARaver) that
there were two new female DJs this year, Tracy and someone else (sorry I
forgot your name!).

But yeah, it does seem like most DJs are men. Don't want to get too
political or sociological here, but I think that's just generally
representative of your typical gender power structure. It does kinda suck,
but I think we should be positive here and completely support all the womyn
DJs out there, and all aspiring ones too. Things *are* changing (slowly).

But hey! We also have one of the best scenes anywhere, and a lot of that can
be contributed to the kick-ass DJs that give their time and energy to our
parties. A lot of them are male, some are female, but I think we can all
agree that without them, we wouldn't be much. 

Positive Vibe Always

Jason

Message-Id: <v01510102ab33893750ba@[204.118.88.22]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Fri, 6 Jan 1995 17:47:37 -0800
To: Brian <Mdma@eworld.com>, David Alves <alves@bethe.ucdavis.edu>
From: infinity@aimnet.com (Infinity)
Subject: Re: Tribal Funk's Wed party (late re:)
Cc: SFRavers <sfraves@hyperreal.com>

Precedence: bulk

David Alves (alves@bethe.ucdavis.edu) bums out:

> reruns
> tribal funk's wednesday party was kinda weak
> low energy, medium small rehersal space
> with a big laser, black lights, and strobes
> there was no escape ...
> the dj I saw did alot of silly
> rock n roll air guitar moves
> like fake scratching
> unfortunately
> his set was
> pretty
> dull

Brian (mdma@eworld.com) makes out through the haze:

> hmmm.... met  a lot of new faces and saw some friends that hadn't been
> seen since october.....wish it would have been longer.  thought the
> drive from salinas was worth it =)


Now I know that I'm replying to this all a little bit to late, but I
thought I might put in my $.02 here about Tribal Funk's Wed. party "last
year in December" (yow-ee that sounds long ago!).

I too attended the party, and while the space was fairly stuffy, damn smoky
<cough, cough>, and the temperature did get up in the low 80's, I have to
admit I undenyably had a wonderful, awesome time that night!

It was amazing to walk into a room, either the ambient room or the main
dance floor, to suddenly be surrounded from all sides, everywhere I look,
wall to wall friends, friends, and more friends.  These were people ranging
from those I had only "seen around" at parties, to those that I had met and
gotten to know a little better on several occassions before, to those whom
I have been building relationships with from all the way back to my early
days of raving, which would be about 10 months now!

It felt as though I knew almost every person there.  There were a few faces
that I didn't recognize from anywhere, but to make up for it I saw a few
people I didn't expect to ever see again, including someone that I used to
go to Junior High School with many years ago.  The last time I remember
having spoken with him was in 8th grade -- and here I meet him for the
first time in years.  It turns out he has been going to rave parties for
about 2 years now, so it was a real trip to exchange stories right there,
comfortable as a clam on that couch I was, dazing off into those very
brilliantly set up Intelli-beam lights (pun intended) on one end of the
room.  Absolutely amazing shit.


Now the music... I was only on the dance floor about half of the night, but
when I was there, the music was nothing short of pretty darn good.

Notably (only in my brain), I noticed that Carlos FINALLY changed his set a
little bit.  And it was truly a real treat to hear a very cabably-mixed,
dancable, upbeat trance set by visiting DJ Trance (LA).

I think Carlos is a good DJ with strong mixing skills and the ability to
choose songs that he feels will "pump up" the crowd.  His energy is just
awesome -- its so cool to see that little guy up there dancing at the
turntables, throwing out a few vocal "Ehy!  Ehy!  Ehy!" hoots in good time
to the music.  While Carlos is a pretty darn good DJ, I feel that the last
several months have not been his best as far as being original in his
choice of songs to play.  It just seems that my experience has been that I
end up telling myself "these songs are from the same set Carlos ALWAYS
plays from".

However, last Wednesday, unless it was just my tweaked perception, I
thought Carlos went <Ka-BOOM> and took off into a wonderful new set full of
cool new songs that still fit his style, and brilliant new mixes I don't
think I had ever heard before.  Furthermore, when it comes to scratching,
Carlos usually seems to favor the more "<wik wikky-wikky, wik-wik wik-wik
wikky>" type scratching performance.  Almost "rappy scratching", if you
know what I mean.  While this kind of scratching takes a lot of skill and
good rhythm, I think it got a little old for my tastes after hearing it a
lot from Carlos time and time again.  At Wed's Tribal Funk, again, Carlos
went <Ka-BOOM>, this time scratching bass kicks as an additional baseline
in such a manner that follows the song a little better, and also a bit less
of a crowd spectacle.

DJ Trance from Los Angeles was in town, originally to play at a friend's
small invitation-only party.  When the space fell through after the party
had already been planned, party planner got together with Tribal Funk and
<poof>, we have a party with DJ Trance, cool lighting, and a lot of other
great DJ's!

Zzzso!  DJ Trance also played a really killer set.  His style ranges from
what seems to be really electronic trace, to upbeat "happy" trace, to
breakbeat trance.  Everything I heard was especially well mixed, and he
thoughtfully mixed in a song containing a mellow "cool down" segments
without a bass or kick.

After the party, I ran into DJ Trance and had a chance to meet him and
communicate how much I enjoyed his set.  He was very modest, and really
appreciative of my compliments.  He did not seem to have any of the
attitude that would lead on that he thought or knew he was good.  Instead,
he just shook my hand and asked me if I'd like a copy of his tape.  He dug
through his pocket and found his last copy -- boy did I get lucky!  I must
tell you this tape is a REAL TREAT.  An added bonus- it was free!  (If
anyone is interested, there is a phone number in LA on the tape that you
can call if you are interested in finding a copy -- email me if you'd like
it.)

Hollywood Dog was zappin' his big lasers all over the main room, and it
seemed SO much more personal than the last time I remember seeing his good
work at the Tribal Funk anniversary massive at the Cow Palace.

The security guys were definately a little on the goonier side, but they
weren't so bad to me.  One look at my friend  Roland the Lion  and one of
the door guys broke out in laughter.  The next instant he kidnapped Roland
(sort of with my permission, but definately with my blessings) to show the
Lion's cute big brown eyes to one of Mr. Security's female squeezes, just
inside the door.  After Roland returned, still as happy as ever, the other
security dude waved me in, not even bothering to search me or the rest of
my large bag of florescent slinkies, squishy toys, beeping buddies, or
other psychedelic toy/insanities.  I guess they got the clue that I'm not
particularly interested in carrying weapons with me!

While they security guys were reportedly not allowing any ins-n-outs, for
those like Cap'n Crunch who NEED to get out of that stuffy, smoky
environment to get some fresh air, they were making special exceptions for
people who did a little talking.  At least this controls the numbers that
can be seen standing around the door outside, visible from the street.  I
think fans are a definate need at this location if it be planned again.

Does anyone know how the Infinity party last Friday went, and if it did (as
rumor has it) take place at the same location?  Did anyone go to this or
was everyone too tired?   :)

Just my $.02.

P.S.  The energy on the dancefloor was pretty excellent from MY
perceptatory standpoint.  But I have to admit I was probably dancing less
than half of the party's duration -- too many friends to catch up with!!

Take it easy


-------------------------------------------------------------------
                                       <<< Love and Positivity >>>
                                             extending through

   !@!    infinity@aimnet.com                         Infinity
-------------------------------------------------------------------

	I have no better advice than be good to the body; that takes you 
were you want to go everyday; and allows you to experience life in all 
its different forms. Drugs in general mixed together can have anywhere 
from eurphoric to deadly results ie acid and x or valium and alcohol 
respectively. The best and first ? is and should be for all of us is it 
worth the risk. I'm a firm believer than in referenec to the big picture 
we are only here for and instant; and than life should not be lived in 
fear of dying. For me experience is everything; its why we were put here; 
but only you can make that discision for yourself. Good luck; have a 
great time; but try and minize the total number of substances that you 
have in you body and any given time. Also; at first do things in small 
qualites and see how it feels; there always time to do more and more. 
This is what herion addicts call chipping; its a way to see how good the 
dope is without overdozing and possibly dying. Because from my personal 
experience if something bad happeneds to you; the doctors in the 
hospital; in their high and mitely way will not have any symathy for you. 
To them you are just and evil drug user who deserves what he or she gets; 
and i speak from experience. Its sad; but they just don't get it. Good 
luck. Just one more thing; I remember a friend of mine who in a matter of 
hours ate 10 waffers; smoked a whole bunch of kide bug; took a lot of 
special k thats catamean and dropped a bunch of lsd and wondered why he 
didn't feel very good???? You decide. To the best of my knowledge he did 
recover fully after a few days of not being able to walk correctly; see 
and do other things. But he sure was scared to death; like please let me 
off the train know. something to think about?

Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; CHARSET=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

V
Though certain aspects of raves are certainly liberatory and challenging 
to the status quo it is unrealistic to believe that it is some ideal 
peace and love scenario. The rave scene is inextricably embedded within 
the wider cultural milieu and thus is deeply affected by the negative 
aspects of partriarchy and gender politics.

I would guuess that there are more male dj's than female dj's but there 
are plenty of good woman dj's around. The Begin Again new years party had 
4 woman dj's play. Pollywog,Charlotte,Tracey & Bonnie. The organizers did 
feel it important to have a percentage of female dj's.

Many aspects of our postmodern landscape are in desperate need of a 
rebalancing of gender engergies. Hopefully the rave scene can help break 
down some barriers to communication and foster healing & transformation.

peace,
ronan

Thomas Hagemann <thage@mercury.sfsu.edu> points out:

>Excuse me for getting cranky and stuck in gender issues, but i still
>wanna know why house/dance/ambient etc. djs are almost all men!!??
>

>egalitarian/utopian aims (or hollow pretensions?).

>transgender djs out there...or that Your Sister's House is still active.
>
>Are the dancers and partyersapprox half women- if not, why aren't they on
>the decks?  The finest djs just happen to be men, is that it? (Or is the
>whole electro culture thing mostly appealing to men? If so then i'll shut
>up and things might make sense.)
>I haven't been out since March, so i'm out of it- please tell me if i'm
>way off!!
>
>Claiming to be healers (and many of you) Gaia-centric, or amorphous
>androgynous and ecstatic and the whole wonderful, loopy story, i still
>think you're controlled, or at least lead, by men.
>Am i wrong to point fingers- dj opportunities have been wide open for
>women, they just haven't come forward?..i'm getting redundant now, but i
>just wonder what the real reasons are, if they're determinable, and if
>anything is wrong or not.   ??????????
>I have waited, for years and years, for things to change and they haven't
>(and if this is old news on the list, forgive me, i've never subscribed
>regularly)
>"Is this what you wanted, is this how you wanted things to be, i wanna
>know, i wanna know, i wanna know..."(Meat Beat Manifesto)
>thankyou my sweet delirious kittens, tinydancer


Lee Fogel <lxfogel@srv.pacbell.com> anamours forth on Tue, 3 Jan 95:

> *  *  *
>
> Favorite DJs of 1994 - I only considered DJs that I heard spin at least
> 3 times during the year.  In no particular order, the DJs whose
> spinning consistantly managed to take me into the highest orbit were:
> Jeno, Markie, Tracy, Galen.
>
> Favorite New DJ of 1994 - An Easy pick - Tracy.  Looking forward to
> hearing a lot more of her.  Runner-up: Solar.
>
> *  *  *


Now Thomas, I know you are new the list as of late, but you'll be happy to
know we have a lot of wonderful, truly talented women DJ's in our little
scene here.  Your Sister's House is still around (Hi MAUI!!!!! and Susan
and All!), and can even be reached at "ysh@netcom.com" if I remember
correctly.

On the other hand, we do NOT have enough of these wonderful women -- we can
always use more!  You are right; the scene is flooded by a majority of men,
but we could theorize for weeks in threads on just the contributing factors
to why and how this is true.  The reasons are not easily itemized or easily
singled out as one being more significant than other.  Like I said, we
could dedicate a thread alone to the reasons.

I'm just happy that we have the excellent talent and energy that the Bay
Area's women DJ's have to offer, and if you'll notice in Lee Fogel's recent
post regarding his opinion of Tracy (see above), he'll agree that Tracy is
one such example of an excellent female DJ that can TRULY schred it up!

A really nice job at Pacific's Begin Again New Year's party, Tracy.

REEEEEEALLY good stuff!  And that hair!  Wowww-ee, all those little braids
are soo cool!  And I don't think I've ever given a more satisfying hug to a
DJ after a truly incredible set than I did give to Tracy after her set just
before midnight New Year's Eve!  Yowsers!  Recalling all that positive
energy makes me SOOOPER-giddy again!

Hope everyone had, OVERALL, a totally UNREAL (that's a positive thing) 1994!

Love,
Todd

I don't know who is crazier: the people who charge those outrageous 
prices, or the people who PAY those outrageous prices.  If people don't 
go to the events that are priced so highly, parties wouldn't cost so 
much.  The reason promoters charge so much money is that they know some 
people will pay theitheir price.  The most I will EVER pay for a rave is 
$20.  With that money, I certainly expect a laser show or something - 
like the Gathering last month.....worth every dollar!

> to avoid commercialized money hungry raves and only go to those 
> that truly care about everyone having a great time and not taking 
> away hard earned money.

I couldn't have said that better myself!
luv to all,
Amy

Chronicle JAN. 8 SUNDAY MORNING

A small craft designed for touring the San Francisco Bay region capable 
of carrying up to 250 passengers is still missing according to Coast 
Guard officials. The S.S. Pomme Fritz was chartered by a local group for 
a floating dance party concert. The luckless vessel launched during a 
lull in last nights storm at about 8pm pacific standard time. Gail force 
winds soon buffetted the craft at 50+ m.p.h.. An S.O.S. was received at 
10:34 pm last night but was muffelled by whale like chirpings and deep 
drones caused by unknown sources. It has been speculated that the Captain 
of the vessel had been under the influence of a popular drug used at 
dance party concerts called "ecstacy" and may have grounded the ship in 
S.F. bay's infamous "Potato Patch", a raised bit of the oceans bottom 
near the mouth of the bay. Supporting this speculation is the report from 
the coast of the north bay where a jacket made of holographic foil was 
found intact miraculously, a tribute to the unknown manufacturers durable 
yet fashionable dance party concert attire.

From: ptiger@crl.com (Purple Tiger)
Newsgroups: list.sfraves
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Sat Jan 14: The Q-ZAR Experience with PT
Date: Sun, 08 Jan 1995 13:18:22 -0500
Message-Id: <kn24lm4Em-SQ075yn@crl.com>
X-Newsreader: Yarn 0.75 with YES v.0.13.B0101
Lines: 49
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Looking for something fun and interesting to do before a night of raving on
Saturday, January 14th?  How about a few rounds of laser tag in a black lit
maze with techno music playing in the background?

Q-ZAR is a game of laser tag played wearing a florescent vest and wielding a
gun. A group of up to 20 people are divided into two teams and are lead into
a maze.  The objective is to tag the players of the opposing team with the
laser beam emited from the gun while avoiding being tagged by their guns.
When a player is tagged with a laser beam, sie is temporarily disarmed and
loses one defense unit. After loosing four units, the player needs to return
to an energizer near hir home base to get more.  Points are awarded for each
opposing player hit and substracted for each defense unit lost.  Points are
also awarded when the home base sensor is tagged (no easy task). The game
play is surprisingly easy, safe, and nonconfrontational.  Targeting is easy
because you get visual feedback from the laser and the gun talks to your
constantly to give you help. There are referees that enforce rules against
running, climbing, physical contact and bad attitude.  As for music, the
maze features an excellent sound system and they will play any CD with
non-explicit lyrics.  They've had no problem with playing my trance and
hardcore CDs and there are no rules against dancing.

Cost: 7$ a game, or $15 for 3 games and 3 sodas.  Typically 3 games will
      fill the entire night up.

When: Saturday, Janurary 14th, 6pm to 10pm

Where: Q-ZAR is located in Ronert Park, Sonoma County, CA, an hour drive
       from SF.  Specifically, take the 101 north to Ronert Park Expressway
       exit, make a left (east) to Commerce Blvd and turn right.  Go to the
       next signal which is Hunter Drive.  Go past Hunter Drive and the next
       driveway on the right is Q-ZAR.  The address is 6591 Commerce Blvd.
       Q-Zar's voice mail number is (707)588-8100.

       People are welcome to gather at my house just off the 101 in San
       Rafael, Marin County prior to my leaving for Q-Zar at 5pm.  Just
       drop me an email (ptiger@crl.com) and I'll give you directions.

I think its the perfect complement for Area 51 alien visitors.  I hope to
see you all there.

Love,

Purple Tiger

ps Water is free.

--
< Purple Tiger (ptiger@crl.com) >
              Be careful, its a vegan eat vegan world out there.

According to M8 magazine, it is 400 to 700 BPM... I think that may be a bit
of an exaggeration.  I don't know, I haven't heard any yet, but I think 180
to 200 may be close.  It comes from the Netherlands, especially Rotterdam.
Gabber translates roughly as "homey."  I hope to make it there this year to
check it out (yeah, I'm going just to check out the music scene ;-))

David

On Sun, 8 Jan 1995, Paul Gorman wrote:

> Just out of curiosity, is Gabber like, really,really...fast? 180? 190? What
> is the background or the home turf of this?
> P.Duff Gorman
> 
Gabber is Dutch hardcore speed techno. I would guess that it averages 
around 160-170+ -I've never actually clocked the stuff that I have, but I 
can assure you it is fast. Just think fast breakbeat without the break 
and syncopation. Just a *really* hard 4/4 bass drum with your choice of 
samples. Imagine "Dominator" played a twice the speed.
 It seems to be usually associated with football hooligans and 
carries a "hardcore" flavor: a lot of the titles sound somewhat violent, 
for example "Tear You Apart", The Falcon; "Fuck the Children", The 
Babysitter, and "Powerful Impact", Evil Maniax. Speed is evidently the 
drug of choice for the Dutch fans. The music pigeonholers have now found 
a new sub-directory of gabber (or gabba as some say) called "hakke" (from 
the Dutch "to chop", I believe) that is faster (200bpm) and harder (?).
 Generally I'd say it's not the most interesting stuff but it is good for 
keeping you awake and moving while writing term papers late at night ;).
Fun in small doses.

--MArc

looks like the same ol' shit to me....
see y'all underground....
-------------

I went to megatripolis last (actually no, that was the first 1) when
it was at the trocadero... I have something like a minimum of a 6 month
wait to return to a place at which I was harassed even slightly by anyone
even vaguely resembling security... suffice it to say it happened at the
trocadero and 6 months ain't up yet... regular club venues must work
especially hard to get my dollars because I'm quite experienced with the
usual fair at these joints... I go to raves to be my self and not worry
about bullshit, but I was unable to feel like that at the trocadero so
I'll just wait for the underground to come around again... I'm not that
into track shows anyway, and there's little to this music to be performed
live if it's all on DAT anyway which it usually is (appropriate respect to
those who actually *perform* parts/all of the music live, but in all fairness
this is a rarity).

-=J=-

>From alt.rave:

Subscribe to 
the X COMPILATIONS mailing list to get the latest DJ Mix tape catalog.

Do the following:  

send an e-mail message to          listproc@gate.net

with the BODY of the message containing
    
                           subscribe xcomp-l Real Name

Where Real Name is your real name, be it Bubba Jenkins, or whatnot.

You will receive confirmation automatically by return email.  
Periodically you will be sent information from X Compilations.

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Mon, 9 Jan 1995 16:43:14 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: standish@c2.org (Michael Standish)
Subject: re: gender damage

on Thu, 5 Jan 1995Thomas Hagemann <thage@mercury.sfsu.edu> wrote:
>Excuse me for getting cranky and stuck in gender issues, but i still
>wanna know why house/dance/ambient etc. djs are almost all men!!??

For all the same reasons that so few women are doing many other things,
like riding motorcycles or skateboarding or being doctors. If I were fond of
viewing women as helpless little girls, then I would say it's all because
of men victimizing women, and not letting women become DJs or motorcyclists
or
whatever. The question then is, why do women (as adult human beings fully
capable of making their own decisions) chose not to become DJs or
motorcyclists or whatever. Partly it's economic, it's expensive to get
started as a DJ. SL1200s ain't cheap nor are all those records that must be
bought every week to stay current, and as we are all aware women get paid
a lot less then men. So women are less likely to spend the money it takes to
become a DJ. Interestingly economics is not a factor in motorcycling because
bikes are far cheaper to use than cars. So I suppose money is not a very
big issue.The big issue is internalized oppression. Internalized oppression
is built up within the oppressed person over years of exposer to sexist
beliefs (from mother, father,TV, teachers, pretty much every one).
Internalized oppression is not an intellectual thing. Many women who are
intellectually strong feminists, find internalized oppression holding them
back just the same. Internalized oppression is a hideous disease that must
be smashed if there are to be any real gains in the fight against sexism.

>snip<
>.or that Your Sister's House is still active.

Your Sister's House, now there are some people I really respect. Instead of
sitting around pointing fingers at men and a male dominated scene. They
took ACTION and put on their own party. And a damn fine one at that. By
providing a place for women DJs to spin, Your Sister's House have sent a
strong message to women in the scene, that is OK for women to be DJs. In so
doing they have struck a blow to the oppression (both internal and
external) that binds us all. Right on YSH!

>snip<

>Am i wrong to point fingers

Yes. You would do better to take action. IE encourage women who show an
interest in DJing, buy tapes by female Djs, make a point of going to raves
where female DJs will be spinning, ask promoters to hire your favorite
female DJ etc.

>dj opportunities have been wide open for women,

Not wide open but by no means closed.

>they just haven't come forward?

For the most part yes.

>just wonder what the real reasons are, if they're determinable, and if
>anything is wrong or not.   ??????????

Yes things are indeed very wrong.

>I have waited, for years and years, for things to change and they haven't

So quit waiting and take action.


Michael Standish  DoD#732  standish@c2.org  (510)849-4511

It seems to me that you think the laser tag game is some how violent.
Its not even particularly aggressive.  It's hard to be aggressize
in the game when you are listening to happy trance music and your
chest harness gives off pleasant vibrations when your are tagged by
an opponent.  Its hardly symbolic of murder.
-------------

I beg to differ; even if the game isn't painful, the metaphor is quite
strongly placed.  The fact is you're hunting your cohorts with a gun.
There is literally noone who isn't inundated with our macro-culture
who doesn't associate guns with danger, violence and death.  While I
wouldn't say this game is terrible (have a look at some of the more
gruesome video games, comparatively, laser tag is benign), but you are
playing a game whose metaphor is war.  If you're worried about violent
lyrics, I would think you might be concerned with a game whose object
is to shoot other players, you are now "acting" out a basically violent
scenario.  I'm not really concerned with people like sfraves types playing
this type of game, but I'd be damned if I'd let my kid (if/when I ever
have one) play something like this.  The message definitely gets through
and it's no less influential than violent TV or music lyrics.

-=j=-

 on those visions.  A good lesson in this struggle can be had by watching

Subject: Re: Sat Jan 14: The Q-ZAR Experience with PT
Cc: Purple Tiger <ptiger@crl.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Mime-Version: 1.0
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

included stuff from earlier posts:

--------------------------------------------------------
> scenario.  I'm not really concerned with people like sfraves types playing
> this type of game, but I'd be damned if I'd let my kid (if/when I ever
> have one) play something like this.

 Although, I am VERY concerned about violence and its propagation in our
 culture something in this last sentence stuck me VERY HARD ( or else I
 wouldn't be responding )

 Consider this:

 I'd be damned if I'd let my kid  "go out to these all night raves where
 there's all types of drugs and loud music destroying their ears and who
 knows what other types of bad influences".
--------------------------------------------------------
I hear what you're saying, however I wouldn't begin to try to tell anyone
other than MY child (certainly not YOUR child) what they can and can't do.
Beyond that, I'm particularly disgusted with these ex-hippie parents who
can't remember their own summer of love when they all dropped and saw God
and refuse to allow their children to undergo the same evolution they
themselves (supposedly) learned so much from.  Talk about hypocrisy....

However, I don't have any problems laying ground rules for my own offspring
should they ever materialize.  In fact, it's my responsibility to do so,
IMHO.  And in a role in which I am tasked with deciding what influences are
appropriate, etc., for quite young people, I feel no remorse in prohibiting
violence, whether metaphoric or real.

 ( Justification for police harassment of these illegal parties if I've
   ever seen it )
------------------------------------------------
The police have definitely been acting on the wishes of misguided parents
and, again, I take your point.  However, I don't see prohibiting violence
and violent toys/games from my own children as interfering with the choices
and development of others, quite the opposite.  The problem you are referring
to comes, IMHO, from people attempting to exercise influence over people they
have no reason/right to exercise influence over.  I also understand and agree
with the concept that children are small people, but real people and that they
should be treated with as much respect as adults.  This still doesn't negate
a parental desire to control to some extent, the ideas a child comes in contact
with, particularly at a very young and impressionable age.  There are many
out there trying to influence other peoples children (television comes to
mind immediately) which is, again IMHO, extremely uncool.  Again,
it boils down to alot of common sense and realizing where the appropriate
limits lie.

So, will I let my kids play violent games, watch Barney, buy toy guns?  No,
I will spend my time turning my children on to things I think are cool,
healthy and productive.  I realize they may reject my values, which is
likely to be hard to deal with but is also something that is inevitable
in some sense.  I will also strongly discourage things that I feel are
harmful, destructive, immoral, etc.  Games/play that is centered around
violence definitely fits the description for me, so I have no problems
prohibiting toy guns, laser tag, and other related stuff.  At some point,
if my kids end up being really into that stuff, I'll have to acknowledge
their autonomy, but I will choose to surround them with things I feel to
be constructive in the beginning.  At which point you allow your children
to diverge from your own values is a fairly personal issue and I'm not even
going to bother to make that public, it's not public business.  It is an
important bit of timing though, nonetheless...

 -=j=-




From sfraves-owner  Tue Jan 10 10:46:36 1995

From sfraves-owner  Tue Jan 10 15:53:53 1995
Return-Path: owner-sfraves
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id PAA01703; Tue, 10 Jan 1995 15:53:53 -0800
Received: from agames.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with ESMTP id PAA01695; Tue, 10 Jan 1995 15:53:48 -0800
Received: from acid.agames.com (acid.agames.com [192.245.82.114]) by agames.com (8.6.9/8.6.6) with SMTP id PAA02201 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Tue, 10 Jan 1995 15:11:19 -0800
Message-Id: <199501102311.PAA02201@agames.com>
Received: by acid.agames.com (931110.SGI/3.14+gl) id AA09127; Tue, 10 Jan 95 15:11:18 -0800
Subject: aggression, joy, and Q*Zar
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Tue, 10 Jan 1995 15:11:16 -0800 (PST)
From: JUMP IN THE FIRE <grigsby@agames.com>
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL21]
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 2077      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


I agree that movies, TV, newspapers, and other mass media saturate us
with violence.

I also note that this saturation coincides with growing anti-violent
crime hysteria: medieval punishment for even the most trivial offense.

As less is permitted, more is desired.

===

Violence is an instinctive response to frustration.  Remember that we are
a few thousand years of human trying to control millions of years of beast.

Calling instinct "evil" doesn't solve our problem.  The beast doesn't care.

===

Denying the beast's existence doesn't solve our problem.  As less is
permitted, more is desired.

===

It may be, then, that we must make peace with our desires.  If they
cannot be contained, they can at least serve our needs.

===

Like fire, anger is a dangerous servant and a fearful master.  Like
fire, anger can be used carefully as a barrier against complete
devastation.

Like fire, the longer anger is denied the more fiercely it burns.

===

It may be, then, that that which we call "inhuman" is precisely that
which makes us human.  And it may be, then, that there is a place for
violence in pursuit of joy.  And it may be that the battle is being
fought here, today, as the lawyers, politicians, businessmen,
gangsters, Party members, judges, juries, executioners, policemen,
informers, enforcers, functionaries, button-pushers, and solid
citizens struggle to make our status even more solidly quo.  And it
may be that a quick red moment of tooth and claw is far better than a
slow grinding death amidst the cogs of our modern death-culture
machine, turning the crank that coins wealth for gray people in gray
suits.

===

And it may be that our high fine moments of agape are also a
manifestation of the beast, and that both our joy and our violence are
condemned for the same reason -- because they force others to remember
what they have tried so hard to forget, working for trinkets with which
to decorate the bars of their soul-cage.

===


"If you don't love blood you don't love anything"  -R. A. Lafferty


// g


PS: Hey, Will Penna!  You still here?

Received: from get.hooked.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with ESMTP id VAA10788; Tue, 10 Jan 1995 21:24:55 -0800
Received: (watchdog@localhost) by get.hooked.net (8.6.9/8.6.5) id VAA08415 for sfraves@hyperreal.com; Tue, 10 Jan 1995 21:24:56 -0800
Date: Tue, 10 Jan 1995 21:24:56 -0800
From: Police Brutality Watchdog Project <watchdog@hooked.net>
Message-Id: <199501110524.VAA08415@get.hooked.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Raid Response
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Here's an update on the response to the Visual Aid benefit raid:

Attendees and supporters of the benefit are meeting at 938 Harrison this Wednesday, Jan 11, at 4:30 pm to march to the Police Commissioners Meeting at 850 Bryant, there to demand some answers.

A civil lawsuit against the SFPD is being prepared by the law firm of Steele, Clarence, and Buckley -- the same firm that successfully handled the October Sweep of 1989, when police illegally declared martial law in the Castro during an Act Up demo.

The Office of Citizen Complaints (OCC) is conducting an investigation.

The SFPD is conducting their own investigation.  If approached by SFPD on this, you have the right to remain silent.

The Board of Supervisors has been very helpful in pointing out how indiscriminate illegal police activites cost the City money in the form of lawsuits such as these, and how more citizen oversight of the SFPD is needed.

For more information call 415-267-6142.

--WatchDog

brian mcGonigle:

 > I went to a WICKED in the summer with a rotten cold... sore throat..
 > feeling shitty...danced all nite til 8AM.. then..all gone!!!!! 
 > awesome...
 > 
 > tried it again for the next cold... this time I felt great during 
 > the 
 > party.. but afterwards the symptoms came back.. BUT it wasnt any 
 > worse.
 > 
 > May not be the 'e'.. may just be the sweat and exercise :)

Agreed.

I went out to see Orbital on Thanksgiving even though I had been houseridden
with the flu for the past 9 days, figgering that I might as well have a good
time instead of nursing my sickness.  The only things that went in my system 
that evening was water, .5 a tab, and the Jolly Ranchers that I didn't give
away, and yet I felt great.

After I had gone home, I sat around in my room a bit, and then the symptoms
came back.  I figgered I might as well see the doctor about it.  At 9 that
Sunday morning, having had no sleep in 23 hours, I went down to CIGNA, got my
medication, and had my sickness cleared in no time  :)

peas,
paul

Ok, twist my arm, here's more info on my favorite bunch of drum bangers,
Crash Worship, just 'cause I love 'em so much.
Here is a post from rec.music.industrial:
>Some upcoming live dates by Crash Worship:
>
>        Fri, Jan 13th
>                B.A.R.S., 17th St @ Carolina in S.F.
>                w/Man is the Bastard opening
>                $10, all ages, 10pm
>
>        Sun, Jan 15th
>                Berkeley Square, University Ave in Berkeley
>                $10, all ages, 9:30pm
>
>They're also playing on Sun, Jan 22 in San Diego, but I don't
>have details on that show.
>
>For those unfamiliar, Crash Worship's live performances are
>unlike any other bands. Three drummers lead the group's sound
>into a purely ritualistic, celebratory chaos in which the
>audience is completely lost in.
>
>These shows are record-release shows for Crash Worship's new CD,
>"Triplemania II," from Charnel Music. For more info about the
>CD (including an audio sample), point a web browser to:
>  http://www.msen.com/~ecook/charnel.catalog.html
>
>
><====================================================================>
>   Mason Jones             Charnel Music - charnel_music@cyberden.com
>   mason@netcom.com        P.O. Box 170277, San Francisco, CA
>                           94117-0277    Phone/fax (415) 664-1829
>  Web catalog: http://www.msen.com/~ecook/charnel.catalog.html
><============
End of post.

I think tix are available at BASS.

David

Subject: next month's "ambient" cruise -- Robert Rich // Jungle 
Date: Wed, 11 Jan 95 00:24:30 -0800
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


On this months jungle cruise, I ran into an ambient music friend from
college who has become quite popular, prolific, and artistic in the
"space" music arena. He's been doing this kind of stuff since at least
'84, well before "ambient" was named. His material is available on
"Hearts of Space". Note that the uninitiated might just confuse some of
this kind of product as "new age music"; such a name would probably
underestimate the musical/artistic value of his music.

--------------------

PS: w/r/t the recent (Mixmaster Morris) cruise, i was wondering if
anybody has an idea of "whose" jungle he was playing. Was it his own
production? I certainly recognized a  number of "his" songs, but I
noticed he played other artists too (e.g. Portishead and that "I see i
know" Exist Dance label song)... I liked MM's kind of "jungle" much
more than the other "jungle" I've heard at wicked parties.

Note that "jungle" goes in quotes till I figure out what the heck
people are talking about.

On Wed, 11 Jan 1995 Mdma@eworld.com wrote:

> i was stoked on going to area 51 this weekend and then i saw the fold out
> flyers and now i've become a bit apprehensive, knowing that its THAT big.  i
> just wanted some reassurance that this won't be a big hunter/gatherer
> convention that i'll be attending.  if not reassurance,  at least can someone
> tell me what to expect so that when i see what i've gotten myself into, i
> don't beat my head against the wall for going to a $20 party?  ---->brian

Hmmmmmmm, couldn't you just guess that I would be the one to reply to 
your question??  Ok,  Yeah $20 is hella bucks to shell out for a rave 
(esp. since you also have to buy canned food!) but I kinda guess that 
there is a time and place for everything.  I normally dislike really 
large parties and prefer smaller ones but its always good to see  a 
really huge massive every once in a while.  Plus, it's thrown by cdc 
whose parties I've enjoyed in the past.  Add to that one of the freshest 
lineups I've seen in a while (cdc djs and wicked djs) and dj josh winx 
from philly and you know it can't be that bad.  Plus really big parties 
have the tendency to attract people who you don't get to see too often.  
Of course, some of these people you don't want to see( all the gangstas 
and shit) but it's kinda a rare chance to meet new people.  Lotsa people 
sit at home and only go out when there's a huge event.  Of course, I 
heard that it might be at richmond ...YUK!!!! but oh well. It still is 
worth going!
laters,  

HAPPINESS IS BEING AMONG FRIENDS

-sly                          
vekatz@ucdavis.edu

From sfraves-owner  Wed Jan 11 13:42:30 1995
Return-Path: owner-sfraves
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id NAA04767; Wed, 11 Jan 1995 13:42:30 -0800
Received: from ultima.org by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with SMTP id NAA04762; Wed, 11 Jan 1995 13:42:26 -0800
Received: from netcom.com by ultima.org; Wed, 11 Jan 95 13:44 PST
X-Sender: tic-tac@ultima.org
Message-Id: <v01510101ab3988992be9@DialupEudora>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Length: 1806
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Wed, 11 Jan 95 13:44 PST
From: ambient@netcom.com (Joe Rice)
Subject: Ambient Jungle Boat (he's the mixmaster)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Despite the rain and my lack of enthusiasm for a $25 5 hour event (wow,
paying more than minimum wage to be enertained!) I ended up going on the
Ambient Jungle cruise on Sat. - which turned out to be a worthwhile
adventure. The boat pitched and rolled the whole night, and it's a wonder
the turnables didn't skip more than they did. There were two levels, with
C3, Jonah, and Thomas on the bottom and Morris playing the whole evening up
top. I spent most of the evening on the floor up top. (Although the
wave-enforced swaying was kinda fun, too) Morris played a fairly eclectic
set, throwing ambient, ambient dub, trance, and jungle into the stream with
impressive continuity. I was impressed with his segues between styles and
songs, often done without beatmatching, the usual method.

The jungle he played was the first I've been able to appreciate. A little
slow for jungle (150 maybe) and well constructed, with original drum
programming and sweeping electronic sounds. Like if Speedy J or Black Dog
took a turn at it. Very different from the recycled sped up ragga/breakbeat
tracks I've heard elsewhere.

I made it downstairs for some of Jonah's live set, which was stunning, and
for some of the C3 set, which was perfect for checking out the bay as we
cruised round and round. Much more chill than Morris.

All in all, a nice ride.

Joe

(ps - I hear Morris is to play at Detour tomorrow)

(:Joe Rice:_____________:tic-tac@ultima.org:_______________:ambient@netcom.com:)
(:"Oh, the turntables are his instruments!"                                   :)
(:"But I can't tell what sound that record is making!"                        :)
(:"I know! He puts them on and off and you never know! I've never seen        :)
(: anything like it!"                                                         :)

From: csc@pilot.njin.net (Sean Casey)
Message-Id: <9501112351.AA00563@pilot.njin.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: medicinal ecstacy
In-Reply-To: <9501100109.AA21687@pacific>
References: <9501100109.AA21687@pacific>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Two effects of MDMA come to mind that might help fight a cold:

A very positive mental state. A positive mental outlook does affect
several chemical balances in the body, and actually does help you heal
faster. [I don't have a reference handy... heard the details by a
physician on NPR]

Hyperthermia. Just for fun, bring a thermometer to a rave (the thin
type you press against the forehead is great) and see how hot you get
when you dance. It's not much different than having a fever, and the
effect on virii should be much the same.

Sean

Why point a lasertag gun at someone and shoot them?

Because it's fun, and it's consentual. Because it's exercise. Because
it's speed-chess, trying to stay "alive" and achieve a goal while
others strive for an opposing one. Because you like to feel your heart
pound, your blood roar. Because when the day's over, everyone goes
home with a smile. Because someone's better than you, and you want to
see if you can become as skilled. Because you have to work at it.

Or even because you like playing with the dark side. The energy is
there; release it harmlessly. Play DOOM. Chop wood. Spar at the dojo.
Grit your teeth when doing something absolute. Play fast deep dark
techno until your brain screams. Tease it. Understand it. Acknowledge
it. Release it harmlessly.

There is no crime between two consenting adults. Whether the gun is
simulated or real. Whether there is pain or not. No matter what one
thinks is "represented". The error is in judgement. No victim and
there is no crime, no right, and no wrong. The real victims are those
you judge and try to "correct".

Sean

From: davidmin@crl.com (David Minuk)
Subject: What is....Jungle?
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Seems to be a bit of confusion, I will attempt to clarify...  Jungle music
is generally reggae and dub influenced breakbeat, that is, drum breaks are
sped up and throbbing dub-style bass is played over it.  Vocals are similar
to ragga(UK/Jamaican rap) and may candidly reflect the troubles of urban life.

I hate musical hairsplitting, but here goes...
Now the music you may have heard on the 5-hour cruise (I don't know I wasn't
there) was (drum roll please) "Ambient Jungle," which features less vocals,
lush ambient-style melodies, and spacious dub production and effects.  Much
less agressive then "regular" jungle, and thus frowned upon by many
steadfast Junglists.  You may also be able to hear "ambient" or
"intelligent" jungle at the Gardening Club.  This style is most likely to
catch on in SF.

As for MC's, they had one at the Jungle event I attended in Toronto, and I
found him to be lame and annoying.  Also, it caused most people to be turned
toward the stage instead of facing each other, and created a
perfomer/audience effect.  That's not what I go to raves for.

Jungle is advertised for an event Jan 20...415-337-4236.

David (with an id)

In-Reply-To: Jason Webber <jdwebber@ucdavis.edu>
        "Re: Jungle Event" (Jan 11,  1:17pm)
References: <Pine.SOL.3.91.950111131136.22547F-100000@dale>
X-Mailer: Z-Mail (3.0.0 15dec93)
To: Jason Webber <jdwebber@ucdavis.edu>, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: Jungle Event
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Mime-Version: 1.0
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Jungle is sort of a combination offshoot of the hardcore/breakbeat and
dancehall/ragga scenes in the UK.  A typical jungle track runs around
150 bpm and has a half-speed bass line and distinctive flurries of drum
beats, not a constant rhythm as with breaks.  There are a lot of vocal
samples, some just chatted over the track and some from other records.
The bass often has a drawn out swooshing sound, as opposed to a more
hardcore/techno-like pulse or thud.  

Jungle tracks are really distinctive and they're easy to spot once you've
heard them.  Many of the freshest tracks are on one-off or very limited
edition "dub plates" (a tradition that goes back to the Jamaican sound
systems of the late 1950s).  Popular ones sometimes get picked up and
reissued by regular labels, and labels also put out the more popular
styles directly.  Moving Shadow is one of the best and biggest jungle-
oriented labels but there are many others.

Jungle has a lot of sub-variants already, even though it really only
began as a noticeable style about two years ago.  It is massively
popular in London but less so elsewhere in England.  There are quite
a few pockets of junglism around the US, I gather it has a following
in places like Houston, Pittsburgh and the upper Midwest.  

The jungle scene in the UK seems to be splitting into factions to some
degree, with one branch more or less the equivalent of G rap here and
associated with a lot of aggro lyrics.  But jungle ranges across the
emotional map; I have a very nice jazzy release by DJ Pulse called 
"So Fine," for example.  

I don't see it as traditional dance music, it's basically too fast for
that, but you can kind of shake to it pretty well and the more interesting
sound effects give it more flavor, for me anyway, than most varieties
of hardcore techno and breaks.  

The jungle scene definitely perceives itself as being new and completely
different from rave, house, hardcore/ardkore, what have you.  I don't
think it has much prospect for commercial success in the US, and that's
probably fine.  But it's definitely worth checking out the music!

Rrrrrrrrrrrrollll the bass!!

phred

On Thu, 12 Jan 1995, Josh Bates wrote:

> I honestly think that is one of the big advantages we have. MC's and live
> acts generaly don't go to well down here, they kind of go against that
> faceless moral, plus IMHO it takes away from the group feeling having one
> guy obviously "above" everybody else & I'd rather just be able to listen
> to the music dry (I don't even like those cool tribal drummers, unless
> it's not to loud) Jus my opinion on the subject :)

   Well it is difficult to pass judgement on the subject as I quite honestly 
have never even heard of any mcees on the scene. But, the part of being 
at a rave that I most enjoy is sharing the experience with others. The 
empathy for everyone (almost everyone :o), and the group feelin that 
soars as the music changes an the MC brings the crowd to an incredible 
high is what I miss. I have only been going to raves in the SF area since 
I moved here from the UK three years ago and it has changed dramatically 
since then, but there is still something missing, for me.

   However, at the smaller more underground raves (most usually the best), I 
can see your point that an MC would definately distract from the general 
vibe and become the center of attraction - not desirable on e. But some 
of the bigger raves, like the gathering (big yet not too commercial to 
attract gansta/HS/hip-hop folks), An MC or two would go down great, IMHO ;)

!@$ Micky Finn $@!

 at a rave that I most enjoy is sharing the experience with others. The 
 empathy for everyone (almost everyone :o), and the group feelin that 
 soars as the music changes an the MC brings the crowd to an incredible 
 high is what I miss. I have only been going to raves in the SF area since 
 I moved here from the UK three years ago and it has changed dramatically 
 since then, but there is still something missing, for me.
 
    However, at the smaller more underground raves (most usually the best), I 
 can see your point that an MC would definately distract from the general 
 vibe and become the center of attraction - not desirable on e. But some 
 of the bigger raves, like the gathering (big yet not too commercial to 
 attract gansta/HS/hip-hop folks), An MC or two would go down great, IMHO ;)
 
 !@$ Micky Finn $@!
>

Greetings!

Just a brief reminder that Komotion (2779 16th St. at Folsom in SF) will
be open again this Saturday from 10AM till 4PM to clean and spruce up.
Thanks to those of you who came last weekend and got so much done.  There
are a few more areas that need some repainting (Krylon spray paint is *so*
hard to paint over!), and other general cleanup chores.

Komotion is an all volunteer arts collective that has hosted the last two
friends and family's (which so many of us enjoyed), and have acted as hosts
to the Bay Area underground for nearly 10 years.  They're awfully nice folks
who need our help to ensure their success in working with lots of upcoming
inspections to get the space dramatically improved for everyone's benefit.

Come on down if you have some time, and lend a hand to this worthy cause!
Thanks!
-- 
====== Bryce Ryan ========== AMBIANCE ========= brycer@ultima.org =========

On Thu, 12 Jan 1995, Matthew Corwine wrote:

> On Wed, 11 Jan 1995, Josh Bates wrote:
> 
> > Sounds like the new buzz word of the month. Breakbeats at 45 with lots of
> > bass sure don't interest me. I know I probably haven't heard the real
> > stuff, but I kinda doubt there are many people that play it.
>              ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
> 1. Raise Foot
> 2. Open Mouth
> 3. Place Foot Firmly In Mouth

Look 2 1/2 years ago some people were calling 2 Bad Mice & Suburban Bass stuff
jungle, most people would have thought it to be techno although it was
miles away from the original detroit sound and just as far away from what
you are now calling jungle. So anytime someone comes at me with the new
buzzword-genre I aint buyin it, they are for the masses to let someone
else decide what their supposed to like now. From what I've heard at *SF*
record stores & parties it doesn't sound like anything special, I know
there's probably some stuff that would sound good in the chill room
but I have yet to hear any dj's play anything but cheesy crap.
			jb

I don't have anything for Friday, so you have to choose from the weeklies;
Saturday and Sunday both Area 51 and Spundae have all-star lineups, check
'em out if you can.  This is just a preview of the big shots coming next
week.

See the note after the calendar to svbscribe or unsvbscribe.  To get on the
main sfraves discussion list, use 'sfraves' instead of 'sfraves-calendar'.

    ----------------------
==== THE SFRAVES CALENDAR ==================================================
    ----------------------

Saturday, January 14th - Komotion klean-up
        Join in on collective effort to fix up the home of F&F.
        Supplies will be provided.  See details at the bottom.
        10am-4pm.  2779 16th St @ Folsom, SF.

Saturday, January 14th - Area 51 
        Carlos  Dutch  Christophe  Josh Wink (Phila.)  Taylor (LA)
        Tiga (Montreal)  Simon  Jeno  Garth  Markie  Thomas
        visuals by Synergy and Optica Lux
        $20 w/canned food for Project Open Hand
        415.615.8559   510.273.9329  408.491.9220  707.523.8783

Sunday, January 15th - MLK Spundae
        Tony Humphries  C.J.Macintosh
        Jay-J  DJ Dan  Simon  Carlos  Garth  Jeno  Markie  Henrik  Mark Farina
        Utopia  Josh  Miguel  John Howard  Suiki
        1015 Folsom @ 6th.  9pm-8am, 21+
        415.974.9389

Thursday, January 19th - Wicked, Deconstruction Records, Urb Magazine &
        Natural Music present live
           THE DUST BROTHERS (uk)  The Crystal Method (la)
        with DJ's Jeno   Markie   Thomas   Garth  Jon Williams
           Doc Martin  Justin Robertson  Paul Bleasdale  Justin King
        At the Trocadero [4th & Bryant Street]  21+ with valid ID   9pm-6am 
        (415) 512 5713

Friday, January 20th - Organic presents Hardkiss - the Hardkiss family
        Delusions of Grandeur Tour Preview
        Live and Direct: Rabbit in the Moon and Hawke
        Plus DJs Robbie and Scott Hardkiss with 
        notorious sidekicks Keoki, Derrick Carter, Mark Farina, Galen,
                Wade Randolph Hampton
        415.266.8215

Friday, January 20th - Billboard Dance Summit
        Jeno  Garth  Scott Hardkiss  Reese  Taj  Markie  Robbie Hardkiss  
        Thomas  Skylab  Gavin Hardkiss  Jonah Sharpe  Charles Uzell Edwards
        Darkhorse  Professor Smith  Jon Williams  John Howard  Raymond Roker
        Wade Randolph Hampton
        1015 Folsom, SF.  415.979.8444

Friday, January 20th - United Nation II
        guest DJ Boy George.  House diva Crystal Waters.
        Adeva with Frankie Knuckles
        + sound Factory DJs Marques Wyatt, Pete Avila, Aaron O
        benefits Prevention Point and Food Not Bombs
        9:30pm-7am, Sound Factory, 525 Harrison.  415.543.1300

Saturday, January 21 -- Nag Champa -- Deep Ambient
        DJs: Joe, Ronan, Nick Philip  Performers: Velocette, Bryan, and guests
        $3-10 Sliding Scale Donation Requested -- Contact tic-tac@ultima.org

Thursday, January 26th - Generations of Love
        the San Francisco House Movement comes together to benefit Project
        Open Hand at 1015 Folsom, Planet San Francisco
        admission - 3 cans of organic food
        415.435.8675

Saturday, January 28th - X, Why Zzz
        w/Skylab 2000.  details to follow.

sometime in january - Groove Trip  415.522.9958

Mondays midnight-2am - "The Mix Show" KWOD 106.5(Sac) - lineup 916.551.0494

        are usually techno-tribal-trance and ambient
Thursday evening 9:30pm-12mid - Minor Minor KALX 90.7 (Berkeley)
Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF 90.3 (SF)

        Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)

Subject: Sat. 10-4 Komotion CleanUp
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Thu, 12 Jan 1995 15:59:00 -0800 (PST)
From: "Bryce Ryan" <brycer@ultima.org>

Greetings!

Just a brief reminder that Komotion (2779 16th St. at Folsom in SF) will
be open again this Saturday from 10AM till 4PM to clean and spruce up.
Thanks to those of you who came last weekend and got so much done.  There
are a few more areas that need some repainting (Krylon spray paint is *so*
hard to paint over!), and other general cleanup chores.

Komotion is an all volunteer arts collective that has hosted the last two
friends and family's (which so many of us enjoyed), and have acted as hosts
to the Bay Area underground for nearly 10 years.  They're awfully nice folks
who need our help to ensure their success in working with lots of upcoming
inspections to get the space dramatically improved for everyone's benefit.

Come on down if you have some time, and lend a hand to this worthy cause!
Thanks!
-- 
====== Bryce Ryan ========== AMBIANCE ========= brycer@ultima.org =========

Subject: MC'S: NOT
Date: Thu, 12 Jan 95 17:39:32 EST
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Dear Sfraves;

       I hate people in general that think they are better than other
people; or by virute of what they do for a living. MC's are not the
music; but tend to think that people come to see them rather than the
music. I for one could stand not to hear someone standing up there
talking about how bad they are; and over the music that I paid good
money to here. If I want to hear someone say how bad they are; I'll
listentoNewt.Itendtolump politians, MC's and Newt all in the same
catogorety; noise polution. By the way everyone knows that I'm the
badest anyway; just kidding :). We are all in this together; and no one
is better or worst than you or I. Love knows no gender; race; religion;
I wouldn't have such a problem if they were up there promoting the scene
or world harmony ..etc. But they promote themselves at the expense of
others; my soul has a problem with this. As John Lenon said we are all
stars; we all shine just as bright as everyone else. So I will proablly
say away from an MC driven event. The scene is about music not
indivuals.

                                       Peace & Love
                                       brianv@liberty.com
                                       aka Brian Darkness
                                       Net Person

Dear Whomever;

       To the person who's address has gone into the electronic winds of
time; asking me to appoloize to ptiger. As a human being I make lots of
mistakes; if ptiger was sincerely looking for someone to go with him to
qzar then I sincerely appoloize. It sounded like advertising to me; and
if its qzar or bay lunch; i still don't think it belongs on an open
forum for sfraves. Also, don't get me wrong I would not want anyone to
feel that I was repressing their right to free speech; for I was not.
The problem with free speech is that everyone has the right and if your
going to say something you need either to be prepared to back it up with
an effective argument or appoloize for it. But with ptiger clarified
intention in mind; I would be interested in going to qzar before the
event. I have fond paint ball memories; even though the
army clotyhes were a little much.

                                       Peace & Love
                                       brianv@liberty.com
                                       aka Brian darkness
                                       Net Person

Hi, my finals end on the 19th, and the best thing that I could think of 
to get the hell away from school after them is a rave, but I have the 
severe handicapp (worse than quadraplegia) of being under 21.  Does 
anyone know of any raves for those of us losers who were born to late on 
the 19th? I'm going away after the 19th, so I'll still have all my stress 
bottled up in me if I don't get to one on that day.  Please e-mail if you 
find one, there are none I could find on the calandar. Thanks!

paintballing) and it's not half of the adrenilane rush.... of course 
playing Q-Zar on some mind enhanser might be an interesting x-perience 
that I have never tried....

I don't know what qualifies exactly as an MC, but here's my expereince.  
Down for the summer in L.A., they had a party called One Roof.  They had 
Frankie Bones come and play some hardcore.  And between some of his 
music, he'd stop the music and just talk for a little bit, while he cued 
up for the next.. or after skylab 2000 was done, he said a few more things.

He was being a real cheeseball when he said "I've been all over the 
country, and I've been to a lot of parties, but you guys rock"  (Or 
something cheesy to that effect.)  Cute.. but stupid.

Sun			sunkim@sfsu.edu

Hi Brian,

I know you mean well but I mentioned it all of twice.  I'm not making
a dime from Q-Zar and I really only want to setup a group activity for
the purpose of adding to the community.  Q-Zar has black lights,
day-glo, techno music, and lasers making it extremely relevant to ravers.
I think its a real kick in the pants and I think a lot of others would
enjoy it too.  The last thing I expected was to get flamed.

Ciao,

Purple Tiger

Subject: Jungle
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Fri, 13 Jan 1995 01:18:14 -0800 (PST)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]

Content-Length: 1575      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

IN FEBRUARY 94 art forum called jungle the end-all of dance music and I 
then posted to the list a question...What is Jungle?

Brian B and Laura brought in some tapes I think they were glad to be rid 
of with the name jungle on them: they had MC's and it seemed like 
Universe style hardcore.

A couple Irish DJ's, paul and dara, played jungle for me for the first time.

Someone gave me a name of a distributer who did internet jungle 
orders(some one from this list:] ) and I sold mostly the spacey ambient 
stuff.

In the S.F. Area there is 
Deaks,Dave,Alex(little),Noah,Gamall,Phish,Jonah,Charlie,Markie,Thomas,Dan
and I am sure many more who play jungle (no girls?) so far Jonah is my 
FAvorite.

Jungle keeps getting better at a fast pace and I have no tapes which 
reflect the current state of junglisms in sf

Today I heard a jungle tape by DJ RAP (a girl)which was ripping and 
tearing(these are jungle terms!)

I hear they are smoking crack to jungle at the Ministry of Sound in London
this is a reflection of the brutal ragga style of jungle which is not the 
kind we are digging here. We like sophisticated drum programing, 
hauntingly beautiful melodies and not much else.

salutations, allen@ameba
"""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""
That post-millenial boogie-woogie will rot your brain

I've seen it tried in SF, I've seen it fail...

Just not with the SF vibe, I guess. Don't think I'd like it, though
I'd be willing to attend and be open minded about it.

I *love* it when DJs really get into what they're doing and share
their fun with the crowd. That's what made Deaks' mind-exploding set
at the last F&F so much fun for me; not only was it a killer set (one
of the best I've ever heard), he was obviously having *fun* and shared
that with the crowd. Wheee!

Sean

I went to tuscon and tried to go dancing
Seems like there is about one big club space used
midweek - Hotel Congress

I caught Disco Night which I heard the next day
is also Gang Night (let's just call this a southwest
perspective) - I was a little uneasy with all the
preppy jock types (Hey watch me lift my girlfriend
in the air, I am sooo Strong ...) until I found the 
"gangsters" to hang with (anyone else ever have 
this mixed crowd = safety feeling?)  

Also heard dj h-bomb play acid jazz.  His music
selection was very good although there were a few
train-wreck mixes. Nice group of people.

Find stores club dada and tuff inc for party
finding assistance - they were very helpful!!
Looks like they have nice parties almost
every weekend and the town had more 
going on midweek than I expected.

Seeya
Dave

OK -->  Friends and Fellow Milton Buddies!  Here's the scooop on what has
been up with Milton lately:

Unfortunately, due to circumstances beyond control, Milton has lost his
account with school at UC Bezerkely.  This means he is officially in a
temporary state of net-weaning, which we hope will turn right back around
again just as soon as he gets another account operational somewhere.  As
soon as he gets a new account working, you'll see him here on the net.  He
got his computer back from his brother, but he still lacks the internet
account he had before.


Some of you were wondering if Milton in a dress would be appropriate
door-discount material for Area 51...  Well I have some exciting news --
over the last week or so, Milton has been working on a full blown alien
costume that he plans to show off this Saturday at Area 51.

Without his access to the Internet (and all of you, his friends), Milton
has been kind of bummed out lately.  Keep an eye out for him at "Area 51",
and be sure to say hello, grin a REALLY big smile his way, and in general
spread some good, positive vibe for him this Saturday night!


Lotsa hugs, and see you all
down in  Area 51  Saturday!

>in it, does this mean that therefore I will be able to see into myself?

I don't know. I tried using my craftsman reversible powerdrill, you
know, like right around where one's third eye would be. And you know,
it was going surprisingly well, a pretty clean gouge. ... And
allahthesundden, it kinda stuck. So like I was in a fetal position,
trying to pull the drill out by standing on my elbows... which really
kinda smarts if you think about it... but then I remembered that it was
a reversible drill!

Oh Joy!

-- Niels.
