>From psychospy@ping.com Thu Jan 12 14:06:12 1995
Message-Id: <199501122202.RAA12428@ping.ping.com>
Date: Thu, 12 Jan 1995 14:09:03 -0800
To: rkrouse@netcom.com, JWILSON1@KENTVM.KENT.EDU, handog@ucssun1.sdsu.edu,
        Python3007@aol.com
From: psychospy@ping.ping.com
Subject: Area 51 Frequently Asked Questions

AREA 51 FREQUENTLY ASKED QUESTIONS
Answered by Psychospy, 10/23/94

WHAT IS AREA 51?

"Area 51" is a block of government land about 95 miles north of 
Las Vegas.  It is surrounded by the Nevada Test Site and the 
Nellis Air Force Range.  The name "Area 51" supposedly came from a 
designation appearing on an old map of the Nevada Test Site.  
Inside Area 51 is a large Air Force base, near the shore of Groom 
Dry Lake, that the government does not publicly acknowledge.  The 
airspace around the base is off-limits even to most military 
pilots and is referred to on aviation frequencies as "Dreamland."

WHAT IS THE FUNCTION OF THE GROOM LAKE BASE?

The base at Groom Lake has traditionally been America's testing 
ground for the latest generation of secret aircraft.  The U-2, A-
12, SR-71 and F-117A were flight tested here long before being 
made public.  Since the government won't acknowledge anything 
about the base, it's hard to be know what is going on there now.  
Common rumors suggest two possible new aircraft, an ultra-high 
speed spy plane known as "Aurora" and a smaller version of the B-2 
which purportedly might replace the F-117A.  Most projects at 
Groom are probably more mundane, though, and of interest only to 
hard-core military buffs.

WHAT'S WITH THE UFOS?

This area has long been rich in UFO lore.  Whatever you can 
imagine--captured aliens, underground bases, alien-government 
collusion--it's all been claimed at Groom Lake.  One of the more 
restrained and interesting stories is the claim by a Las Vegan, 
Bob Lazar, that he worked with extraterrestrial flying saucers at 
an installation at Papoose Lake, south of Groom Lake, in an area 
he calls "S-4."  He says he helped "reverse engineer" one of the 
craft, but that he saw no aliens himself.  There seems to be no 
way to confirm or directly refute this claim.

Since Lazar first made his claims in a locally televised 
interview, many tourists have been coming to the public lands 
closest to the base to try to catch glimpses of alien craft in 
flight.  Many believe that they have seen UFOs here, but there are 
so many UFO-like natural and military phenomena on display here 
that its hard to separate the wheat from the chaff.  Many people 
have lived in this area all their lives and never seen a UFO.  It 
is important to note that there is a difference between the claim 
that the government has alien spacecraft in its possession and the 
claim that you can come here to see flying saucers in flight.  In 
general, the second claim is less credible.

WHERE DO WATCHERS GO?

About 130 miles from Las Vegas, at Mile Marker LN 29.5 on remote 
Nevada Highway 375, is a lone mailbox used by a local rancher.  
Since this "Black Mailbox" is the only landmark on this stretch of 
the highway, this is where the true believers come.  Many visitors 
claim to have seen flying saucer here, although the rancher 
himself claims to have seen none.

Much closer to Area 51, there are two hills on public land--White 
Sides and Freedom Ridge--that a visitor can legally climb to view 
the secret Air Force base.  Freedom Ridge is more popular because 
it is closer to the base (13 miles) and a less strenuous hike.  
The viewpoint can be reached by a four-wheel drive or by a 50 
minute hike from a good dirt road.

The Air Force has applied to seize the two viewpoints, but the 
process is going slowly.  The land remains open as of Oct. 94, and 
will probably remain so through at least Jan. 95.  If the land is 
eventually seized, other viewpoints will remain, but farther back 
and harder to get to.

WHAT ARE THE "CAMMO DUDES"?

That's the nickname for the anonymous private security force that 
patrols the military border.  They wear camouflage fatigues 
without insignia and drive white Jeep Cherokees with government 
plates.  They keep close watch on any visitors that come within a 
few miles of the border, but they are under orders to avoid 
contact.

WHAT ARE THE DANGERS OF VISITING THIS AREA?

The greatest danger is wandering across the unfenced military 
border, which would result in your immediate arrest and a fine of 
up to $600.  Wherever a road crosses the border, it is marked by 
clear "Restricted Area" signs which should not be crossed.  In the 
desert, the border is marked by orange posts every 50 yards.  It 
is unwise to hike near the border at night because the posts 
become invisible.

Another major danger, when driving, is getting stuck on an remote, 
unmaintained dirt road that your vehicle cannot handle.

RESOURCES

"The Area 51 Viewer's Guide," a 110-page, self-published book by 
Glenn Campbell, offers general information, a reference list, maps 
and practical advice for visitors.  It is advisable to obtain this 
guide before you come so that you can be adequately prepared.  The 
cost is $15 plus $3.50 Priority Mail postage (US), ordered from:  
Secrecy Oversight Council, HCR Box 38, Rachel, NV 89001.  A 
catalog of other publications is available upon request.

Breaking news is reported in a newsletter, "The Groom Lake Desert 
Rat," which is available free by email or for $15 per 10 issues by 
regular mail.  Send your request to the address above or: 
psychospy@aol.com.

###




----- End Included Message -----

Subject: Mitsuma (a poem)
Date: Sun, 15 Jan 1995 07:35:56 -0500
Organization: Purple Tiger Sophistems
Message-Id: <iQH6lm4EmAqV075yn@crl.com>
X-Newsreader: Yarn 0.75 with YES v.0.13.B0101
Lines: 47
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Mitsuma
-------

Hello Mitsuma.

You may wonder how I came to be.

I once believed that no soul ever left this earth, and instead returned
again and again in an endless enjoyment and celebration of life.

Even as I believed this I had no idea of how old my soul really was.

One day I discovered I was the oldest soul there ever was, the first soul to
walk this earth.  

I discovered this as I lay in my bed and my soul reached the limits of
its memory, and lost track of where it was supposed to be.  

It slid upwards through time for some countless number of millennia until
it came to rest in a grassy field on the shores of the San Francisco bay.

There were thousands of people waiting for me there and I knew that they
loved me as much as they loved themselves and as much as they loved each
other.  

As I gloried in their love, my friend Mitsuma came forward and said,

"As the second oldest soul on this earth it is my pleasure to give you the
 gift you gave me so long ago."

Mitsuma kissed me then and when he did he passed to me a virus, a thought,
a belief that evolved me.  It was not like a torturous struggle for survival,
it was like the feeling of relief you feel when reach your bed after a long
day.  I lost every shell I still had after all these lives, and I knew and
felt all things and emotions.  

I returned to the present then and now I am here before you Mitsuma.

And now I ask you, before I kiss you, do you want to evolve?

- Purple Tiger, 1995


--
< Purple Tiger (ptiger@crl.com) >
                              "Wow!" - Milton

i guess it's like perfume...just stinks to some people
give me fresh air please

greg

From sfraves-owner  Sun Jan 15 16:20:46 1995
Return-Path: owner-sfraves
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id QAA23859; Sun, 15 Jan 1995 16:20:46 -0800

Date: Sun, 15 Jan 1995 16:20:43 -0800 (PST)
From: Sami Khoury <red@hyperreal.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Area 51 review
Message-ID: <Pine.BSI.3.91.950115160735.23479A-100000@taz.hyperreal.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I got there around 10.  Good visuals in the main area.  Wandered around 
and entered the smaller, foyer-type room in front of the arena where 
someone was actually spinning jungle.  Being from Houston, I've certainly 
heard my share, and this dj knew his stuff.  Very melodic, danceable, 
fluid jungle.  I'm a bit biased about dancehall, ragga style stuff--which 
is to say I hate it.  But no screaming rastafarian here, just controlled 
female vocals (*sigh*) and swooshy sounds.  Later, this foyer was filled 
with some of the juiciest house I've heard in a long time :)

The place really started to get full around midnight, Josh Wink came on 
around 2 and spun a really cool set.

Cool things: you could bring in water and food and stuff.  They didn't 
check ID.  Very little attitude was sported.  Cops were hospitable.

Not so cool things: the sound system seemed mudded up--as though they 
picked the wrong bass frequencies to boost, and it wasn't as crisp as it 
could have been.  Cost $20 to attend.  I guess this should be expected, 
since the location and the building were *great*, and there was plenty of 
security.  In the east, it seems that if you don't pay the cops enough 
"security tax" they shut you down even if you're legal.  Oh well...

Really cool things: met/saw more sfravers at one time than I ever have: 
John Shiple, Brian Behlendorf, Laura La Gassa, Cindy Kawakami, Mike 
Wertheim, Susan Kameny, and Philip...argh, forgot the last name.

	Sami

From: davidmin@crl.com (David Minuk)
Subject: The gate (profound prose)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I was walking my dog along the Point Richmond shoreline this afternoon.  On
my left side was the bay; on my right side was a fence.  On the other side
of the fence, there were rows of grey houses surrounded by green lawns.  I
came upon two girls who were standing on the other side of the fence, ages
about five and eight.  They were screaming at me:  "Let us in, let us in!"
I was suddenly perplexed by this strange request.  "But you are in," I
said,"I am outside."  They said, "No, we want in!"  I examined the gate
separating us.  It locked from both sides.  "Look," I said, pointing behind
me towards the bay, where clouds were hovering over the Golden Gate and
seagulls were soaring seemingly without care, "there's the bay.  The whole
world is out here, on this side of the fence."  They stood their ground.
"Well if you're outside," asked the older child, "how did you get outside?"
I had no answer for her.  Now I am full of doubt.

David

From: deaks@netcom.com (Ernie Deakyne)
Message-Id: <199501160434.UAA22682@netcom20.netcom.com>
Subject: Some DJ commentary :)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Sun, 15 Jan 1995 20:34:58 -0800 (PST)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 2926      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

   Over the past year I've read a lot of messages about fast music vs 
slow music and house vs techno and MC's vs No MC's etc. etc.  and I've 
found it very surprising that very little is said about the energy levels 
at parties and the energy interaction between the DJ and the crowd.  Sure 
you can say "There was LOTS of energy there last night.."  But where 
exactly did the energy come from and what did it do.

   I'll start off with an example from Area 51.  Through the first 5 
hours, the music kept a steady "THUMPIN" pace which had the majority of 
the people in the big room dancing hard!  But by 3am I was beginning to 
tire and decided to chill in the bleachers and watch the crowd. Before 
Josh Winx went on the music was around 140bpm and was starting to wear 
people out.  I could see the crowd slowly wandering away from the 
dancefloor to find some place to relax.  Winx then got on and immediatley 
slowed things down.  The crowd slowly began to build up the group energy 
almost from scratch.  Winx was a prime example of a dj feeling the energy 
of the crowd, connecting himself to it, and then bringing the energy 
HIGHER through the music.  He brought the music down to the energy level 
of the crowd and then took everyone for an amazing ride.
  
   As I sat in my chair the music slowly began to pull 
me in and pump me with energy.  But it wasn't JUST the music.  It was the 
fact that the DJ was able to bring everyone to a common energy level and 
then bring them higher.  It was the crowds energy that was pulling me in 
to dance and it was the DJ who brought everyone to that level.

   It's this manipulation of energy that is more important then any 
tricks you can do as a DJ.  What I love about the SF scene is that so 
many people are open to share and accept the energy of their friends, 
fellow ravers and the DJ.  Some people feel the DJ should be in the 
background, just playing music for the people.  However, I think the DJ 
should be at a spot where he/she can connect with each and every person 
on the dancefloor.  Not necessarily on top of a high podium, but perhaps 
just 1 or two feet above the dance floor so they can see beyond just the 
front row of dancers.

   Well, that's all I've got to say about energy right now.  Just 
remember before making comments about music being too fast or too slow 
that it really doesnt make a difference when it's "in the mix..." :)

   Oh and I had an incredible time at Area 51.  Great music in both 
rooms, tons of smiles, WAY cool security (Christophe had my friend open 
his backpac at the entrance and my friend had over 100 blowpops inside.  
Christophe looked in and said"Oh! You're in dude! Get in there!") and I 
had the feeling that everyone there was a friend :) ... Btw, I was the 
guy wearing that big white puffy afro looking hat all night.

   Peace out and rave on and on and on and on and ... oo 

-Ernie "DJ Deaks"

From: crunch@netcom.com (John Draper)

Subject: New Years Rave report

The Aliens have landed in Richmond
             By
         Cap,n Crunch
         


I have but one thing to say,   "The Aliens have landed!!!" in 
"Area 51" a super Mega rave.    If you were transported into 
the middle of the main arena of Area 51,   and looked around,    
you would have thought you had been abducted by the little 
"Greys".    The insane visuals led one to believe they were in
this huge flying Saucer,  and looking up and all around you,  
were the slanted eyes of the alieans staring down at the main 
arena.     The smoke,   when combined with the lazers,  and 
the two huge Eyeballs with spinning spirals looking down 
at you,   would have certainly "Transported" you off this 
planet.

CDC's Sound system,  with it's huge 20 foot wide speaker banks 
certainly pinned your ears back.     In front,   the Wicked 
crew were craning up the most twisted jungle I ever thought 
possible.

Aliens of all types and sizes were waddling,   dancing,  and/or
floating across the huge Richmond Auditorium all night long.
The costumes were amazing....    "Ooops!   Didn't mean to
step on that.... Whatever you call that thing!!!"  The elevated 
shoes were literally out of this world,   as people wore 
tramboline shoes,  tentacles,   and other unknown apendages 
in the stranges places.

For theme and effects,   I have to hand it to the promoters,
that they did the most incredable rave of the year, that will
rival no equal in a long time to come.....

For me,    I literally left my body to be torn to schreds by the
awsome audio energy of DCD's speaker banks,   while my mind left
the solar system at warp 9 for the most intense interstellar
journey I thought possible.    Step aside,  Cap'n Kirk,  THIS
Captain is COMIN THROUGH!!,  being blown through the universe,
powered by the most insane hard acid,  I thought possible!!
Yow!!  I don't know what that Hard Acid trance DJ was in the 
SPAZ room,    but whoever he was,   he should be promoted to
Admiral.   Yowsa!!     

Earlier,  in the main room,  we were also treated to some excellent
hi-nrg hard trance,  which led to an extremly wide variety of
music from 123 - 160 BPMs and everything in between.

One hilight I thought mentioning....   As I was dancing,  just
GETTING INTO IT!!   I had this big shit eatin grin on my face
and this cop walks by,    and smiles and says....
says "How old are you?"  I say,  "old enough to be your father
and lovin every minute of it!"    He smiles back and shakes
his head and continues walking around.    Even the security
had smiles on their faces.

The Dj's wore the "Area 51" overalls and lab smocks,  and Carlos
who spun last,    played the "Close Encounters" sound track where
the huge saucer was "Communicating" through the musical notes..

FUCKIN BRILLIANT!!   Thats All I gotta say....  Carlos,   you'
*really* did it this time!!  Congrats on a wonderful ending....

"Would the person who parked his saucer please move it!!.... It's
blockin my shuttle craft!!

As I was rocketing through the Galaxy,   I've heard unconfirmed
reports that UFO experts were speaking in a spacey voice over the
Ambient music in a clever bit of brainwashing.

Many people approached me and said "You were in High Times!"
ANd I said "Oh!   Really?    What did they say?" Some reported
it talked about my attending the World Unity Festival in Arizona.

As I recall,   I remember quite well,  this writer,  trying to keep 
up with my constant moving around between the rave and the 
rainbow gathering,  and I had time to talk about a wide variaty
of things,   probably about raving.

If anyone happens to obtain a copy,   I certainly will want to
have a look at it.    (hint hint!)

Anyway,   I'm going to have this big fat grin on my face from
this "Alian encounter" for a very lojng time to come.    Somehow,
my mind managed to find what was left of my body,   thanx to some 
old acquaintences from AutoDesk.    Both are merged quite happily,
especially after about 3 hours of yoga and some blockage removals.
That hike to the waterfalls just put the icing on the cake.

Later...  Thanx for the wonderful party -  Carlos,  and to the tons
of SFRavers out there....

C. Crunch

Subject: Re: Area 51 review
Date: Sun, 15 Jan 1995 21:23:05 -0500
Organization: Purple Tiger Sophistems
Message-Id: <9YT6lm4Em6Y4075yn@crl.com>

Precedence: bulk

The visuals were astounding with two laser banks, intellibeams ringing the
arena, a projector screen suspended from the roof over the center of the
arena where some very beautiful montages were constructed using a bank of
twelve slide projectors.  Nice murals in the chill room.

Josh Wink was awsome and I always dig Carlos.  Wicked was in the back
vibrating bolts out of the supports.  There was a nice little electric
sign that scrolled out the DJ's name so I could tell who was spinning
without having to squirm my way up front.

There were lots of cops and security, but they seemed to only wander the
halls giving people the privacy they need.  No ID check, simple backpack
search, and a question about if I was packing markers or paint.  Sent me
a wierd message at first, "We don't care who gets killed, but don't fuck
with the building."

There were concessions, but they weren't over priced.  A $1 for a small
water bottle and a $1 for a shot of expresso (good expresso too).  It
sent me the message that CDC et. al. wasn't milking the vendors for a
lot of money (if any).

I was real happy with the sound quality throughout the building.  Even
better, it was possible to hold a conversation in the hallways without
shouting,

Managed to connect with lots of regulars and a few new folks.

The best massive I've ever been to and I wasn't even on drugs.

Ciao,

PT

--
< Purple Tiger (ptiger@crl.com) >
       Kale and Eggplant pizza, that's something you don't see everyday.

From: Marc Pfister <mjpfister@ucdavis.edu>

Yikes. Now that was a RAVE. Heres a quick top ten, in no particular order:

1. Carlos. This man coold have lit up all of Richmind with his energy. 
2. Incredible lack of gangsta vibes, and lots of security presence 
without gestapo techniques.
3. Wicked's bass bins, which were going so far into the sub-bass in the 
latter of the jungle sets that I swear my pants were floating off of my 
body, riding on a standing wave. Or maybe the resonant frequency of denim 
is close t0 20 hz.
4. That crazy acid/breakbeat monster that was probably heard four times 
that evening- Josh closed his set with it and Christophe gave up after 
four attempts to find a record to start his set on that would mix, so he 
went with the beatless MLK speech. (or so it appeared). P.S. It's a 
Strictly Rhythm test pressing, for all you fellow trainspotters.
5. Christophe's MLK "I have a dream..." recording, and the crowd response.
6. The eerie laughing song....
7. Wicked's jungle sets. 
8. Visuals. Lasers. Alien Heads. Lasers. Intellibeams. Lasers. Lasers. 
Lasers.
9. A great multifaceted crowd, especially those klub kids with the 
platforms (xtra props to the one with the flashing shoelaces). Also the 
breakdancers- especially the ones working the circle in the second jungle 
set.
10. Leaving at 7am to *clear skies* and a beautiful sunrise, after a week 
of dismal weather, especially up here.

Marc

I saw a picture for a 5-watt radio transmitter distributed by Free Radio
Berkeley in the new issue of Colors and I became very interested.

Being a SoCal-Raver myself, I figgered some helpful soul resonating to the same
frequency up North might be able to help me out.  Can anyone tell me how to get
in touch with F.R.B.?

assistance truly appreciated,
paul



   milk
   weed
                                                     paul.geronca@support.com

Subject: Re: Area 51 review

I must say that as far as massives go, this was pretty good on production,
though a little low on Vibe (but I think that will improve with time)
Carlos is "old school" and I'm sure that as long as he is at the helm, 
everything will be alright and people will be taken care of.

As far as the main room is concerned, it is the best use of the space
that I have seen since the first Unity Massive benefit for Mal.
(but I didn't go to Phuture so I don't know)

This is how an all ages event should be, low on attitude, lots of smiles and
a reasonable amount of good music for your money.  I wished that there had
been more people dancing and less galking but maybe that will pick up
next time (and I hope there will be a next time).  The newbies that did come
to this event came ready to rave and they definitely seem to want to learn
what its all about, it's up to the "vets" amongsts us to share the vibe and
get them on the right track :)  This would be a nice theme to
continue, maybe at an outdoor location in the summer or at Burning Man
in the Nevada desert at labor day.

Oh Yes! and Josh Wink played Acieeeeed!!!!


				G

From sfraves-owner  Mon Jan 16 14:48:07 1995

Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id OAA09795; Mon, 16 Jan 1995 14:48:07 -0800

Received: from DialupEudora by netcom19.netcom.com (8.6.9/Netcom)
	id OAA07538; Mon, 16 Jan 1995 14:47:13 -0800
Date: Mon, 16 Jan 1995 14:47:13 -0800
X-Sender: ambient@localhost (Unverified)
Message-Id: <v01510104ab40285b6faf@DialupEudora>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: ambient@netcom.com (Joe Rice)
Subject: Area 51 (the soon-to-be-jaded-raver view) =)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I sometimes wonder how many spoiled brats guest lists have created. As I
was entering the Richmond High School, uh Civic Auditorium I overheard "The
$10 list [I don't get in for free?], oh that's great - where's Dutch -
we'll see how well he plays with broken fingers." On the other hand,
security were non-intrusive and the ticket people were friendly.

I'd never been to the Civic before. It's ok, but I kept thinking I was at a
hockey game with all those seats. You could lose about a thousand people in
there.

Wandering into the main hall I immediately wished I had some ear plugs.
Loud, loud, loud, although it did make most objects vibrate, a neat effect.
Dutch was playing some fairly hard trance when I arrived around 12, hoping
to catch Taylor's set. Evidently he was bumped to 11. Drat. Ran into Brian
Behlendorf, Cindy, Laura and Mike Wertheim rather quickly, which was
surprising considering he number of people who I looked for all night and
never found.

Simon was spinning in the Wicked area, where the sound was bearable, good
even, with tighter bass than the "whoommm" of the big room. Pretty good
music here. Markie comes on and drops the jungle. Decent jungle stuff, but
he didn't really mix it which is weird, as he mixes house just fine.
Impressive bass, though. I'd kinda like to see a real jungle party in the
UK. Major kudos to Markie here for causing the gigantic, floor consuming
breakdance circle to disintegrate before he went back into standard Wicked
house fare.

The SPAZ area was set up like an ambient room, with blankets everywhere and
people laying down, but every time I went in there they were playing trance
or techno.

The visuals were great. Excellent Intellabeam programming, and decent
lasers. Plus computer projections, and no less than 18 slide projectors.
Almost overstimulated. There was even a laser in the Wicked area as well.
Cool alien heads were strung up over the seats, and there was a Schwa booth
for your abduction pleasure. Over the top was the guy with the LED suit on.
Go for it!

Josh Wink played mid-tempo acid and trance for the most part, but picked
things up towards the end of his set with some really nice acid tunes.
Cristophe continued on the same track, adding some classics to the mix and
moving things a little bit housier. Carlos closed things with his
scratching, cutting style.

Question: There was a song that both Wink and Carlos played with a 303
going crazy over a funky 808 beat. It also a vocodered voice saying
something, and a non vocodered sample saying "Get on up" or "Feel the
groove," or something else along those lines. Please, does anybody know
what this is?

It was a big rave.

Joe


(:Joe Rice:_____________:tic-tac@ultima.org:_______________:ambient@netcom.com:)
(:"Oh, the turntables are his instruments!"                                   :)
(:"But I can't tell what sound that record is making!"                        :)
(:"I know! He puts them on and off and you never know! I've never seen        :)
(: anything like it!"                                                         :)

>   I'll start off with an example from Area 51.  Through the first 5
>hours, the music kept a steady "THUMPIN" pace which had the majority of
>the people in the big room dancing hard!  But by 3am I was beginning to
>tire and decided to chill in the bleachers and watch the crowd. Before
>Josh Winx went on the music was around 140bpm and was starting to wear
>people out.  I could see the crowd slowly wandering away from the
>dancefloor to find some place to relax.  Winx then got on and immediatley
>slowed things down.  The crowd slowly began to build up the group energy
>almost from scratch.  Winx was a prime example of a dj feeling the energy
>of the crowd, connecting himself to it, and then bringing the energy
>HIGHER through the music.  He brought the music down to the energy level
>of the crowd and then took everyone for an amazing ride.

Excellent point. I was tired of the big room myself and when I went back in
after Wink started playing I ended up staying for the rest of the night.

>Btw, I was the guy wearing that big white puffy afro looking hat all night.
>

Ah ha, suspicion confirmed. That's the coolest hat around.

Joe

That song that both Josh Wink and Carlos played is called Watch Me
Now by Grooveyard.  I think just about every DJ out there has bought
it now, big buzz on it.  Has a Run DMC sample on it that gets the
crowd jammin.  It's a available at Primal Records in Berkeley if
anyone wants it...  Had a blast on Saturday, hope everyone else did
too...

Dj Dave Alga

I'm so glad you all got to experience Josh Wink (not winx)...he's easily 
one of the best dj's in the world and it's a shame it took this long for 
SF to discover him. On the east coast you can see him on a nearly weekly 
basis...the real shame is that SF is so closed-minded. Yes, there's tons 
of good talent here but i think being such a closed scene hurts SF. Go 
see Justin Robertson and Paul Bleasdale at the Dust Brothers show on 
Thursday and see what i mean...there are incredible dj's from all over 
the world, and they go everywhere but here. Scott Henry from Baltimore, 
Sasha from London, Terry Mullan from Chicago. Kimball Collins from 
Orlando...if i had the money i'd throw a party with dj's from everywhere, 
just to show this city a taste of the incredible talent that is out there....

mikebee

<<mikebee@freenet.scri.fsu.edu
<<mike@organic.com

Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id SAA22397; Mon, 16 Jan 1995 18:41:58 -0800

Received: from crl3.crl.com by mail.crl.com with SMTP id AA18971
  (5.65c/IDA-1.5 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>); Mon, 16 Jan 1995 18:41:05 -0800
Date: Mon, 16 Jan 1995 18:41:05 -0800
Message-Id: <199501170241.AA18971@mail.crl.com>
X-Sender: davidmin@mail.crl.com
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Version 1.4.3
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: davidmin@crl.com (David Minuk)
Subject: Greetings Earthlings
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Weekend report coming up, but first, help needed...

My friend Rich, promoter of Kundalini, is throwing another one Feb 3.  He
has a venue lined up (not the Troc) but the venue owner will only allow 18+
and an ending time of 6 a.m.  Rich wants an all ages place that can go until
dawn.  If anyone knows of such a place, please let me know.  All suggestions
will be passed on to him.  In any case, I hope to see you all at what will
be another great party!

I started out Friday night at the Crash Worship show.  I don't like the
promoter(Terminator, a heavy metal club) or the venue (B.A.R.S.-129
Carolina).  Started out great with the room stuffed full of dancers and
luckily very little moshing.  Still a little too much testosterone for me,
I'd love to see Crash Worship at a rave instead of a metal or industrial
show.  I was already sweaty when a CW "helper" who was carrying a big jug
dumped the liquid over the crowd's heads.  I drank it up, thinking it was
water-it was vegtable oil!  Yuk!  Anyways, it made a great lubricant for the
nearly bare dancers in the crowded room.  B.A.R.S. tried to shut the show
down repeatedly - gee, didn't they know that CW uses fire and fireworks?
The band refused to stop, and the crowd was just getting more fired up.  I
wasn't prepared for a us vs. them situation, but much of the crowd loved it.
After power was cut off, the band continued their percussive attack among
the crowd.  When security tried to clear the floor, CW brought out their ace
in the hole - the guitarist was carrying a megaphone on his head and and
amplifier on his back, and was somehow firing thousands of sparks 20 feet
towards the security people, creating more mayhem.  (Nobody got burned too
bad this time though).  The band then continued playing out in the street,
despite the rain and the arrival of several squad cars.  Overall, I would
rather have had more of a sensual vibe, but it was pretty fun.  

Capn Crunch clued me in to a party being put on by Mr. Floppy, so I checked
it out next.  It was in a loft downtown.  There were lots of blacklights and
day-glo decorations (the stars looked familiar-same ones from the
Flophouse?), and the music was purely trance.  About half the small crowd
was dancing ( and dancing very well), the rest were on the floor in deep
meditation.  I danced.

Sat... Q-Zar!  What fun!  Great exercise too.  The only SFRavers were Purple
Tiger and me, unfortunately, but there were lots of other people there to
play with.  Then, on to Area 51.  Out of this world!  Josh Wink launched me
into orbit when he first slowed the beat down to a crawl, then sped it up to
hundreds of BPMs!  Or was it my imagination... ;^)  It was after the song
with the loud crunching guitar sounds... I think...  My sense of time was
distorted that night, the greys must have got to me...  Later, I looked at
my watch, it said 4:30 but it was in fact 5:30-where did that hour go?  I
checked myself for incisions, but couldn't find any...  Those grey devils
must have very advanced surgical examination techniques...  Luckily, I
brought along my bouncy moon shoes to help me readjust to earth's gravity.
I do wish to return to Area 51 someday.  Calling occupants of
interplanetary, quite extraordinary craft!

Enough silliness...

David

Watch for my Web page coming very soon!

From: Jonathan Tea <solrvibe@bga.com>
Message-Id: <199501170445.WAA12802@jake.bga.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: (fwd) for the love of raving
Newsgroups: alt.rave
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Got this off of alt.rave.  Many of you probably saw it but for those who
didn't I thought I might share it.  This isn't in response to anything, or
directed at anyone.  I just thought it was cool and something to keep in
mind, cause this is what we started doing it for in the first place.  I'm
not really a Moby fan and never really have been, but I don't question the
fact that he's a real person and his heart is in the right place:

---------------------------------------------------------------------------

as uncool as it might be, raving is a special thing, a phenomenally 
special thing.  hundreds of people celebrating communaly, uplifted, 
transcendent...
that's why the sad unhealthy state of rave culture is so completely 
fucking depressing.  to watch something so wonderful become something 
gross is a tragedy.
and we're all to blame, really.  and we can all work to make things 
healthy if we want to.
i say-bring back happiness, joy, transcendent celbration, naive wonder, 
respect, and positivity.
dj's-stop playing boring records that no one cares about.  stop trying to 
'educate' people and concentrate more on making people happy.
happiness is a lot more valid than jaded bitterness.
oh well, there's my two cents.
moby

On Mon, 16 Jan 1995, David Minuk wrote:

> I started out Friday night at the Crash Worship show.  I don't like the
> promoter(Terminator, a heavy metal club) or the venue (B.A.R.S.-129
> Carolina).  Started out great with the room stuffed full of dancers and
> luckily very little moshing.  Still a little too much testosterone for me,
> I'd love to see Crash Worship at a rave instead of a metal or industrial
> show.

I was at the Sunday night show at Berkeley square. This was the first
"show" I've ever been to so I didn't know what to expect other than
massive weirdness, which I got. It was split between watchers & do'ers
like most parties, but there seemed to be a higher % of do'ers who were
realy "doin' it" I released myself much more than I could at any possible
rave. It was both very different & similar to a rave. Similar in that you
were going after your primal desires to release/dance to trance-inducing
music, the *big* difference being that their alot more hardcore about it.
The floors & people were covered with all sorts of slippery goo so that
you would slip down if there weren't so many people around you, so
everbody was bumping into eachother, which at first I didn't like the idea
of, but I think it brought the crowd together. Lot's of *fire*, it was
very exciting to be dancing & have some guy blow a huge fireball past you.
I definatley recomend the experience to anybody who likes to go of *realy*
hard. Got to see familiar faces Mark A, Tracy & Donavon and made the
mistake of going to some party afterwards thinking that we still had
energy, since afterall it was only 2am.
			josh B

> Hyperthermia. Just for fun, bring a thermometer to a rave (the thin type
> you press against the forehead is great) and see how hot you get.

>or.. Safety First  Fever pacifiers; there's a little heat sensitive pad
>in the tip, and you're less likely to end up with a mouth full of mercury :-)


Good idea, Simon!

But I think Sean had a safe idea too with the recommendation of one of
those thin-type thermometers.  They are about the size of thumb and the
thickness of a few pieces of paper.  Its the same type of material that is
now built into those  battery voltage testers that are built into the
batteries' package.

and Berkeley. They didn't give an address for Free Radio Berkelely, but mentioned

Quoth David Minuk:

> I started out Friday night at the Crash Worship show.  I don't like the
> promoter(Terminator, a heavy metal club) or the venue (B.A.R.S.-129
> Carolina).

I'm _never_ going back to that place.  No running water so you had to pay
$1 for those tiny bottles, and you had to 'relieve' yourself in porta-potties
with the tops chopped off.  Plus the PA kept cutting in and out all night,
and bouncers called the police -- like anything was going to happen that
hadn't already.  As if that weren't enough, they sprayed Halon into a room
full of people, nearly suffocating many (which is how Halon works, by binding
oxygen so the fire can't burn).

> Still a little too much testosterone for me,
> I'd love to see Crash Worship at a rave instead of a metal or industrial
> show.

Maybe that place up near Willits that PW used?  Outdoors, plenty of space
for a bonfire, a place to crash afterwards in the sun, mud baths, beautiful.
They'd be a great centerpiece for another weekend of raving up there...

// g

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk



David Minuk writes:
> I started out Friday night at the Crash Worship show.  I don't like the
> promoter(Terminator, a heavy metal club) or the venue (B.A.R.S.-129
> Carolina).  

> I'd love to see Crash Worship at a rave instead of a metal or industrial
> show.

	I have to disagree.  I saw both the BARS and Berkeley Square
shows.  Berkeley Square has a reputation for kick-ass Crash Worship
shows, and it was, but the BARS space was clearly superior.
It was just so much bigger, there was more room on the dance
floor to find your particular grove.  The extra space afforded
by the chill-out-style rooms were also a major bonus; IMHO they
added about as much a rave-style feel as you'll be able to get.
Since the point seemed to be to click into the tribal thing with
everyone around you (which certainly was happening at *both*), too
much more space might not be a good idea.  People need to be close
and personal, but not crushed together precariously over the fires.
The BARS space seemed to be exactly right for the size of the crowd.

Those were my first two Crash Worship shows -- Needless to say, I'm a 
convert. 


T.

--
     __|| __||                   Todd Hodes
    (____(____)            hodes@cs.berkeley.edu
                     http://http.cs.berkeley.edu/~hodes

Mijos! I have missed you guys SO MUCH! I was shut off for so long because
of some bullsh*t financial shuffling here at UC. But now, it's all over.
Tho I did piddle on the UC net administrator's car door. 

Twice, just to be safe.

Whoa! Area 51 teaches me yet another lesson: my fear of tolerance makes me
space out my X, but then it hits me like madonna's virgin again stuff, and
my ass is floored. Don't get me wrong, you get to learn a lot about your
ass when this happens. I swear, I could sit on a flyer AND READ IT thru my
overalls and a thick blanket, I just couldn't get the colors right.

Anyone who saw Ernie (the guy with the black shirt and BIG eyes) x-ing for
the first time there knows why this is such a wonderful chemical. His
tearless-cry realization of joy that "you're ALL so beautiful!!!" was
truely the chill-room highlight of the party. This dude is coming for more,
I'll bet...

At the 7-11, right after the party, I got to hear the NY style cashier
explain to those convenience store pixies (you know, those guys that hang
at the 'levin in the mornings? Where DO they come from? Where do they go?)
what a rave was:
                    (read with that east-coast whine)
"Yeah, these kids came from that party. Good kids, the lot of 'em. The cops
know about it, no problem at all. Crazy, they are. Dancin all night long,
they go in at 10, they stay till the morning. Music, dancing, no fights, no
alcahol, (shrugs his shoulders, increases pitch) no drugs...." and then I
buy an all rubber pacifier and a slushy......

Me and Infinity and some non-sfravers got this idea up on the overlook in
the Berkeley hills: a few weeks ago, we all met spontaneously on twin peaks
after Kundalini, and I always drag people along to chill for an hour or so.
As my Slacks Acieed and Pimp Coat contrasted with serene beauty of the Bay,
we thought "aHa! Let's do a CD-ROM of 'Milton's after rave spots'" but
seriously, most of us should have taken the time to stick around later. 

Shure, lots of us went to the after party or chilled with friends, but we
should try to set up a spot right up close to the place, so sleepy/spun
drivers and there precious payload of life can sort it out for an hour or
so, and all that unity that we exclaimed all night sticks around for real.
Solidify your new-found friendships. So, my curfew line will carry
after-party info from now on, if possible. And it will accept all
contibutions. E-yeah, could be.....


Just had to get that all out of me system.

Lotsa love,
 Milton and you know who!

ps. Thank you Cloud Factory for B-sitting my E-Bee.....she thanks you all....

ps. anyone who has seen me peaking knows that my vocabulary then limits
itself to wow/yeah. You can get far in life with just those two words. ex:
       THEM                       ME
"jeno rocks, huh?"               Yeah!
"look at those lights"           WoW!
"this is so awesome"             yeah!
"hey, Milton meet my friend"     wow!

Try it, you may never need to speak beyond this. Life can be sooo simple if
you decide to make it so.....

sorry to take so long to get into this but here i am...


On Thu, 12 Jan 1995, Jack wrote:

> Hey, I saw mikebee mc at a rave(Wink spun that night, too, no less) and
> it was pretty damn cool.  I prefer just listening to the music,
> generally, but if done well, an MC can really get you going :)
> ----------------------
> 
> I agree!  (I also understand that people don't want to always hear ego
> pumping...).  Does anyone have a tape of mikebee rapping?  I'd personally
> love to check it out.  Also, mikebee, are you hear?  Got any gigs coming
> up?

just like anytying there are good mc's and bad mc's. the british 
hardcore/jungle culture is built around them. i've heard some great mc's 
and i've heard people who i've wanted to slap. :) Bad mc's generally 
big-up themselves (say self-promoting things) too damn much. Good mc's 
big up the crowd. and good mc's know when to shut up.
i've had some of my best experiences ever mc'ing with a crowd - t's like 
an exchange of energy, i feed off how the crowd reacts...if the crowd 
doesn't like the music, then i have trouble doing a good job. But there 
have been moments (which i luckily have one of on tape) where me, the 
music and the crowd clicked (i used to mc solely for a jungle dj named 
dieselboy)...and it's pure magic. 

My next gig is in Allentown, PA at an all-jungle party called Bass 
Rush...it's my first plane gig. :)


mike

i ddon't think you get the whole gist of mc's....they don't stand up 
there and shout about how bad they are and 'rap' like you'd think (the 
only mc's i've seen do this were american and nuff said about that). The 
role of mc is one to help the crowd feel it, to get everyone pumped and 
into the music. Granted, this doesn't really work with more 
trance-inducing musics, as i stated in my last post....i guyess you need 
to experience it to understand it...


mikebee

	/* don't try and compile this or I'll have to hurt you. */

Mailer: Elm [revision: 70.85]
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Amy writes:
> 
> I hate to sound like a geek, but is Crash Worship a band?  If so what 
> type of music?  Just curious.

	Yea, they play tribal, but not what a raver would normally think of
as tribal -- it isn't techno.  It's a couple guys taking turns beating on
drums, wailing, spitting fire, building fires on the dance floor, throwing 
various substances onto the scantily-clan masses, and other general mayhem.
They're not so much a band as performance artists who need the audience 
for the show.  The real nice thing is that they seem to mix the community 
spirit of a rave with the intensity and sexuality of something much more 
hardcore.


T.

--
     __|| __||                   Todd Hodes
    (____(____)            hodes@cs.berkeley.edu
                     http://http.cs.berkeley.edu/~hodes

> i ddon't think you get the whole gist of mc's....they don't stand up 
> there and shout about how bad they are and 'rap' like you'd think (the 
> only mc's i've seen do this were american and nuff said about that). The 
> role of mc is one to help the crowd feel it, to get everyone pumped and 
> into the music. Granted, this doesn't really work with more 
> trance-inducing musics, as i stated in my last post....i guyess you need 
> to experience it to understand it...
> 
> 
> mikebee

damn right mike, I heard some american shit mc on this tape my friend has 
from some rave on the east coast and I can see why they have such a bad 
name. But some parties in England that I went to last year took me to 
another dimension. Dreamscape in particular was the biggest rave I ever 
went to in my life, massive, what a trip that was. Also Revelation on new 
year's blew my mind. Although, it was a shame I missed Begin Again as 
lots of fellow ravers were there :oe

	The scene in the UK is very different and always has been ever 
since the first acid/house parties in early eighties. It would be impossible 
to pull of some the events they have in the UK here and I am not sure 
if they would be appriciated anyway. The commercial raves here attract 
the wrong type of people and generally get a bad rep for fights, bad 
drugs, etc and usually get busted anyway - so much for the right to 
peaceably assemble -

........but that's off the subject anyway, I agree that mc's are 
sometimes key in getting the crowed pumped but whether or not they would 
go down well on the SF scene is another story altogether.


 - Micky Finn -

 :) New Years Eve in London (20,000+ screamin,trippin ravers :)

Precedence: bulk

I;'ve just heard an excellent tape of MC Mikebee and DJ Dieselboy and
can assure that mikebee knows whereof he speaks :)

I'm against having the kind of MCs who have nothing really to say except
"get it on for DJ . . ."  The old reggae style MC (Tommy Cowan, etc.)
is a good approach, as are the better hardcore/jungle ones.  But opinions
on this are not universal anywhere, there recently was some disagreement
on uk-dance among the net.punters about MCs there.

It gets down to the same old thing, below par DJs and below par MCs are
wack, good ones are worth it!



From sfraves-owner  Thu Jan 19 02:46:33 1995

Date: Thu, 19 Jan 1995 02:46:32 -0800
From: Fred Heutte <phred@well.sf.ca.us>
Message-Id: <199501191046.CAA18737@well.sf.ca.us>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Well DJ Relay
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

The Well is hosting its 100th monthly "WOP" (Well Office Party) this
Friday, the 20th, at the Presidio Yacht Club at the foot of the
Golden Gate Bridge at the north (Sausalito end).  If you're on the
Well, or if you're just interested and would like to meet some of the
people who are active here, you're welcome to attend.  It starts at
7 pm and generally finishes up just before midnight.

obsfraves, we're having what I call the first Well DJ Relay, with
four Well based-DJs spinning da toonz.  It won't be a very big or
overly loud system, and we're kinda not sure how it will go over with
the Well crowd, but we're part of the culture of the Well too, so it
could be interesting!  The Well is home to the "house conference,"
co-hosted by M Normal (miga@well.sf.ca.us), where we are currently
among other things debating the cosmic meaning of "rave culture" with
none other than Fraser Clark.

Anyway, the lineup is: M (miga) playing ambient, Gil (tow) probably doing
house, Bob Bickford (rab) doing '60s and '70s, and then me (phred)
finishing with house and trance.  

It's basically  a loose potluck, so bring something drinkable or eatable
to share if you like (but it's not required).  

If you need specific directions, I'll be happy to email them.

c u in the future!
phred
~e
:c miga

 csc@pilot.njin.net (Sean Casey) writes:
> Hyperthermia. Just for fun, bring a thermometer to a rave (the thin type
> you press against the forehead is great) and see how hot you get.


...Picking up on this hyperthermia thread, I'm currently investigating the 
risks of heat strain in clubs/raves.  In a replication of a clubs thermal
environment a couple of subjects danced for an hour to some excellent house
tunes....their oral temperature increased by 0.1oC every 15 mins, and in the
hour they lost 1kg in weight.  When I bunged the results into a computer
model, the prediction was they'd be dead after 4 hours from heat stroke.....

Continuing my research, I'm interested in behaviour in raves, I'm sure your
scene is not that different from ours in the UK...... So if you have a free
minute, and don't mind answering a few questions......

Cheers, 

	<marc>

*****************************************************************************

I am currently investigating the thermal environment in night clubs.  I am
interested in finding out what your experiences are in clubs and would be 
grateful if you could take a few minutes to answer the following questions.
All responses will be treated in complete confidence, your co-operation is
greatly appreciated.



1.  How many times in a month to you go to a club/rave etc?

2.  What type of music was played at the club you visited most recently?
	(e.g. House, Techno, Jungle)

3.  How long did you spend in this club? (Hours)

4.  How much of this time was spent dancing? (%)

5.  What do you usually wear when dancing?
   	(Plese list all clothing, not including underwear.)

6.  Do you ever remove any items of clothing? (Y/N)

7.  Do you take additional clothing to the club to keep warm before and
    after entry? (Y/N)

8.  Do you use the cloakroom in clubs? (Y/N)
	(if no please state why)

9.  How much water do you consume in a night? (Litres)
	(1 small bottle of water =500ml
       	  soft drinks carton =330ml)

10. How much alcohol do you consume in a night? (Units)
	(1 unit =half pint of beer/ one measure of spirits)

11. Have you ever found the tap heads to be removed in the toilets of a 
    club? (Y?N)

12. Do you ever take drugs such as amphetamines (speed) or MDMA (Ecstacy)
    in a club? (Y?N)

13. Whilst in a club have you ever:
	a. suffered from headaches?
	b. felt sick?
	c. felt dizzy?
	d. felt confused and disorientated?
	e. fainted?

(Please state those letters that correspond to your experiences)

14. Have you ever had painful spasms of muscles used during dancing, either
    whilst dancing or after dancing? (Y/N)

15. In the last club you were in can you please indicate how you generally
    felt:

	a. Very Hot
	b. Hot
	c. Warm
	d. Slightly Warm
	e. Cool
	f. Slightly Cool
	g. Cold
	h. Very Cold

16. Would you have preferred to be:
 
	a. Warmer
	b. Cooler
	c. No Preference


Please add any additional comments you wish to make about your experiences
in, and how you generally feel in night clubs.........


Age:

Sex:

Thank you for completing this questionnaire, it is greatly appreciated.

	-marc
					  o/	Dep't Of Human Sciences
					/ |	Loughborough University,
					 / \	Loughborough,
						Leics,  LE11 3TU
					M.B.Mcneill1@Student.lut.ac.uk
						+44 (0)509 238649

From sfraves-owner  Thu Jan 19 13:46:41 1995

	id AA24868; Thu, 19 Jan 95 13:46:36 PST
From: alves@bethe.ucdavis.edu (David Alves)
Date: Thu, 19 Jan 95 13:46:36 PST
Message-Id: <9501192146.AA24868@bethe.ucdavis.edu>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: mc slowpoke
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


apologies for coming in late on this thread ...
but what are you people talking about?

when I went to a movie mega-rave in LA there
was some "give it up for so and so, come on LA" mc'ing
but this seemed about on par for that party

I've never heard any "yippee yippee we're all on e" 
motivational shoutouts either - but that sure doesn't
sound too inspiring!

So this is an east coast / uk phenom?
And it goes on constantly through the whole party?

Indulge me, my fantasies about early rap - ny sugarhill
underground dance parties - hot and sweaty all night
and then like your fave morning dj, the funky four 
or lady b get on the mic and *Take You Home*

This would be like the Power of a well-timed Diva
(Afrohead makes me move) and can be deadly if overused
Now most of this that works for me has an emotional hook
with some bravado and sex thrown in for good measure
even your basic keep on truckin

But what sends me running for the door are the super-cheesy
secret rave planet samples.  Oooh Aaah, we're not in a gymnasium
we have transported.  Don't get me wrong.  I like fantasy in a
party - I just think the Worst techno/rave/house samples
I've heard had this type theme.  Painfully corny.	

This would be my fear of an MC.
Can one person, with words, touch everyone?
There is such an unspoken understanding - a common presence -
but approached from Vastly Different Head Spaces by the party attendees. 
One persons rock'n'roll goof is anothers peak experience.

And aren't you taking away or diminishing the
role of Everyone At the party to Make the party by having a
single leader?  Does everyone still get to be a Superstar??
Are we an Audience or the Truly Fabulous ??!!

Dave

Lotsa big name DJs and artists descending on San Francisco this weekend
for the Billboard Dance Music Summit; there are star-studded lineups at
most of the parties this weekend.   All the details are below, so I won't
bother repeating it up here.  I think I'm starting off the weekend at
the Trocadero tonight, and then 1015 Folsom Friday or Saturday. 

    ----------------------
==== THE SFRAVES CALENDAR ==================================================
    ----------------------

Thursday, January 19th - Wicked, Deconstruction Records, Urb Magazine &
        Natural Music present live
           The Dust Brothers (uk)  The Crystal Method (la)
        with DJ's Jeno   Markie   Thomas   Garth  Jon Williams
           Doc Martin  Justin Robertson  Paul Bleasdale  Justin King
        At the Trocadero [4th & Bryant Street]  21+ with valid ID   9pm-6am 
        (415) 512 5713

Thursday, January 19th - Pleasuredome Billboard Dance Music Showcase
        w/Chicago DJ Maurice Joshua & performances by Livin' Joy,
        Kathy Sledge of Sister Sledge, Melanie Williams, Joe Roberts,
        and more.  doors at 9, show at 9:30.  $5 at the door. 21+
        177 Townsend St @ 3rd, SF.  415.985.5256

Thursday, January 19th - Lift one-year anniversary
        DJs Maurice Joshua (chicago), Frankie Feliciano (NY), Digit (london)
        plus Aaron O, David Harness, Tim Martinez, Jay-J, Black, Rolo 1-3.
        55 Natoma, SF.  9:30pm-5:30am.  415.267.5984

Friday, January 20th - Organic presents Hardkiss - the Hardkiss family
        Delusions of Grandeur Tour Preview
        Live and Direct: Rabbit in the Moon and Hawke
        Plus DJs Robbie and Scott Hardkiss with 
        notorious sidekicks Keoki, Derrick Carter, Mark Farina, Galen,
                Wade Randolph Hampton
        415.266.8215

Friday, January 20th - Wicked/Zendada/Astralwerks/Gardening Club present
        Jeno  Garth  Scott Hardkiss  Reese  Taj  Markie  Robbie Hardkiss  
        Thomas  Skylab  Gavin Hardkiss  Jonah Sharpe  Charles Uzell Edwards
        Darkhorse  Professor Smith  Jon Williams  John Howard  Raymond Roker
        Wade Randolph Hampton  Kris Needs(Delta Lady/UK)  
        Andrew Rawnsley(XLR8R)  Orion(Astralwerks)
        1015 Folsom, SF.  415.979.8444  415.207.LEAF

Friday, January 20th - United Nation II
        guest DJ Boy George.  House diva Crystal Waters.
        Adeva with Frankie Knuckles
        + sound Factory DJs Marques Wyatt, Pete Avila, Aaron O
        benefits Prevention Point and Food Not Bombs
        9:30pm-7am, Sound Factory, 525 Harrison.  415.543.1300

Friday January 20th - Metagrooves Electronic Music Conference
        Cats Grill, 8th and Folsom, 12noon to 6pm. 
        panels,forums, networking, music,(djs Mark Riva, BPM/0, Shanti,
        AlphaCentauri). ambient dinner party, and post-party to follow.
        Panelists include Astralwerks, Silent Records, Richard Sun- ATOI,
        Micheal Mantra, MoonshineMusic, NorthSouth Records,
        Planet Earth Records, KALX, Soundworks, Greenhouse Record Pool,
        Robert Rich, City of Tribes,23 degrees, Sound  Traffic Control, etc.
        12-1pm registration, 1pm keynote address (Mark Riva,Metagrooves)
        1pm-6pm panels and forums, 6pm-9pm ambient dinner party,
        9pm-on post-party.  $10 = full Metagrooves XPO experience.
        more info: 415.647.7091

Saturday, January 21st -- Nag Champa -- Deep Ambient
        DJs: Joe Rice, Ronan, Nick Philip, Jonah Sharp of Spacetime Continuum
        Performers: Velocette, Torsion
        $3-10 Sliding Scale Donation Requested -- Contact tic-tac@ultima.org

Saturday, January 21st - Indonesia
        Jeno, Rick Preston, Spinner, Frank Nitty, Scott and Robbie Hardkiss
        At: Santa Cruz Civic Auditorium; $12.50 in advance/$20.00 at the door
        (408)388-3883    (510) 667-4151     (415) 605-4242    (415) 560-5314

Saturday, January 21st - Nervous Records Showcase
        Masters at Work (Little Louie Vega & Kenny 'Dope' Gonzalez)
        Frankie Feliciano   C.J.Macintosh  Pete Avila
        21+, 1015 Folsom, SF.

Sunday, January 22nd - Bulletproof Boat Party
        Marques Wyatt  Derrick Carter  David Harness  Miquel
        Tickets and info at Bulletproof 629 Haight (255.7168)

Sunday, January 22nd -- 8th House ov Aumbience 
        Presented by Silent records:  entrancing IRIS, Heavenly Music Corp.,
        Robert Shea, Happy, Theta Blip, Prof. Smith
        1190 Folsom @ 8th, (415) 864-0146.  $5 advance tix at Soundworks

Thursday, January 26th - Generations of Love
        the San Francisco House Movement comes together to benefit Project
        Open Hand at 1015 Folsom, Planet San Francisco
        admission - 3 cans of organic food
        415.435.8675

Saturday, January 28th - X, Why Zzz
        w/Skylab 2000.  details to follow.

        Simon  Doran  St__  Charisma
        Sacramento.  415.522.9958

        environmental listening, sweet n' sticky house, etc

        415.267.3076

        525 Harrison @ 1st, SF - 9:30pm-7am, 21+   415.543.1300

        Charlotte & guests galore in up to 4 dance floors.

        $5  415.303.2906  510.765.3251  408.932.0224

Mijos, I feel that I must discuss this. It is a condition which can cause
great discomfort in those around you.

 
Goes sumthin' like  theees:
Okay, yer on the "elevator go up" mode 40 mins after taking yer Disco
Biscuit, and as the peak is very obvious and you do the 140bpm
jerk-n-twitch, all that water wants out. 
                           So you oblige.
Now, spun out of yer head, you somehow make it here to the gender
discriminatory room with the tile and ceramic display. Others are enjoying
the wonders of the sink and that "oh, so dashing" person in the mirror, but
you-oh youuuu!-have one thing on your mind. So, you strut and skip in time
to the beat right into the aforementioned release-zone, and as you clench
your fists into tiny balls of joy, you do the cabbage-patch and exclaim "I
gotta boogie pee! E-hee!" and pop into the stall.

Here's the wonder. You stare at it for 2 minutes, you concentrate, and
suddenly, like a fuse on fire, a trickle winds away inside you, and
suddenly you moan at the top of yer lungs:
 "OH GOD YES! YES! OH! GOD YES! SO FUCKIN' GOOD! OH! MAN, THAT'S SOOOO GOOD!"
The discomfort will be noted if you look down and see the feet in the stall
next to you shuffle closer to the toilet and farther away from the
division. 

I apologize to any who may have been disturbed by me  at area 51. Me and IT
have not had so much fun doing our basic work in so long. If you can't
handle it, wear ear plugs to the loo. Know wud ahm sayin'?

ah, BTW,  happens to both sexes. Enjoy that tract, folks.

Always willing to share, 
 Milton and the E-Bee.....

Did anyone else see THEM? I met Xanthor, can't remeber its system, but the
planet is something like NTOOTTTLOIIAS ("No, That One Over There, To The
Left, Or Is It A Satellite? Damn, I'm too high to point it out.") so it'll
e-mail me later.

poor Xanthor, decided to "come out" and tell us about its planet, but
Xanthor  got handed some bunk E last week, and got all pissed about it and
tried to hunt down the guy  for a refund, but he was gone by 3 am. So
Xanthor and I found some Black Lics and a hit of Felix, and we sat in the
chill room and talked some. It said those T-shirts were sort of racist, it 
really felt the shirts were really sexist, representing only one of the
several reproductive states they assume, and that the organs were not drawn
on (they got these thingies with-oh, I'm not supposed to tell). I gave
Xanthor a back rub, when it tried to reciprocate, its finger suckers kept
getting stuck to my skin, so we had to use some massage gloves from
Faralon7. Xanthor said there are some people from its planet that are
really backwards and that they keep abducting people and have elvis
somewhere, and that they do cooperate with the US govt, but only as a sort
of inside joke, sorta the down side of extreme evolution, a weird sense of
humor. The rest just come down for some partying. 
  Last year it spent new year's with the Kamaaji tribe of dolphins near
Maui, and the year before with Rasim beavers in Oregon. They were kinda
cheerful but dull, but the dolphins were really cool. I hadn't done that
yet, but it didn't call me a newbie or anything.  I got a flier from it
about the Spider Monkey Funk-E Fest in Belize this March, but I can't read
it anymore, it just looks like a piece of bark with teeth marks. 
  It had this thing they take like we do E, and I tried it, he calls it
"general positive/compassionate attitude" and once you trip on it, you can 
bring it up again, anytime, anyplace, and feel the same as you did the
first time. Seems like one dose will do you for good. So they give it out
free where it comes from. I was sooo lucky it had lots on it. It's still
legal here in California, but lotsa people have a problem with it.
 At first on its planet, long time ago, there was a group that wanted to
restrict it, but there was so much, that everyone got some and then it was
pointless to do anything but take it as well. All I could say was "Wow!
Right on!" and gave it a hug again.

Me and Xanthor went back to dance, and let me tell you, this is one funky
alien. It didn't even make fun of me dancing, it knows how sensitive I can
get, and it really enjoyed the main room, especially Carlos. It likes
little guys with big smiles that hop around a lot.

Both an eager female  and I tried to get it on with Xanthor later on during
sunday, but we couldn't figure it out plus the how-and-who and  there's a
problem with those thingies they have down there-oops, gotta keep that to
ourselves.....

Lotsa love,
 Milton and the Stardusted E-Bee.....


"So what do we do with this?"
"ouch! Anything but that, you stupid humans, sheesh!"
                  -Xanthor learning top say "sheez!"

Dear Sfraves;

	Hi; Tuesday night my x-housemate beat the grap out of me. I have 
a broken orbit(eye socket); a couple of pulled cervical(neck) muscles, 
and cuts and bruses. Why, he's an alcoholic and did it while he was in a 
black out. The reason I'm posting this is that I'm scared. I got a 
restraining order placed against him, and am currently hold up here in my 
10x10 room with my computer; and my two siamese cats Ernesto Kitty and 
Archemedes. I've only been here in Cali for about 3 months and really 
don't know that many people. I'm scared he going to get drunk again and 
come back here with something more than his fists. I have no other place 
unfortuately to go except public shelters and I fiqured I'll take my 
chances here. I'm looking for a new home before the restraining order runs 
out on the 9th of Febuary. It really hurts to eat; but the painkillers 
thay gave me help; at least there's a bright side to this; refering to the 
painkillers. So any kind words; suggestions or whatever would help. I 
don't think I will make it to a show this weekend due to the my current 
situation. But I hope to at least be at Community next Wed. I would hate 
to have to let someone elses problem break my spirit.

		Peace & Love

From sfraves-owner  Fri Jan 20 09:44:14 1995

From: geoffw@nexsys.net (Geoff White)
Message-Id: <199501201743.JAA04348@nexsys.nexsys.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com, dhouse@mercury.sfsu.edu
Subject: Re: Full Moon? What Up?
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

The Full Moon went off without a hitch Tuesday night/Wednesday Morning.
The Mappoint was the Move weekly at 181 Eddy.  This is a really nice party,
in a really dodgy neighborhood, "Rock Lobsters" milling around and openly
lighting up their glass crack pipes (yow!).  It's interesting to note that
there were no "gangsters" at this party, I guess the neighborhood is too
rough for them. There was lotsa Vibe, Josh followed by Doc Martin 
who ripped it up like the ol' days.

The party let out at 3 and everyone (including the doorman who said that Move
was his first exposure to "rave" culture but that he liked what he saw) went
over to a well known spot in Berkeley (not the marina!) where Garth played for
5+ hours, some really good shit!.  This was the smallest FMR that I have
seen in a while, no more than 50 people or so, but it was really nice and
intimate, A little cold but we kept each other warm with smiles, dancing and
music.




					G

        "Re: Full Moon? What Up?" (Jan 20,  9:43am)

Subject: Re: tenderloin/181
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Mime-Version: 1.0
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

This is a really nice party,
in a really dodgy neighborhood, "Rock Lobsters" milling around and openly
lighting up their glass crack pipes (yow!).  It's interesting to note that
there were no "gangsters" at this party, I guess the neighborhood is too
rough for them. There was lotsa Vibe, Josh followed by Doc Martin
who ripped it up like the ol' days.
-------------------

As a longtime tenderloin resident (10 + years), I can verify the availability
of "Rock Lobsters" in and around the 181 (this was an ultra-funky night
spot back in the early-mid 80's as well, but that's another story...).  I
suspect the reason that there are "no gangsters" at the 181 is primarily
due to the fact that they're too busy selling rocks to bother with dancing.

I would be careful of how you deal with the neighborhood; not to cause undue
alarm but some caution is advised.  I am actually moving away from this hood
which I have considered home for some time because of the escalation of rock
related bullshit, violence included.  The cocaine problem in the tenderloin
has been skyrocketing out of control and has been having a number of bad side
effects.  While for the most part, if you keep to yourself, you will be fine,
it's worthwhile to keep your wits about you when in the vicinity of the 181.
I strongly recommend that those who are not in complete control of their
faculties NOT wander around in this neighborhood.

The worst thing about the tenderloin these days, is not, however, the local
residents, junkies and dealers, it's unfortunately the police.  I am moving
basically because of a misunderstanding between myself and a pair of corrupt
undercover police who I mistook for Johns/junkies and ordered out of the way
of my front door one night coming home from work.  They decided to step out
of their undercover personas just long enough to rough me up for "interfering"
in their "operation" which just happened to be blocking my front door.  The
serious thing is that if something like this happens there is no recourse you
can take and these guys are worse thugs than any of the rest of the local
criminals; they are simply another gang, with the exception that they have
the city behind them.  Since this incident I have had several windows in my
car broken which they recognized from the incident in front of my house and
while I am rich enough to replace the glass and keep rolling, it's a drag to
deal with.  I was unfortunately warned that if I made a formal complaint I'd
likely get more attention from the undercover police, something I'm not too
interested in.  At any rate, I don't mean to scare people away from the 181,
on the contrary, since the more people like us who hang out in the neighborhood
the better the neighborhood is (and I'm still down for the loin, for whatever
it's worth).  The club is quite cool, has much history and hopefully someday
when we get control of our public servants, the neighborhood may once again
shine.  On the other hand, there are things to be aware of just so you don't
have to deal with unpleasantries that could be avoided.

-=J=-

hug? In its many forms, it will cause ravers to submit to humiliation,

voice that says "'we' love you" actually means it. Words and actions don't
always see i to i.

At 11:07 AM 1/20/95 -0800, schoudhu@ccmail.abbotthpd.com wrote:
>     But get this.. IT GOT BUSTED! Does anyone know why? Could it be
>     another one of the Police busts that theyre doing ( Dv8, SFactory )

Maybe it's time for people to start heading back underground nowadays.
Realistically these raves we go to are SO EASY to find out about...that's
why the Cloud Factory is cancelling our voice mail for awhile and trying to
find ways to keep mkore underground.  How long has Wicked had the same
phone number at least a year now, not to mention the Gathering or Basics or
countless others...I'm not harshing on any of these people, but I hope they
will think about how they are "promoting" if these busts continue, because
I'm pretty sure that the people there didn't get there money back when the
show got cancelled...don't flame me to the list please unless it's a
general discussion levelheaded type thing...one way we are staying more out
of sight is doing a private camping trip for 60 people some we know some on
our mailing, we are hoping that we can build a stronger sense of community
and cultivate a good word of mouth system so as not to rely too heavily on
voice mails.  that's enough spouting for today...

loveandhugs scott

                   Know whuddah mean, good people?
        Well, someone does. Their "anonymousized" message follows:

>Don't worry about the creaking, freaking, etc., you just said something that
>should have been said a long time ago.  People feel, for some reason, that
>it's wrong to mention things that bother you, because, I guess, the scene
>is about being positive, etc.  Unfortunately, when things aren't exactly as
>advertised, people seem to be afraid to speak up because it will make them
>seem negative.  I have felt for a long time that there is an inner clique
>that if you aren't in it, then all that love goes sliding right by... with
>barely a nod in your direction.  While I generally am very "down with the
>scene", I feel there's alot of hypocrisy about acceptance, and I don't want
>to have to schmooze people to be accepted.  I think it's too bad that some
>of the people who are into the scene act like this, but I've often had the
>experience of having friends, etc., that will tell me about FMR events while
>the same people that told them wouldn't tell me for a million dollars where the
>damn thing is.  When those same people turn around and start bleating about
>how they "unconditionally love everyone" I have to laugh... baby, keep that
>kind of love to yourself!  Anyway, I, for one, greatly appreciate your taking
>"social risk" (well, depending on whether you care...) to keep things straight
>up and honest, so get on with your funky self and keep it real!

so, if anyone agrees that we're getting the short end of a limp stick,
write me, I won't tell anyone, or even "anonymousize" it without yer
consent, Jeno will never know, and you can sleep tight. Plus you can help
construct a party someday, just by bringin' yer bad-ass self and dancing
and smiling. 

           Dream about it. Think about it. Talk about it.
                     Drive to it and do it!
                      Take back the scene!

                    (or get blisters trying!)

	Does anyone know if that measurement that determined that the 
sound was "above legal limits" was taken inside or outside? Is there 
actually a limit on the amount of sound one can produce within a 
sound-dampening room? I wonder if the firing range the nice peace 
officers use ever reaches above said legal limit? Actually, this is a 
serious question, cuz if parties can be shutdown due to excessive 
interior noise, this could represent a problem not only for large 
massives and little gatherings, but also the parties you and two friends 
throw in your flat that the cops stumble upon...

From sfraves-owner  Fri Jan 20 18:14:42 1995

	id SAA05289; Fri, 20 Jan 1995 18:13:39 -0800
Date: Fri, 20 Jan 1995 18:13:39 -0800
From: geoffw@nexsys.net (Geoff White)
Message-Id: <199501210213.SAA05289@nexsys.nexsys.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com, medeiros@nature.Berkeley.EDU
Subject: Re: fool's moon
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk



My dearest Milton,
	Will you please lighten up on the whole FMR thing.  There is nothing
	sinister or malific going on.  Basically it takes money and energy
	(yes and guts) to throw these parties and after over three years
	I'm sure some of the participants are getting tired, especially when
	people complain no matter what you do.  

	If you let people know early with plenty of advanced warning then
	the parties are busted before they start (because all of the auto
	movement and folks hanging around HOURS before they are suppose to be
	there tips off the Police).  If you make it too accessable then a lot
	of gangsters and the nitrous proffiteers show up and make it less than
	a wholsome event.  People complain about the party always getting busted.

	If we drive it underground and people have to work a little to find it
	well it is true there are less people but the Vibe is stronger.

	I personally told at lease 8 people on this list where the mappoint 
	to the FMR was around 8:30 pm.  Anyone who called me that night
	and asked me where the mappoint was, was told.  No, I didn't tell the 
	location to people until around 2:00 as I was told to do.  There are a
	a couple of reasons for this, first there shouldn't be a bunch of people
	milling around at the site before the music starts, two years ago the
	most of the folks who went knew how to act at an underground, they
	slipped into the area quietly and didn't draw attention to themselves,
	now people bring firecrackers, nitrous tanks without silencers and
	boom their stereo's just askin for the cops to come.  The second reason
	is that the site could CHANGE at short notice and all of the people who
	went to the first site will become lost.  Undergrounds are suppose to
	be hard to find, remember?
	If you came to 181 there wasn't any problem finding out where
	the party was.  There are even places on the net where
	directions can be found if you bother to look.  The simple fact
	of the matter is that the FMR IS an underground party, it is
	generally illegal, even when it is not stressed by the police
	it is because there are tacit agreements made about conduct and
	size.  For all the bitchin and moaning, I don't see anyone
	risking their sound systems (except maybe Brycer and Galen) or
	arrest throwing outdoor underground monthlies.  Why don't you
	try organizing and throwing your own FMR before you criticize?
	In fact the next time we can use your credit card to secure the
	generator.



				G

   I agree that the FMR should be underground, but I also think Milton
has some great ideas.  Maybe it is time for other groups to get together
and put on FMRs.  I'm glad Wicked has been throwing FMR's for so long...
but I must admit, it gets very annoying when the parties don't start until
5:00 am the following morning...Geoff mentioned that maybe Milton should
try organizing a FMR before he criticizes.  Well, he has been.  Milton
has been introducing many different groups (Ooga Booga, Tribal Funk,
E-Ticket, Harmony, etc...) to us (the Cloud Factory)...I can't speak
for everybody, but we are considering throwing full moon parties this
summer (with help from other groups).  
   We don't want to step on Wicked's toes, but if people are
going to be left completely in the dark, maybe it's time some other
people do something about it.  I completely agree that it should
be kept underground, but it's also nice to know that the party you
are searching for is actually going to happen.....
Hopefully this won't become a flame war (I don't see why it should...).
Anyways, I just had to vent.....

matt

Why wait to the summer?  There is a full moon comming up in 27 days!
I think that most of the people who complain don't realize what a tourch it
is to bear.  Are you saying that the Cloud Factory is willing to commit to
putting on an FMR for 12 months or so straight?  (It's one thing to throw
one party, it's another to throw them for three years)  The thing is that
I don't think any of the complainer are willing to say OK we will throw
the party for the next 13 months, no matter what, we will front the $400
a month or so that it cost to rent the sound system, generator and such,
we will risk arrest, inpounding of our system for the next 13 months, we
will manage a crowd at an illegal event where no-one is being searched and
any one can bring guns.  We will clean up the place after the party if folks
don't stay for that part.  Is this what I'm hearing that the Cloud Factory is
signing on to do?



 
>    We don't want to step on Wicked's toes, but if people are
> going to be left completely in the dark, maybe it's time some other
> people do something about it.  I completely agree that it should
> be kept underground, but it's also nice to know that the party you
> are searching for is actually going to happen.....
> Hopefully this won't become a flame war (I don't see why it should...).
> Anyways, I just had to vent.....

Well I think you will see the light when you have thrown one or two of these,
how much energy it takes to throw these consistantly and make sure that they
go off without major incident.  Even Galen who I have the utmost respect for
had some really bad shit happen to them at the end of sunset because of the
area that they chose to have the party in.  It's not easy and before people 
open there mouth about how they are gonna have a Full Moon party, I hope
they have some commitment to having more than just a "one off"
