Received: (from solrvibe@localhost) by zoom.bga.com (8.6.9/8.6.9) id WAA05609; Fri, 20 Jan 1995 22:20:00 -0600
From: Jonathan Tea <solrvibe@bga.com>
Message-Id: <199501210420.WAA05609@zoom.bga.com>
Subject: Full moon
To: geoffw@nexsys.net (Geoff White)
Date: Fri, 20 Jan 1995 22:19:58 -0600 (CST)
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
In-Reply-To: <199501210316.TAA05414@nexsys.nexsys.net> from "Geoff White" at Jan 20, 95 07:16:26 pm
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
Content-Type: text
Content-Length: 1908      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> area that they chose to have the party in.  It's not easy and before people 
> open there mouth about how they are gonna have a Full Moon party, I hope
> they have some commitment to having more than just a "one off"

OK, all respect to those who put themselves in jeopardy with the law to
throw these things.  But why does one group have to "carry the torch" for
full moon raves?  The full moon is a special time that has been happening
for a lot longer than raves have been and just because someone wants to
throw a full moon party, I don't think that obligates them to have one on
every full moon.  

It seems to me that these things would be harder to bust if different groups
were throwing them throughout the year.  When the same group is throwing
them month after month, it becomes progressively easier for the authorities
to track them down.  And having two on the same night would certainly reduce
the bust factor.

The full moon is a time to come together and have a good time and make new
friends and revel in the energy that seems to only come from a full moon. 
All this discussion about who can and can't throw a FMR seems to be missing
the point.  If you wanna throw a FMR, do it!  I don't care if there are 3
other FMR's the same night.  The idea that full moons are a kind of property
or territory is selfish and egotistical.  No person on this planet put that
sun reflector up there or any of the magic that goes with it.  Let's not get
away from the real reason we're doing all this, folks.  And it wouldn't hurt
any of us to www our asses to hyperreal and re-read what Laura wrote about
PLUR (paying special attention to the R part.)  I've put too much love and
energy into the collective vibe to just let it get torn down now.  Now's a
good time to get centered again.  Do it!

My two cents worth, flame away if you want to.  I can take it. 

vibrating at the speed of love

solarvibe

I mention this because I believe that if the current people who throw FMRs
were to stop and no other group made a concerted effort, there wouldn't be
any party. You see most people have better things to do than throw this
party, as soon as it stopped getting fun or started to get dangerous,
they wouldn't be into it any more.
  
> 
> It seems to me that these things would be harder to bust if different groups
> were throwing them throughout the year.  When the same group is throwing
> them month after month, it becomes progressively easier for the authorities
> to track them down.  And having two on the same night would certainly reduce
> the bust factor.

The people who throw the FMR don't go around breaking people's legs or anything
If anyone wants to throw a Full Moon Party they should do so, just make sure
that both parties don't converge on the same site.  In fact I'm surprised
with all the complaining going on that no one else has attempted it.

I've heard the lame excuse that if Wicked threw a party the same night that
no-one would go to the alternative one, well ther's just one way to find out
isn't there folks? And you might get lucky and Wicked could get lazy and you
might just have 1000 drunken people to deal with wondering when the party's
gonna start. I hope who ever throwes the party can deliver the goods :)



				G



> 
> The full moon is a time to come together and have a good time and make new
> friends and revel in the energy that seems to only come from a full moon. 
> All this discussion about who can and can't throw a FMR seems to be missing
> the point.  If you wanna throw a FMR, do it!  I don't care if there are 3
> other FMR's the same night.  The idea that full moons are a kind of property
> or territory is selfish and egotistical.  No person on this planet put that
> sun reflector up there or any of the magic that goes with it.  Let's not get
> away from the real reason we're doing all this, folks.  And it wouldn't hurt
> any of us to www our asses to hyperreal and re-read what Laura wrote about
> PLUR (paying special attention to the R part.)  I've put too much love and
> energy into the collective vibe to just let it get torn down now.  Now's a
> good time to get centered again.  Do it!

I have never heard anyone at Wicked say that the FMR was THEIR Party.
I have heard them say that if there is gonna be another party, it should be
far enough away so that authorities busting one don't think it's the same party
just moved.  I would say that the folks who want to throw a FMR the way that
they want (posting it to the net, giving every one plenty of time to arrange
baby sitters, and starting the party early so you can have thousands of people
attend) should do just that and let others who are willing to put up with
the late notification and dodgey date shifting to do it the way they want.

You are quite right that the Moon shines down on each of us equally, if
you don't like the way the FMR is executed, there is no one stopping you
from throwing your own.




From sfraves-owner  Fri Jan 20 21:20:49 1995

Subject: The 'People' in the moon...
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Fri, 20 Jan 1995 21:19:53 -0800 (PST)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

  I just have a few comments to add to the current FMR debate.

o  The FMR's don't just happen in SF.  They happen all up and down the 
California coast and other places of the world.  Wicked has been throwing 
it consitently the longest.  Before they came to SF, they threw some 
FMR's in England (under the Tonka sound system name) and thought about 
throwing similar parties in america. (Read their interview in XLR8r (i 
think) from a month or two ago.)

o  The full moon isn't the only celestial event for a good outdoor 
party.  The Cloud Factory threw a party the same day of the persid (sp?) 
meteor showers, we threw the party in a canyon and were blessed with an 
amazingly clear Monterey night.  It was a break-in so we were risking our 
equipment and what not, but the party went off with no problems.

o  I don't think there are any soundsystems out there that want to put 
the FMR on each and every month.  That's where Wicked gets lots and lots 
of props.  But, I think it would be a good thing for other people, who 
have experience in outdoor parties, to throw the FMR. 

o  Of course, you don't want 4 seperate FMR's going on at the same time.  
That's why there should be some communication between all the sound 
systems who might be intersted in throwing the party.  There should also 
be some discussion about how it should be promoted and how word would be 
spread.  It seems that Wicked has been spending the last 9 months or so 
trying to make the FMR more underground.  I mean, come on, after you've 
been in Rolling Stone magazine, you might need to shrink things a 
little.  Granted, they should at least put soem info on the voice mail 
saying it's canceled (if they're even going to put it on in the first 
place.) B But they have done a good job of moving it deeper underground.  
I think the fact the even had one in January (and with only 50 people) is 
a good sign they still want to keep doing it and build it up again.

o  On the Cloud Factory FMR... We've never said we want to do it for 13 
months straight.  It was milton who first suggested the CF do a full moon 
and we've been thinking about doing it.  If we do though, it woudln't be 
till this summer and it would probably be in the Monterey/Santa Cruz area 
or perhaps over the Golden Gate and up in the mountains.  We would also 
be interested in colaborating with some of the other sound systems out 
there to get more people involved in it.  Perhaps CF could do something 
on a Sat. night and then Pacific will take over on Sunday (in the same 
spot, if it's a good/safe one..) and do Sunset :)

  Anyways, enough said...

-Ernie (DJ Deaks)

 "There's so much love in this world..."

>   I just have a few comments to add to the current FMR debate.

Yeah I saw a picture of the FMR in Thailand someone was holding up a sign
that said "The ORIGINAL Full Moon Rave" :).  It is true the FMR (at least
for Wicked) is an modern day interpretation of the Sabat or Pagan Meet that 
happens at every full moon.  In a fully Pagan community there would be 
full moon gatherings all over the country side and peopl would go to the
one that was closest to them either physicaly or psycicly


> 
> o  The full moon isn't the only celestial event for a good outdoor 
> party.  The Cloud Factory threw a party the same day of the persid (sp?) 
> meteor showers, we threw the party in a canyon and were blessed with an 
> amazingly clear Monterey night.  It was a break-in so we were risking our 
> equipment and what not, but the party went off with no problems.

Yes, sister Moon has 27 other faces, pick one.  Like the New Moon posse did.

> the FMR on each and every month.  That's where Wicked gets lots and lots 
> of props.  But, I think it would be a good thing for other people, who

This last party was really good, it was nice that it was small, such a contrast
from the 3000+ party that left Bonnie Doon a mess over a year ago.


> 
> o  On the Cloud Factory FMR... We've never said we want to do it for 13

> on a Sat. night and then Pacific will take over on Sunday (in the same 
> spot, if it's a good/safe one..) and do Sunset :)

That's fine but bear in mind that folks can't have it both ways, they complain
that Wicked is lagging but no-one wants to say OK I'll carry the load for a 
while.  Every one is willing to do one or two but if Wicked stopped all 
together would there still be a FMR? Who would carry on the tradition?
I'm afraid that offers to do one in the future (but don't get me wrong
please please do do it!) won't help the situation now of making sure that
there is a (hopefully unbusted) party each month. And if Wicked say OK guys
your right, we're out of it, who's gonna step to the plate and carry on now
I don't hear any of us out here saying that we will take this tremendous task
on for a period of time, maybe someone should offer to do them for a season,
i.e Cloud Factory take the spring, Wicked take the Summer, Pacific take the 
Fall, and CDC or someone take the winter. That way the burden would be shared

Other event coming up

Feb 1-2 	Imbolc
March 21 	Ostara
May 1		Beltane

All good Pagan Holidays in their own right!

I don't care if you're a jaded raver.... I've seen so many music 
styles/trends come and , well, they actually never go - we just keep on 
groovin'! But I want to thank you for the major compliment you gave me in 
this message, as I did the Intellabeam programming! Thank you sooooo much 
for calling it excellent!! And a big (smooch) from Andre as well. I was 
called at the last minute ( 7:30 pm the night of the event) and am 
further handicapped by crutches ( yes, I am still on crutches and heading 
for more surgery soon ). But I couldn't bear the thought of sitting at 
home when there were 6 Beams that needed to be programmed for what looked 
to be a cool event. And Dutch was panicking. So off I went, and it was 
fun! I ran through his set, until about 2:30, and then Andre and Trev 
took over. It was a cool party, everyone was dancing, and kudos to all 
the DJ's and Visual artists that contributed their positive and creative 
energy to the party. And thanks to all you who came and danced. 
Hopefully, in about 9 months to a year, i will be able to once again join 
you on the dance floor. Peace. Lady Trash

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com

    i don't believe i have been more dissappointed about a party in a great
while!
this party proved to me that maybe just maybe ... i don't like organic
parties.
i think i knew this before hand , but the appetizing price of 12 dollars, so
called magnificent dj line up, and the location which i like ....all tempted
me to go.
as for the people however.....i don't know but there is just something about
the people that organic attracts.
it seemed like there were two kinds of people there.....big brutes with no
shirts fumbling around as high as kites, and little girls problably about 14
years old.
   i always appreciate a good dj when i hear one ....and last night out of
the lineup...i'd have to say it was fairly dissappointing. Keoki, who i came
to see, pretty much kicked my ass but for some reason i expected him to be a
lot more entertaining. Though his mummy costume was pretty neat!
now for hardkiss.....i believe all these brothers do well is make records and
sell them , not perform them. they seemed excited about being there but i
think it was the way they didn't mix records is what bothered me the most but
I did get a free tape though -so that was cool. And lastly i thought mark
farina did a pretty well done job and ended off the evening with some good
tunes.
.......all in all this party was dissappointing, and maybe i learned my
lesson this time about what parties i like and parties i don't like. but
hey...you win some you lose some, can have it always how you want it
unfortunately...............erica

On Sun, 22 Jan 1995 Ravergirl2@aol.com wrote:

>     i don't believe i have been more dissappointed about a party in a great
> while!

I was trying to decide whether to go to Organic or the 1015 Folsom thing 
and pretty much flipped the coin.  Folsom it was. I hadn't been to a 
party at 1015 since it used to be "Das Klub" in the 80's. 

Here's my most interesting story from this event:  three Italian guys are 
in line ahead of me and are disscussing some pertinent matters and 
finally one of them decides to take his I.D. and proceed to security dude 
for the once over... his trick was to immediately light a cigarette in 
front of the security guy while checking the I.D.  At the time I figured 
it was to make him look more mature, but now that I think about it maybe 
it was just to draw more attention to the fire in his mouth than to the 
features of his face...

Anyways the security dude determined the deception and didn't let him or 
his friends in. 

Other than that I don't think I could report anything signinficant so 
I'll leave it to someone else. 

WIllis

Nag Champa was a nice event , but a missed opportunity on my part.

 I guess I arrived with some misconceptions about the event - I thought
it was going to be something like listening to a classical music
quartet - everyone sitting around quietly and appreciating the music.
It actually was like a big chill room at a Richmond rave , but without
the big bass coming in from the main dancefloor ,and better mattresses.
Once I made my conceptual shift , I had a good time for the remainder
of my time there ( I had to leave early because I had to go to work
today - that's where I'm writing from now ).

 Nice video work by Mike - and who was the other guy(s) upstairs? And
the music was great too , once I understood that a wide range of musical
styles was going to be played. 

 ---

 One of the things I usually regret is not meeting or talking with more 
folks at raves - so Nag Champa would have been perfect , except I got
started with my conversation somewhat late , so I didn't get to meet as
much folks as I could have . It was nice to see folks I haven't talked to
in awhile - Resonate , Raffaela , Rocky (Rocki? female , not male ),
and other SFRavers whose names don't begin with R . Maybe I'll do more
and better socializing at the next such event ( let's have another one! ).

	Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

I WOuld try and make Nag Champa,  but nobody took the time to tell me
where it was.    If you looked in the calander,  you would have seen it
mention an Email address to contact for more info.   Well,  I emailed
my request for info,   but they didn't tell me in time,  so,  not knowing
where the party was,  I didn't go.    How was it?    I heard it was smokey,
yes,  well then I probably wouldn't enjoy it.     Just so you all know,
to all those smokers out there in SFRave land,   I have medication to counter
act the nasty effects (Nausia,  dizzybess,  etc),  unfortunately,  it costs
me $25 for a single pill,   thats $5 more than an E tablet,   which really SUX,,
so all U tobacco addicts out there,  PLEESE consider what *I* have to pay
to enjoy myself at raves.   The medication WORKS,  is horribly expensive,
but I'm willing to put up with it so all U smokers can still have your
nicotine fits because I like raving so much to have to put up such a high
personal expense to attend these parties.   Anyway,  thats my $.02.

Cheers
Crunch man...

At 11:07 AM 1/20/95 -0800, schoudhu@ccmail.abbotthpd.com wrote:
>     But get this.. IT GOT BUSTED! Does anyone know why? Could it be
>     another one of the Police busts that theyre doing ( Dv8, SFactory )

Here's my speculation on the recent busts by the SFPD. I was at the 938
Harrison Raid/debacle/ that occured on New Year's . I almost didn't get my
computer out that raid, owing to the fact that the cops wanted to
confiscate everything. But that's another story! After finally allowing me
to take the computer home, the officer in charge, a Captain, happened to
mention to me that: 

"By the way it was one of the local clubs around here that turned 'You 
guys' in" 

Could it be that the recent slew of raids and busts _might_ have an
economic basis? ie., that some clubs might be blowing the whistle to drum
up more business for their own locales. What do you think?

In fact, I think Reid is right.  I was also at the 938 Harrison raid and 
several others (the police as well as the guy who threw the party) said that 
it had been the owner of another club (I forgot the name though) who had 
registered a noise complaint earlier that day because of the sound check.
The police came by later on because of the earlier noise complaint.
(at least this is what I was told by the lawyers handling the case)

I've seen it happen before and it wouldn't surprise me at all if a lot of 
the recent busts were a combination of club owner sabotage and the 
"crackdown" on soma clubs.

It would be really unfortunate if this is true.

From sfraves-owner  Mon Jan 23 01:44:17 1995

Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id BAA29772; Mon, 23 Jan 1995 01:44:17 -0800

	id BAA05692; Mon, 23 Jan 1995 01:43:21 -0800
Date: Mon, 23 Jan 1995 01:43:21 -0800
From: crunch@netcom.com (John Draper)
Message-Id: <199501230943.BAA05692@netcom8.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Atomicon Review
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Atomicon Review

   A fellow SFRaver,  David Minuk informs me of a Hardcore rave on 
Friday that I should check out.    It wasn't initially on the
SFRave calander.   but early on Friday afternoon,   someone
added it to the Addendum to the calander.

Friday, January 20th - Atomicon
        "techno, jungle, gabber, hard acid, hardcore, house"
        415.337.4236

With a severe lack of Gabber and Hardcore in the SF Area,  and
thanx to David for providing me a ride,  I had the opportunity
to check it out.    We had no idea how large this party would
be,   because it wasn't promoted that well,   and it got up
on the SFRave calander rather late,  so few people had
opportunity to check it out.

We call the info line,   and learn where it's map point is
located,   and after driving around for a while,   we locate
the Map point dude,  pay then $5,  get our hand stamp,   and
head out to the secret location (Somewhere in SF).

We finally arrive at the venue..  Which was very discreet,
and eventually get let into the space.    The space,  although
rather small,    was about the size of Komotion,   might be
able to accommodate about 100 people,  possibly 150.   When
we arrive,   about 30 people were there.    DJ Crust was 
spinning Housey trance.    And we learned that DJ Stone and
Maria had just finished spinning.    Maria was spinning jungle
but we missed it (Darn!).

The Chill area,  was decorated with spacey mushrooms,  and
a strange mask was mounted on the wall.    It had comfortable
mats,  and pillows spread around the floor,  and the main
dance area had about 10 people dancing.    After stretching
in the chill area,    I headed out to the dance area,  and
was surprised to hear the "Ha Ha" laughing song again.   This
song was also spun by Josh Wink at Area 51.   I also heard
two other songs played at Area 51,  plus a bunch of new songs
I haven't heard before.    I haven't heard DJ Crunch spin 
before,   and have to say,  he was rather good.

Eventually,  DJ Crush gave way to DJ Mars who wasted no time
in upping the BPM's to about 160 -175 range,  and played the
most brilliant Hardcore Trance I've ever heard.    ALL the
songs he played,   I've never heard before,  and really dug
his energy.    The much faster beats,  and new Hard core trance
was really refreshing to hear,  especially in the SF scene.

I recommend that we put DJ Mars behind the turntables at our
next Friends and Family party.   His stuff is really brilliant,
and his energy is amazing.    With little or no breaks in the
fast pumoing 160+ BPMs,  his "beat matching" was excellent,
which I seldom hear from other Hardcore DJ's,  which isn't
that much around here.

The Sound system,  although small,   delivered the music adequately,
although somewhat overdriven at times,   but for the small space,
it was certainly OK with me.   The strobe was excessive at times,
but it wasn't on ALL the time,  and the lighting and visuals wasn't
super spectacular,  but the music more than made up for it.

Most of the Hard core trance was instrumental,  lots of electronic
sounds,  literally put my brain out in space,  and I danced his
entire set,   chilling no more than 5 - 10 minutes as the music
was constantly beckoning me to continue dancing.    Being my
2nd "all nighter",   where my previous evening was devoted to
hearing the Dust Brothers at the Troc,   which got shut down
early by the pigs.

After DJ Mars left the turn tables,  the BPM's got nudged up a
few more notches to somewhere between 190 and 210 BPM's as I
got to hear Gabber for the very first time.    Yow!!   It was
totally INSANE...    It's almost impossible to jump around at
that speed,   but BOY!  It offered some very new dancing 
possibilities,  as I was experimenting,  and frustrated that
the Earths gravity was far too weak for me to do a lot of
jumping around,   but eventually I fell into some blazingly fast
undulating motions with my back and arms.  WOW!!  Had NO idea
I could move that fast.   It is vertainly something I wouldn't
want to do ALL the time,   but the variaty was really great.

I think that Brisen the DJ,  had the volume slightly in the
distorted range,   but the super high energy really loostened
me up,  thats for sure.   Most of his music comes from the
E Coast and Holland and Germany/

At about 5 am,   me and David plus a few others were the only
ones still dancing,   and David wanted to check out Venus,  but
by the time we got there,   things were shut down,  so we eventually
headed back homw.

All in all,   it was an excellent party,   fairly small,  and
VERY UNDERGROUND!!    I strongly recommend that you go to the next
planned party.     Just expect some secrecy,  and a tight Map point
policy.    Also expect a little difficulty in finding the map point.
Just be VERY discrete,  and don't hang outside by the front door.

It is very refreshing to know that the SF scene will be getting
more variaty in music types and higher BPM's.   So be looking 
forward to expanding into newer variaties of music,  and hopefully
the SF scene will offer far more variaty....   CHECK IT OUT!!

Crunch

Hi! Susie has been nice enough to let me use her net connection to 
get word out that I need a place to live. How shall I put this without 
sounding too desperate? Hellllpppp!!!! This unending dwelling search has 
like-you know-put a serious dent in my rave schedule. God! i was so 
pooped on Saturday after having "the perfect place" snuffed by a roomate 
who decided at the last minute to change her mind and not move out, that 
I didn't make it to nag champa, ohmygod! So I'm really hoping that maybe 
some very special sfraver knows of a place. Let me discuss briefly my 
wishlist for a place:

safe neighborhood in sf
good transporation (no car now)
w/ direct access to yard for my kitty boo
washer and dryer would be nice
no more than three roomates though two would be better
reasonable rent

I am a responsible, clean, happy & friendly roomate, i've lived 
in sf for almost five years.  Some of the best people on earth are ravers, 
and as i continue to rave, i continue to be amazed by the infinite 
amazingness of ravers, so i know my 
plea is in good hands here. If you know of a place, call me @ Gregory's 
(415) 665-7057. THANKS!  Peace, Amy

In article <Pine.3.89.9501221901.A14146-0100000@netcom>,
Reid Fossey <reidf@netcom.com> wrote:

> Could it be that the recent slew of raids and busts _might_ have an
> economic basis? ie., that some clubs might be blowing the whistle to drum
> up more business for their own locales. What do you think? 

I think you are right, but I believe the economics to be much more evil than
the jealosy of rival club owners.  There are some very rich and politically
connected property owners, our beloved mayor (cough) may be one of them.
Seen how the property values in the Embarcodero have gone up over the last
few years?  My guess is these property owners want to do the same to SOMA.
I haven't heard of any yuppie bars being busted lately, they might nail
daddy's favorite son if they did, so they don't.

I'm not saying the the police are the dupes of some malevolent political
machine.  This is SF after all.  But certain elements of the police force
are sure to be open to political promptings.

Ciao,

PT

Subject: the 1015 thing

Precedence: bulk

There were a lot of good reasons for not going to the friday
wicked/astralwerks/gardening club/whatever thing at 1015 folsom.

- Going to any well establised club on a friday or Sat nite means
that there will be a lot of club people/tourists there.

- Big ugly flyer alert

- Music industry & record label people in town usually brings in a pretty
vibeless "suit" element.
 
- CLubs featuring multiple dance rooms (3 on friday) often create a party
with a lot of churning: the "Let's go see if something cooler is happening
in another room" syndrome.  I find that one dance room, and a chill out
room works best, except for big venues like Richmond Civic Auditorium. 
where other dance area can be set up far as an indepenent  entities.

- alcohol

Well, we went anyway simply because it had been *so* long since we've gone
out dancing (NYE), and we prefered 1015 Folsom and it's DJ lineup over 
Ceasar's where Organic was.  We pretty much got what was expected, a club
scene.  In at around 2.   Screetching Diva on the stage of the Main
room to our right, retro 70's in the front room to our left - we dodged a
couple of drunks and escaped to the basement.  Better - Markie was spinning
and there seemed to be some kind of a vibe.  Horrible speaker distortion
to our left, conga player to our right - we opted for the speaker distortion.
Bought a 2$ bottle of water.   My record for fastest time before having a
water bottle stolen was shattered at about 2 minutes.  I put it down,
spin around, it's gone.  (previous record 15 minutes, also in the basement
of 1015 folsom strangely enough).  Ah well, perhaps it saved someone's 
life.  Speaker distortion reduced the music to a nice rumble - hey the
conga player really isn't too bad...

Later we check out John Howard spinning some nice house in the front room.
The main room is featuring John Williams, but the high end seems to be 
getting pushed to a rather harsh level.  All the tourists are there 
anyway.  By 4:30 the party had thinned out considerably.  Jeno is going
off in the basement, but we were already feeling bored.  At least it didn't
get busted.

Lee
____________________________________________________________________________
lxfogel@pacbell.com   (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )    lee@hyperreal.com

Geoff W. inquires of Milton:
>Why wait to the summer?  There is a full moon comming up in 27 days!

well, I would love to see it happen, too, sweetcheeks! maybe there's enough
time to get ready, maybe not. Why the rush, "we" haven't been to one in
sooooo long anyway, remember? Nor have *most* of the people I love and
consider sincere and open. A lot of them are under 21, go figure.....

>I think that most of the people who complain don't realize what a tourch it
>is to bear.  Are you saying that the Cloud Factory is willing to commit to
>putting on an FMR for 12 months or so straight? 

Well, hold on there. Maybe it's a COMUNITY effort. Let me explain this term
to the general public: a lot of people with like interests cooperate and
share the work and the joy. Makes it easier for everyone involved, lets
more people participate, the scene grows and blooms. Oh my!

>I don't think any of the COMPLAINER are willing to say OK we will throw
>the party for the next 13 months, no matter what, we will front the $400
>a month or so that it cost to rent the sound system, generator and such,
>we will risk arrest, inpounding of our system for the next 13 months, we
>will manage a crowd at an illegal event where no-one is being searched and
>any one can bring guns.  We will clean up the place after the party if folks
>don't stay for that part.  Is this what I'm hearing that the Cloud Factory is
>signing on to do?
 
Ok, Geoff, it's COMPLAINERS, not just MY big mouth. Maybe you should talk
to all those who aren't getting the info as soon as yourself or those 8 on
your phone tree. Or those who don't work for themselves and can't afford to
reschedule everyday, at the whim of "that voice on the line."
 Also, what if that money does pop up? What if several people share the
costs? Hmmm....And what if we do decide to clean up the place? That sounds
like a way of life more than a chore after a party. Guns, hmm, are you
saying that there WILL BE GUNS at anyone else's FMR? 

>Well I think you will see the light when you have thrown one or two of these,
>how much energy it takes to throw these consistantly 

Hello? Consistantly? But yes, I am shure it will be a pain in the colon.
Sheesh, maybe we'll all just give up...

>and make sure that they
>go off without major incident.  Even Galen who I have the utmost respect for
>had some really bad shit happen to them at the end of sunset because of the
>area that they chose to have the party in.  It's not easy and before people 
>open there mouth about how they are gonna have a Full Moon party, I hope
>they have some commitment to having more than just a "one off"

I can't make promises, especially if they can't be kept 100%. Who knows
what sorta shit will happen.But wow! maybe we should TRY and see what
happens? 
Maybe wicked would like to cooperate and join in with other systems, have a
rotating set of DJs and systems and promoters every month? That would mean
a lot of planning and talking and understanding and sharing, sorta what
ravers try to do in their everyday lives. Hmmm....I'm up for that. Care to
share?

clinging to that limb I went out on,

Subject: Nag Champa review
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

      mattster says:                Nag Champa review                    
1/23/95                                                                        
12:26 PM
Nag Champa, the giant slumber party, the perfect end to a long evening. I went
with my friend Cydney who is stuck in horrible grad school hell on the East
Coast and has been dying to go to some offbeat parties since I talk about raves
a lot. Cydney described it like an opium den, which I thought was really right,
people lying around on bean bag chairs and in sleeping bags listening to spacey
music, some dancing very slowly, some covered in body paint and moving in a very
stylized manner and some watching the psychedelic graphics on the video screen.
Lots of cigarette smoke, yes, too much. We parked up on the stage and got to
watch the djs at work. Great music most of the time, the stuff I love to space
out at home and managed to enjoy it there, too, but I couldnt help noticing
that as soon as music with a little bit of a beat was played, people were immediately
on their feet, ready to move, asking for more. I was, too. Left after about 2
hours because it was too hard to sit without getting way sleepy. I can dance
till morning, but please dont ask me to sit so long because the mind wanders
and loses focus. Thanks to all who put it on. I will go to any event at Komotion
anytime because I like the small community feeling there.

Matthew

---- Sleep when you're dead.

Mijos, if anyone would like to contribute to the FMR debate, but has a fear
of being flamed, fear not!

Anything anyone has to say is just that, something they said (wrote!),
nothing more. Nobody's opinion/views are any more valid than anyone else's.

So write today, to me  (for anonymous forewarding) or everyone (soapbox!),
and don't fear a response! And remember, the more input, the more the party
belongs to everyone. LIKE IT SHOULD.

Sure - FMR's are sometimes a bit flakey and have had a higher bust 
percentage than other parties - this is nothing new, and is actually
pretty common for illegal renegades.  If you don't like the way something 
is run, it is real easy to just conserve your energy for something else.
If you feel strongly about some void in the scene, complaining about it 
usually will not do much to fill it.  Positive action might.  

Lee
____________________________________________________________________________
lxfogel@pacbell.com   (   ( ((truth-love-energy))  )   )   lee@hyperreal.com
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

At  8:26 AM 23/1/95 -0800, Jack wrote:
>Could it be that the recent slew of raids and busts _might_ have an
>economic basis? ie., that some clubs might be blowing the whistle to drum
>up more business for their own locales. What do you think?

>C'mon!!!  [really tho!]

>At  8:26 AM 23/1/95 -0800, Jack wrote:
>Could it be that the recent slew of raids and busts _might_ have an
>economic basis? ie., that some clubs might be blowing the whistle to drum
>up more business for their own locales. What do you think?
>----------------
>dead on the $$$!!!!  Did you think anything else mattered to "them"?
>C'mon!!!  [really tho!]

If it was just greed, this would be an isolated incident. Unfortunately it
seems that there is a concerted attempt to contain and control youth
culture in general and rave culture specifically. Which explains the
moritorium on Club Licences (licences are a source of cash for the city, so
rule out greed), the 2am dance ban. The alchohol/drugs smear attempt and
attempts to make peace-loving citizens just plain shit-scared.  Seems like
the CJB is alive and well and living in San Francisco by default. Expect
your right to dance on the grass to go the way of other "quality of life"
rights. This is not an Isolated System, but rather an interlinked
global-legal hegemony. But if we maximise our positives, we can stop this
before we get to the point of no return.

DD

From sfraves-owner  Mon Jan 23 19:33:35 1995

Received: from violet.berkeley.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with ESMTP id TAA13709; Mon, 23 Jan 1995 19:33:31 -0800
Received: from [128.32.207.42] by violet.berkeley.edu (8.6.8/1.33r)
	id TAA16261; Mon, 23 Jan 1995 19:33:27 -0800
Message-Id: <199501240333.TAA16261@violet.berkeley.edu>
Date: Mon, 23 Jan 1995 19:39:00 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: sboyer@violet.berkeley.edu (steve boyer)
Subject: Organic/Nag Champa
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

        Hey all!  Went to a couple of things this weekend, and thought I'd
fill you in on the details.

        Organic:  The evening started out originally with the intent of
making it over to 1015 Folsom.  After hearing what was coming out of the
front floor (it sounded worse than Kylie Minogue :-), we lost interest,
even if the rest of the party wasn't like that.  We packed up and headed
off to Organic.  
        Arrived at Ceasar's, and waited in the rain for about 30 min. 
Inside:  quite a few people (800?), mostly younger than me (I turned 24
last week :-), dead vibe.  I found myself trying different parts of the
dace floor to find a crew that was into it, but failed.  Ravergirl2 was
dead on with her description.  I'm really not all that picky with the
music, but it just wasn't happening for the DJs that spun before Rabbit in
the Moon came on.  It sounded like they were switching every 45 min or so,
the DJ would try to find a groove (deperately), play a couple of good
tracks, and then the music would change.  Case in point:  amazing acid
track (yay!) leading into slower breaks stuff (bummin').  Rabbit in the
Moon was pretty hit 'n' miss.  Some pretty cool 303 stuff -- I'm such a
sucker for that sort of thing.
        Good stuff:  my friend's first party, seeing him stand there
"taking it all in." the dancing guy with glowinthedark stuff that exploded
all over the crowd, covering them in drops of florescent green.  seeing
some friendly faces.  neat funky track during the "technical difficulties."

        Nag Champa:  Ahhhhh.... this is more like it!  After a day of
record shoppin', this is just what the doctor ordered!  Got there around
midnight and stayed 'til the last track.  Lots of people  spread out on the
floor of Kommotion, and a *very* positive vibe, which more than made up for
friday's disappointing experience.  Jonah spun an amazing Jugle-ish set
(I'm no good at the catagories thing) that seriously set my mind on Mars. 
The DJ that followed (Mark somebodyoranother?)  blew me out of the solar
system...  All this was wrapped up quite nicely by Joe Rice.  I'd honestly
have to say there wasn't a time all night when I didn't like what I was
hearing (a little too loud 'round 3am, but no big deal).  Visuals were
amazing too!  Many thanks to all on the list who brought this thing
together for the rest of us to enjoy.
        Good stuff:  hearing ethan say 'we packed the place' with a smile
on his face :-). seeing a fellow happy chemist there. having the chance to
actually *talk* to some of the people I've been meeting at these things.
riding home on the bart with a new mix tape in the walkman and seeing the
sun peek out from behind the clouds.

steve

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Mon, 23 Jan 95 16:49:00 PST
From: Glenn Fajardo (Starwave) <glennf@starwave.com>
To: sfraves-owner <sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com>
Subject: RE: calling all lurkers


The FMR's in Seattle started out and continues to be a cooperative, 
community oriented event.  The events are led or coordinated by different 
people at different times.  The promoters are usually good (although by no 
means perfect) about communicating what's to be done for the celebration. 
 DJ's Dervish & Michael (ATOI, Seattle) have been taking the initiative for 
 coordinating and are very much into everyone helping out to make things 
happen.  I have known them to invite and encourage even those promoters whom 
they don't necessarily see eye to eye with.   We try to live up to our 
motto:

     "FOR THE PEOPLE, BY THE PEOPLE FOR THE LOVE OF THE VIBE!!!

It's not my place to say whether either side is right or wrong.  I can only 
offer what works for us up here.

Peace.  I have faith that you will all work it out somehow.

Tigger

PS:  The FMR's in the North West were modeled after the Bay Area FMR's. 
 Thanx for the inspiration!

and don't fear a response! And remember, the more input, the more the party
belongs to everyone. LIKE IT SHOULD.

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: 21 Jan 1995 21:34:27 GMT
From: isao@morph.com (isao)
Organization: Morph's Outpost on the Digital Frontier
Subject: Re: 181, where is it and what kind of music do they play?

>>I like funk.  Is the 181 unsafe or not.  Should I go there?
>>
Andy,

181 is short for 181 Eddy-- coincidentally, the address.  Its in the
tenderloin in SF a couple of blocks from Market St. I think.  I reccommend
taking a cab if possible, actually, if you don't want to be approached by the
various street people that occupy the vicinity.

I've not had a bad experience with them myself, just offers to buy stuff from
strung out people holding persrciption bottles in my face, but my suburbia/LA
friends were a little freaked.  Personally, I think it adds to the
experience.

The club is pretty cool-- its been called New York-ish.  Used to be hoppin'
Wed/Thu, often a $3-$8 cover.  Haven't gone in a while.

Its 21+, and sneakers are not allowed.  Beyond that, there're no other dress
codes-- I've gone in ripped jeans & motorcyle boots, but have been bounced
while wearing a jacket & sneakers :(

Two stars, Joe Bob says check it out.
Isao

From: Fred Heutte <phred@well.sf.ca.us>
Message-Id: <199501240746.XAA00201@well.sf.ca.us>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Weekly Whirl (triple-pack EP!)  loooooong
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

 
Well it's been quite a while since I babbled about my travels hither &
thither
so here goes . . .
 
NEW YEAR FREEZEOUT
 
And as we slam the dial back on the scene-machine, here we are in Portland,
it's New Year's Eve and fuckin' freeeeejid, about 30 degrees and a strong
gusty wind, and we're chillin', literally, on the sidewalk outside the
infamous Albina warehouse for the big Noo Yeer's do.  I stood on that
sidewalk for just about two fookin' hours, missing all of my friend Brad
Vachal's opening set, and came in just in time to hear Buck crank up on
a full-on hour plus of slow breaks, then a whizzing Dub Tribe set, a
head-achingly loud Jon Bishop hard house-trance set, a slightly more
melodic go by Mike Stevens, all amidst the clangorous sonic mud of this
concrete warehouse.  It was full but a typically low-vibe crowd, how can
you get settled into place where there is literally nowhere to go where
the sound levels are comfortable?
 
So that was the way to ring out '94, I guess.
 
COME/UNITY UPSWING
 
Ringing in the new at 1015 Folsom with the first Come/Unity of '95 was a
better
effort overall, in fact one of the nicer C/U I've been to in a long time.
A real chugger with more of the classic Come/Unity vibe than I've
experienced
in a bit.  I liked Jeno's set quite well (he slid 'Acperience' under some
wailing diva track :), and Dub Tribe was doin' the new slooow dubby stuff
in the basement which was sounding really fine.
 
FRIDAY IS BACK
 
Friday the 6th, back again to 10 Fifteen Folsom for Sound System, a new
addition to the Friday club collage of Dig! (upper floor, hip hop),
Club Bohemia (gold room, disco-ey), and Zendada (basement, progressive
[gawds I hate that term but there it is] house).  The motivators behind
Sound System, once again, Dub Tribe, along with Professor Smith (who is
chair of the Department of XLR8R :-), playing dubby stuff which I was
unable to catch due to work, and residents Corey and Keith Crusher.
With four crowds to mix, it was somewhat as LeeF described about last
Friday (which was really not the usual stuff, more of a Billboard multi-
event), but actually I think it's good the crowds get to circulate and
try out different sounds.  Hey it brought *me* into 1015 for the first
time on a Friday in ages . . .
 
Saturday I spent a shortened but still interesting evening at Il Pirata,
with turns by a variety of DJs including the bar manager, J. C., himself.
The crowd kinda went poof! at 2 am instead of growing the vibe like in
December, but such is life.
 
Sunday the 8th, once again at 10 15 Fol som, this time for the transplanted
Spundae since DV8's liquor license was yanked for the first three weeks
of January.  The crowd was typically clubby and actually a bit sparse,
but I had an interesting time watching Carlos work the decks while Dutch
experimented with a Quadriverb effects box.  Carlos took to some serious
scratching which I haven't seen him do for some time.
 
PORTLAND HANGS IN
 
I spent the following weekend in Portland and only attended the Friday
night weekly hosted by Manoj on the 4th floor of the Park Ave (Modish)
site, with DJs Sean Paul, Dazy, Brad and Mike Stevens taking the decks.
The Portland underground is not exactly thriving, but it's hanging on.
I had the distinct displeasure once again that evening of running afoul
of Portland's small-town suspicions, as one of the space's organizers
physically tried to push me out right after I had paid my entrance,
for some reason I resembled some badguytype who apparently had been
hanging around.  Everywhere else I go, no problems.  Here at home,
I've been accused of being a cop, a dealer (in fact, both back to back
one memorable night), and who knows what . . . sigh . . .
 
BUSTED AT ... THE *TROC*?!?!
 
Although there was a lot of buzz about the Billboard showcase at the
Trocadero on Thursday night, much because of the Dust Brothers, I was
more interested in seeing Justin Robertson, a personal favorite in his
production guises (The Prankster, Lionrock, etc.), and some of the
other DJs.  But to avoid the expected crush at the Troc I decided to
check out Lift at DV8 (yes, it is open, serving lemonade at the bar :).
They always seem to have a fashion show at DV8 when I go and this was
no exception.  But without the alcohol quotient, the crowd was sweet and
serene, and one side of the dancefloor was occupied by a circle not of
the usual boring hoofers, but some excellently acrobatic old-skool
breakdancers doing that thang to the sounds of house.
 
I got to the Troc around 2:45 to find it not at all crowded and completely
low key.  Justin Robertson had just gotten on deck so I was primed for
the remainder of the evening.  Just when I scooted upstairs for another,
yes, lemonade, the word came down that the cops were shutting the party
down.  At the Troc!  I mean, the Troc is practically the only bust-proof
place in my experience (no doubt there have been some, but it's rare to
say the least).  Once again, a trumped-up noise complaint was used in
the ongoing campaign by the Yalon Gang to close down a perfectly harmless
club night.  Leaving a right disappointed JR and the rest of us to straggle
out of the ole Troc . . .
 
BILLBOARD DANCE SCHMOOZE
 
On Friday I stopped at Billboard dance music conference briefly (at the ANA
Hotel on 3rd) just to check the temperature of the scene, which was not
even tepid, four seminars going in a very low-key way.  I actually liked
this, the dance music "industry" is still a very small and unimportant
wedge of the big multinational music machine.  I saw current chartbusters
like E. G. Fullalove just wandering about without a whole lot of clamoring
and pestering that you see at, say, computer industry tradeshows around the
current "names."  So, while it was a schmoozefest -- that is the point of
these things, after all, it seemed like a very pleasant one and not the
sharks-circling kind of affair that the Gavin Report confab and similar
ones have seemingly become.  In spite of all our grumbling about the
commercialization of the house/rave/techno/jungle scenes, and the undeniable
faults and stupidities of the "commercial" side, it's still really not all
that bad.
 
LET'S GO TO THE WOP
 
That brings us up to this past weekend, where we started with the monthly
Well Office Party over at the Presidio Yacht Club at the northeastern
side of the Golden Gate.  Actually, it's a lot less swanky than it sounds.
And there was a torrential rainstorm throughout the evening, driving
everyone inside for the duration.  On the ground floor, the usual
schmoozefest with copious consumables, laminate-making and whatnot.
Upstairs in the lounge, actually a nice room with a bar (unused), pool
table (er, DJ equipment platform!) and fireplace, DJs M Normal, Gil,
rab and myself took turns in the Well's first "DJ Relay" and a fine time
was had by all, though my mixing was technically as bad as I can remember.
We had a good enough time that we'll probably do it again in a couple of
months!
 
MORE BILLBOARDNESS
 
I went to 1 0 1 5 Folsom yet again Friday after the WOP closed down at
midnight, and arrived to find the scene fairly much as Lee Fogel described,
except I walked in right when Kris Needs and Delta Lady were doing "Anything
You Dream," with the singer in this sort of disco outfit belting out the
tune up on the stage, and a vibeless crowd sort of shifting about watching
the proceedings.  Jon Williams followed with a generally faceless mid-130s
banging beats set (it's the style now, yunnow), and someone told my friend
Brad (also down from Portland for the weekend) that JW was actually mellower
than some of the DJs on beforehand.
 
It got a little better after that, with Garth and then Raymond Roker in the
main room, Corey doing breaks and Andrew Rawnsley in the gold room doing,
well, garage (great toonz tho).  After 4 or so, in fact, it was like Editor
Sound Clash in the front hallway with Raymond Urb on the port and Rawno
XLR8R
on the starboard.  Downstairs we had Markie, Jeno and Taj, the latter
spinning
wickedly deep basslines that took full advantage of the wondrous new bass
setup downstairs.  And I thought Jeno rode the really sweet smooth sound
in a way I haven't heard him do for a while.  Kewlness!  But no vibeness,
I'm afraid.  Too many people intent on having a good time to actually have
one, methinx.  I didn't see very many industry types, despite this being
a Billboard showcase.
 
SWEET NAG CHAMPA
 
More rain did not dampen our spirits setting up for Nag Champa at the
Venerable Komotion.  It was sparse at 10:45 and suddenly full at 11:15,
and 20 minutes later everyone who had been standing around in Cocktail
Party Mode suddenly got the idea, went horizontal and made it a party!
There seem to be two schools of thought on the evening, both with valid
points, in my view.  One was that the mix of music, ranging from mostly
beatless through some fairly beat-oriented stuff at quite a variety of
speeds, was just fine.  Others feel that an ambient party really needs to
be basically beat-free.  Myself, I can't avoid moving when there's something
grooving, but that doesn't have to apply to everyone (and not to me in some
situations!).
 
It got quite crowded for a while, but bearably so, and after 3 it was fine.
I enjoyed almost all of the music, starting with Ronan's varied selections
through Joe Rice's wonderfully smooth and deep finale.  Big credits to
Jonah for his usual superb selecting and a 45 minute Jonah In the Jungle
excursion which proves beyond a Moving Shadow of a doubt that yes there
IS good jungle (well I *knew* that, in fact I played a jungle track at the
Well party the night before :-).  My own view is that it was a fairly
experimental evening, and the next time there should be at least one
full set devoted mostly to textures.  But my hat's off to the people who
did the hard work to conceive of this and pull it off, the music and the
visuals were just outstanding.  Turnabout was fair play, Joe Rice had
come up to Portland to the New Year's event and watched Dub Tribe play
there, so it was fitting that Moonbeam & Sunshine were on hand to watch
Joe play!
 
I want to say again what a pleasure it is to work with all these sfraves-
related events.  I think, without overstating the case, that we really
are helping to preserve and evolve the "house nation" concept with these
events, in a time that really needs it, and I hope we continue to put
on innovative events that aren't afraid to take a risk and maybe even
fail in some eyes, because otherwise we too can turn into the vibeless
repetition that one encounters often in clubland and the underground too.
 
Yesterday I stayed away from all events.  Instead I went record shopping,
finding mostly older stuff at Star Alley and BPM.  If you have some time,
go to BPM soon and check out the upstairs, where a rather large collection
of vinyl is sitting in about 50 milk carton crates, priced good-to-go
at $2 to $4 a disc.  Nothing hugely amazing there, but I found some
interesting tidbits including some Strictly test pressings that sound
really good.  Tell DRC and Chris I sent ya :)
 
While I was there, it was discovered there had been a break-in the previous
night and a bunch of computer and audio stuff had been taken from the
upstairs offices.  Just then, Buck arrived, hoping to pick up a reel-to-
reel recorder which was one of the items taken.  The look on his face
said it all (anyone who's seen Buck spin recently knows how devoted he
is to those reel machines).  This is a disheartening blow to the BPM/Third
Floor gang so pleeze send some sfraves-beams their way.
 
Sunday night, I was tired of going to clubs, so I went and saw a movie !
 
I went into such length describing all this because it's really been my
reimmersion in the SF club scene after almost a year of being away from it.
 
My impression is that musically and vibe-wise, things are very much on a
sour (rather than dark) tip, maybe it's just the times, but I don't hear
much up-beat music or see it in the faces.  I think we miss the anchor
events of 1993 like Boogie Buffet more than might have been clear a year
ago.  But Sound System, Zendada and Come/Unity, to name just three ongoing
clubs at 1015, show that things can continue.  With the new apartment
complex about to go up across the street and the crackdown on SOMA now
becoming an integral part of the upcoming mayoral race, in particular
I think the good or great moments at 1015 Folsom are to be savored, because
by this time more or less a year from now the venue will be curtailed or
even closed, is my guess.  But there will always be *somewhere* . . .
 
c u in the future
phred

If it was just greed, this would be an isolated incident. Unfortunately it
seems that there is a concerted attempt to contain and control youth
culture in general and rave culture specifically.
-----------------------

This is not an Isolated System, but rather an interlinked
global-legal hegemony. But if we maximise our positives, we can stop this
before we get to the point of no return.

yes, the straight white christian right wing corporate overlord *IS* that
fucked, believe it.  The question is how do we counter this?  This is
shaping up to be one of the challenges *our* generation must face.  We've
been handed an incredibly corrupt system, and ignoring it won't make it go
away, nor is it a suitable response, it's time to wake up and smell the
coffee.  It will destroy the planet and all else with it if we don't
intervene; the questions are where, how and when, IMHO...1 thing seems to be
that we need to pool our collective "bargaining power" together in ways
yet TBD.  Any ideas?

Subject: Tribal Funk

I was at a gathering called F.A.M.I.L.Y. Saturday night and picked up a
letter of sorts from who I guess would be the promoter(s) of Tribal Funk.
The letter (on day-glo green paper) explained the goals of Tribal Funk, and
explained that there were differences between our two cities...stating
however, that recognizing our differences would allow us to better
understand one another and become a stonger force.  (Duh!  =)  It went on
to ask (since the drive is only 6hrs. between cities) for suggestions as to
how to bring us all together.  I dunno if anybody knows about this but I
thought it'd be nice to mention anyway.  I sure smiled when I read it!!  If
I can dig up the original I'll post it in full.


Frick out!

>Well you were doing some pretty serious complaining & I'm pretty sure Jeno

Mijo, complaining is NOT an insult. I have the utmost respect for the 4 DJs
and they have catalyzed the most important episode of my life. I am always
going to remember all the magic that happened thru them. 

The whole problem with this list or any discussion is that people take too
many things personally, can't handle criticism or different ideas. The fact
is, tho, wicked's not got its shit together. If they need help, we'll join
'em. If they want to keep certain people away (those who can't sacrifice a
midweek engagement) we'll do a seperate one.

No one is stealing wicked's show. Wicked rocks. Sometimes the setting
sucks. Sometimes they flake. But a weekend-bound full moon will not affect
those die-hards who say "screw wednesday, I'm going to Wick's FMR".....

        "Re: Full Moon? What Up?-I'll tell you what!" (Jan 24, 11:11am)
References: <199501241911.LAA00283@nature.Berkeley.EDU>
X-Mailer: Z-Mail (3.1.0 22feb94 MediaMail)
To: medeiros@nature.Berkeley.EDU, Josh Bates <unknown@nexsys.nexsys.net>
Subject: Re: Full Moon? What Up?-I'll tell you what!
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Mime-Version: 1.0
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

The whole problem with this list or any discussion is that people take too
many things personally, can't handle criticism or different ideas.
---------------

Word.  I've seen a surprising amount of "religion" in this respect; I'd
say it's time to stop creating idols, wicked DOES rock, although it's
lately been diffused, likely by their well deserved success.  I do get
extremely annoyed, however, by the inability of list members to hear any
criticism of certain entities; wicked isn't the only one, but it surely
IS one of those entities that folks don't want to hear being criticized.
I agree they need to take their thing further underground; a friend of
mine had his nose broken at that last Bonnie Doon gig, and this is the
kind of thing that I assume wicked is trying to avoid by going further
underground.  However, there definitely is a group of "in the know" types
surrounding not only wicked but the SF rave scene in general that seem
to be into that "beautiful people" or "special people" or "chosen ones" or
the club-kid ego trip thing; deny it if you want, but I believe that Milton
is sounding an alarm that is long overdue.  There's a growing clique
mentality that is the reason I quit going out to clubs in the first place;
I don't like that club-kid mentality and it's definitely been on the
rise lately....  For example, the gigs thrown by friends and family, & by
Bryce and crew have had a marked distinction from the more "commercial"
parties; that attitude is generally not at the friends and family events,
which (IMHO) is one big reason that everyone likes them so much.

So, it appears that we maybe should get busy rather than complaining,
which is even better!  I would be happy to help organize, scout, or
whatever, I've already offered my services to the cloud factory folks
and would be willing to help any other interested parties as well.

JUST DON'T EXPECT ME TO WORSHIP AT THE ALTAR, OK?  I'm an atheist,
afterall...;-)

-=jack=-

(This text composed by voice)

warning ** non-rave related ** warning

wall street journal television is looking for someone who can talk to
them (anonymously if necessary) about computer system security,
specifically, breaking in.  ideally they are looking for someone who
can appear on camera in NYC (again, anonymously if necessary) for a
taping in the next day or two.

this is apparently in response to a recent New York Times article
about a christmas day break in.  the person doing the piece has an
email address which i'll pass on to anyone who wants to talk with her.
she has indicated that she is interested in getting the big picture,
though anything is possible with the press, she sounds like she is
hoping to desensationalize / make more realistic some of the
inaccurate info in the NYT.

if someone could send me a pointer to the cypherpunk mailing list, i'd
appreciate it, this sounds like a good opportunity to educate people.

(sameer: this also sounds like a good opportunity to plug your service
if you use secure measures to guarantee privacy.  she seemed really
interested in this angle --- the "if you want to be secure and you use
an online service, you should use a secure online service" tack.)

anyhow, please contact me if you are interested, and i'll forward
email on to her so she can get back to you.  feel free to use any of
the anonymous email remailer services if that is appropriate.

-- Bob

Message-Id: <199501242258.OAA19231@nature.Berkeley.EDU>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Free Radio Berkeley :)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Mijos, recently someone posted a query about free radio  berkeley, the
happy pirate on the run's thang, Stephen Dunifer.

Well, an Oakland Federal District judge (Claudia Wilken) ruled in FRB and
Dunifer's favor recently, and the FCC can no longer touch the micro-power
station. But they'll try something else, later.

104.1 FM airs on sundays, usually, on a 10 watt transmitter. Last week's
message(jingle):
           "What we need is liberty,
            not no stinkin' laws
            freedom from the FCC
            and their money grubbin' paws
            Hi, hi, mateys,
            oh, good ole pirate radio.
            Land of the free,
            home of the brave
            FCC, roll in your grave."
Ahhh, ain't it sweet to gloat sometimes? It's all about money and freedom.
The FCC charges 100 thousand big ones to grant people the right to transmit
from a 100 watt transmiter. They claim it blocks airplane
navigation/communication systems. You figure it out.

This means that maybe soon, you can set up a station with limited reach as
a local outlet and regional showcase. Hmm, this and the internet, maybe Big
Bro's asleep.

Anyway, it's in the papers, I saw it in the
(lame,unquestioning,conservative) Daily Cal.  Way to go! I feel better for
the first time since the elections!
Maybe there is hope for Amerika after all...................

Lotsa love,
 Milton and the E-Bee.............

phred writes a novel,
(chap 6, 1015 again)

>Downstairs we had Markie, Jeno and Taj, the latter spinning
>wickedly deep basslines that took full advantage of the wondrous new bass
>setup downstairs.  And I thought Jeno rode the really sweet smooth sound
>in a way I haven't heard him do for a while.  Kewlness!  But no vibeness,
>I'm afraid.

talking about Vibe is easily as hard as talking about the music
I thought there was plenty of vibe at the party - is there some "standardized"
form of Vibe that we measure different parties against?  I enjoy different
kinds of music, different kinds of parties, and Different Kinds of Vibes.

Personally, I got there kinda late (for me) and thought "Wow, this is crazy
the way the upstairs has so many people these days ..." - then I ran into
a bunch of friends for hugs and saw some other friends who'd been out of town. 
I found all sorts of energy pockets on the dance floor both upstairs and
downstairs (I enjoyed Garth) -  I got smiles from all sorts of cute happy
folks getting down - total strangers offered me juice and smokes.

How do you describe a flavor of vibe?
there was some form of "vibe" - even if the best way to recognize it
was the lack of your pile on the floor and think deep raver thoughts vibe
Or *whatever* you think Vibe is

that was a 7 on the club-kid vibe scale, i'd say a 2 for the blowpop
sunshine statistic and a bullish 16 on the mid-party sweaty belly button
index ...

**********************

The politics of tree climbing
Tarzan, Lord of the ... oh, nevermind
I get the impression that there are 200 people
who really dig FMR's and 5000 who couldn't give a shit
cuz they start too late and people have jobs and other lives
Out of sight Out of mind


Pathetic whining about the good ol days 
My good ol days were last weekend and my future is, ummm, unknown
Disposable subcultures, by Definition 
Move On, baby

Dave





From sfraves-owner  Tue Jan 24 17:59:01 1995

	id AA28897; Tue, 24 Jan 95 20:48:35 EST
Date: Tue, 24 Jan 95 20:48:35 EST
From: csc@pilot.njin.net (Sean Casey)
Message-Id: <9501250148.AA28897@pilot.njin.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: calling all lurkers (Make Your Vibe)
In-Reply-To: <199501241852.KAA29025@nature.Berkeley.EDU>
References: <199501241852.KAA29025@nature.Berkeley.EDU>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

If you want your kind of party to happen, make it happen! In general,
criticism only results in resentment, but action makes vibe.

If there's a party you really like, put your energy into making it
happen! You'll help keep it alive, and give it your own personal
energy. Nothing has been so satisfying for me as seeing this energy
not only palpable in the room, but then magnified far beyond anything
I could do... All promoters need help; if you just ask, they will be
happy to give you lots to do.

Or throw your own! Easier done than said, except perhaps finding a
space (the bane of all promotion). Lots of people are just looking for
an excuse to party.

For parties that just need some remedying, provide some of the remedy.
Help them to work out logistics, to fix problems.

Finally, if you want more great parties than you can stand, find
spaces for the promoters that throw those great parties. That's the
hardest part for them. If spaces were easy, there's be smorgasraves
every weekend. Help them make it happen.

(I figured that when I move to the bay, the best way to get myself to
look for outdoor spaces would be to buy a motorcycle :). On a sunny
day, don't even bother calling... :))

Sean

I hope that this "cilque-ish" and "in the know special people" type of 
attitude is not becoming as wide spread in San Francisco as I am being 
led to believe from reading the various posts to the list.  We don't have 
many clubs or raves here in Sacramento and so coming to SF is very 
special to me because I always get a feel good feeling that I don't ever 
get here in Sac.  When Ooga Booga existed, I felt like if I didn't know 
everyone there, I was a nobody.  It was like a fashion show - look who I 
know fest.  I just hope this won't become an epidemic....
luv,
Amy

I personally don't think i could have been happier except
if they had actually stopped letting people in at some point
(although i probably would have been one of the people
not let it, so maybe not :)

Komotion was overly packed for an hour or two and 
it was quite claustrophobic and unbearably stuffy...
i didnt really mind the smoke so much as the fact
that the smoke adn all the other air wasn't able to go anywhere
and i almost had a few serious attacks of claustrophobia
cuz i also couldnt make it to the door over the bodies
strewn across the floor...

but that all ended soon enough and it was happy happy times from then on
(as compared to just happy times before that)

Ummm.. not mentioned so far was a beautiful set by torsion
(aka bryan campbell aka the first guy to post to the socal-raves list :)
 
It sucks that there were major equipment problems for him,
cuz listening to the DAT that he made,
it would have been more than an incredible experience
had he had everything up an running

Velocette also had some pretty rad stuff that i was quite in love with
although teasing my with faintly audible 303 lines
was not nice at all

Other highlights... the woman with the Dige.. was really cool
cuz i thought it was some wierd mix of the song

Jonah's ambient jungle section of his set
and definitely Nick playing "Nervous Acid" 
at the end of an otherwise completely ambient set

and that guy who finished was okay too ;)

as the woman said at like 6 AM

thankyouthankyouthankyouthankyouthankyouthankyouthankyou
to whoever helped put that on

 ,
dana

My mailer says that Joe Rice said:
> 
> We'll definately address he ventilation concerns at the next one. I woke up
> Sunday afternoon barely able to breathe.
> 
ventilation could have been improved if more people had taken responsibility
to ensure no smoking in the big room. everybody who's been to komotion before
knows about the No Smoking policy in the big room, and why it's there.  And
that includes all substances, except for a small amount (as we discussed
about the next to last party) of incense.  I love incense, and i smoke 
tobacco, and i always do it near the door or outside;  i strongly recommend
others do the same, and suggest the same to folks who they see lighting up. 

there is also a tradeoff that can
be made between running as much equipment as we did from the loft and running
a very powerful exhaust blower that was capable of cooling down one of the
dance parties we held there.

as far as the overcrowding goes, it's really a tough call as to ~when~ to
start holding people up at the door.   also, once the decision is made, a
number of people (not just one or two) need to help make that happen at 
the door.  having had to say "you can't come in" now a number of times, it's
not easy, and it's important to have the support of several other people
to share the burden of explaining why to people in as nice a way as possible.
-- 
====== Bryce Ryan ========== AMBIANCE ========= brycer@ultima.org =========

Subject: new net account
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hi gang:

A while back I asked the list for suggestions about getting a personal
Internet account.  After getting information about a few vendors, I've
signed on with Hooked.  They use the "Pipeline" net client, which uses
TIA for net connectivity; it's much faster than my Chameleon software which
uses SLIP.  Hooked provides a (beta) net browser which only shows graphics
on demand.

Hooked hasn't beeen accepting new customers for a while, since they are growing
too fast and it's been very hard to log in.  To allieviate this, they`re
currently letting people dial in via a Compuserve packet node and they're
eating the $3/hr cost.  Sounds like they care to keep their customers!
I get unlimited hours. for $25/month.  Downside: their overloaded server
is sort of a useless place to telnet to & I wouldn't want to have to
use it for shell accounts; I plan to explore this a little more.

Anyone shopping for net access ought to give hooked a call, IMO. I have
also heard that sirius is a good one to try; no personal experience with
them, though.


AstroBoy
ubu@hooked.net   (soon to move sfraves there)

>From ubu@hooked.net Wed Jan 25 01:43:45 1995
X-Ph-To: rpcaras@srv.PacBell.COM


Not much to add to this discussion except:  
 
I FUCKIN LOVED IT!!!! 

 
I went to the gig at BARS which did have rotten bouncers and  
$1 water, but also had a whole lot of people who really went off. 
I was skeptical at first since I'm usually pretty bored by the metal 
scene.  And I thought maybe it was a bad idea to be waering sneakers
instead of boots.  But after hanging around for a bit I realized there
was a lot more metal in people's bodies than on their clothes, lot of body 
paint and animal costumes and tattoos & stuff.  Seemed like as 
the evening went on I saw more people who looked like ravers.  The opening
band was excuricatingly awful, especially 'cause they  
kept making lame muttering political speeches that I *agreed* with 
more or less; kind of gave concern for the oppressed a bad name. 
But Crash Whorship (oops, meant to say Worship, no ... really!) finally
came on and all was forgottn.  There was a mighty high percentage 
of do-ers to watchers, to borrow "unknown"'s metric.  People were jumping, 
howling, dancing from  the get.  
Provocations of all the senses, magnesium flares, strobe

lights, smoke, and the infamous squirting unknown liquids, catalyzed us to
go beyond audience to sentience.  It was time to go over the edge or leave
the room. The central dance area was boundaryless mass of slippery bodies. 
It was between a mosh pit and a massage group, it was heavy metal contact 
improv.  I could let myself fall and knew that I would 
be lifted or tossed or shoved in some direction before I could hit the
floor.  Random grabbing, be it for balance, a caress, or to get
someone out of the way, was the order of the moment.    
For minutes on end, the universe was naught but but skin and love and
muscle sweaty maple syrup and smoke and desire and fear and wet and
gripping and inner peace at a hundred miles an hour and skids and hugs and shoves
and the smell of mustard.   

And there were a lot more women than I'd have
imagined.  I'd been down for more of a "testosterone vibe", but there were
maybe 20 per cent women in dance area, which might have been part of why it
felt so damn *safe* in there.  With all that swirling surgin stompin, I
think the sight of a few crucifixes would have freaked me out & I was
relieved to see a shirt reading "Dykes From Hell".  I didn't realize till
the end of the show that lead precussionist is a woman (nope,didn't take a 
census)  For all the fire-circle dances and line dances and pushing, 
my feet didn't get stepped on hardly ever, and I managed not to stomp
anybody either.  Oh, and there was some music too.  Daemonic precussion,
swooping electronic bleats, somebody with a trombone(?), amplified moans
and mutterings.  For me anyway, the use of touch and smell and even
taste to the event made for truly transcendent experience.  There was 
nowhere to hide, no compartment for self-awareness to peer out of.  It
was the same sort of ego loss I felt at my very first raves, but more 
physically involving.  One didn't have to consciously suspend disbelief.
The interplay between "leadership" and participation was ideal.  Without
the participation, Crash Worhsip would be little more than mis-placed
circus acts with a drum corps. But this bunch are really on to something, 
they've gone deep into the territory between art and magick.  
(OK, so much for theory.)

After the beastly bouncers chased us out, the party moved out into the
street, where our frenzied energies drew down a most welcome rain shower.
 Oh damn, my disposable painters coveralls were simply *ruined*!  Took a
while to calm down after all this.  The next day, after perhaps five hours
and light and interrupted sleep, I felt alert and glowing, like I'd taken a
final exam or run a 10K. 
 
If this was an "inferior" Crash Worship gig, I can't wait for a real one! 
 
AstroBoy

Some of you had asked me to post when I get on the net and  leave my 
email adress.  Here it is 

peterf@netcom.com

After just being on for about a week I find it to be a great way to get 
to know some ravers alittle better.  Very often I don't take the time to 
get to know people more at raves because it can be very difficult to 
communicate verbally with loud music.  Also much of the time I'm feeling 
so high from my enhanced connection to the oneness of the whole 
experience, that it can be difficult to shift my focus away from that to 
individuals, and I don't have that much of a desire to do so, being that 
I having so much fun dancing.  Sorry I missed the last ambient party.  

                          Peter

>From the Department of Shameless Self-Promotion . . .

I'm the opening DJ for the weekly Sound System club at 1015 Folsom this
Friday the 27th, scheduled for 11:00 pm to 12:30 am.  I believe the
schedule then has residents Corey and Keith Crusher.  The last one I
went to was $5 with the flyer and $10 without, but I haven't seen any
flyers for this one since I'm in Portland so I'm not exactly sure about
that.  Anyway, once you're in you can also check out the concurrent
scenes in the gold room (Cafe Bohemia, disco-ey), upstairs (Dig!, hip hop)
and downstairs (Zendada, pro-house), if things work the way they did
previously this month.

For sentimental value alone it's a big deal for me to play in the big
room at 1015.  I expect clashy beats galore but plenty'o'fun wax and
hope you can come and enjoy :-)

c u in the future!

Subject: Stompy stuff Wed Jan 25 and Sat 28th
Date: Wed, 25 Jan 95 22:27:28 -0800
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>

Precedence: bulk


After having a pretty good time at the "stompy productions" thingie at
Club Touche (300 DeHaro x 16th) last week, I was calling around to find
out what was going on tonight. I called the club at 861-8990 and found
out that it is happening again this Wednesday Jan 25, 10-4AM w/ Mark
Farina, John Howard, and Suiki.

Mini-review: Although I was thoroughly unimpressed with the "vibe" at
first, it progressively got better later in the night as the music got
more interesting and the crowd got happier. There was certainly a lot
of "beautiful people" there, who were fun to watch, but not very
friendly. In addition to the BP's there were also some  inner-circle
folks in attendance, e.g. Garth. Fortunately, there were enough people
just into dancing (as opposed to posing) that made the event pretty
fun. In addition, the music kicked good n' funky.

Eventually I ran into some people I've been seeing at SF's classic
raves (FMRs, GG-park, Pacific) for a long time and felt a bit more
comfortable w/ the crowd. The space itself is quite comfortable, w/ a
good soundsystem, nice lights, friendly staff/security/etc.

In my search to find whether this 300 Deharo thing was happening
tonight,  I also, I found out that Stompy is also having an event on
Sat Jan 28th (267-7615) w/ Harry Who, Mark Farina, and Jeno.

PS: thanks to Matt for posting about the event at 300 DeHaro last Wednesday.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==           Niels Mayer -- netcom!mayer -- mayer@netcom.com               ==
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

Dear Sfraves;

	Thanks for all the kind letters of support I receicved from you 
all during my hours of darkness. The good news is that I'm getting 
better; I've found a wonderful place to live with other massage 
therapist's and a hot tub up in Orinda Hills; and that I actually should 
be able to come out this weekend and have a good time. Yeah!!!!!!! Aagin 
thanks to all the sfravers. And I appolloize if I missed a personal 
thank you to any of you who replied to my post. If so please let me know 
there's something special waiting for you if you did. To all of you love, 
hugs and a thousand little kisses.

		Peace, Love & Thanks
		Brian Darkness
