Good variety of events this weekend - highlights could be the
new moon party, the reopening of the Gardening Club, and Come-Unity
on Wednesday; also check out Generations of Love tonight, and the Stompy 
party or X, Why Zzz on Saturday.

I'm going to be out of town the next couple of weeks so I think Brian
(or his second-in-command) will be handling the calendar.  Please
send any info for new events to him (brian@hyperreal.com).


    ----------------------
==== THE SFRAVES CALENDAR ==================================================
    ----------------------

Thursday, January 26th - Generations of Love
        DJs Tracy, Solar, Tony Fader, Jim & Jeno
        Live: Hardkiss Music & DubTribe
        Ambience: Darkhorse  Charles Uzzell Edwards  Jason
        the San Francisco House Movement comes together to benefit Project
        Open Hand at 1015 Folsom, Planet San Francisco
        admission - 3 cans of nutritious food
        10pm-6am.  415.435.8675

Friday, January 27th - Sound Factory 2nd anniversary 
        live: the Solsonics & the Greyboy Allstars
        + new resident DJ Roger S + Pete Avila & Aaron O
        + Brass in the loft w/DJs Marques Wyatt & Julius Papp
        9pm-7am.  525 Harrison @ 1st.  415.543.1300

Friday, January 27th - Rain Dance Productions Tribal Dance Party
        DJs Eric  James  Tom  Wool
        $3, 10pm-4am at the BrookDale Lodge 11570 Highway 9, Brookdale, CA
     >Take 280 South to San Jose and then take Highway 17 South to the Mount 
     >Herman Road exit.  Drive down Mount Herman Rd for several miles until it 
     >ends at a signal.  Take a right.  At the next signal take a right.  This 
     >is Highway 9.  It's approximately four miles up Highway 9 to Brookdale. 

Saturday, January 28th - Stompy Dance Concert 
        Mark Farina  Jeno  Harry Who
        Pure Mixed Media  Synergy Video
        10pm-6am.  21+  415.267.7615

Saturday, January 28th - X, Why Zzz
        Dj Dan  Jon Bishop  Rick Preston  Tony  Liquid 
        Skylab2000 (LA) performing live.
        408.235.0658    415.979.3052    510.247.2202
        exwhyzzz@aol.com

Saturday, January 28th - Groove Trip presents Liquid Groove
        Simon  Doran  St__  Charisma
        Sacramento.  415.522.9958

Sunday, January 29th - Dark Blue New Moon
        environmental listening, sweet n' sticky house, etc
        1 pm to whenever @ top secret location 1 h north of SF
        bring warm clothes, firewood, food to share
        415.267.3076 

Wednesday, February 1st - Come/Unity
        Garth  Jeno  Simon  +  Jason & Dubtribe in the ambient room
        1015 Folsom - 415.241.8815

Friday, February 3rd - Kundalini
        Galen  Jeno  Garth  Travis  Spun
        510.944.7743    415.337.4337


==== W E E K L I E S =======================================================

House/techno/acid jazz/ambient/etc regular happenings
Some of them may have ended - let me know when that happens...

---- T h u r s d a y -------------------------------------------------------

Kit Kat - 6th & Harrison (the End-Up) - 21+, $5 w/invite b4 11, $10 w/o
Soul Purpose - live acid jazz and DJs John Essen & guests - 
        21+, 9:30pm-2:30am, Sound Factory, 525 Harrison, sfca.  415.882.1178   
Moving Company - deep soul + deep house w/DJs dedan, themba, life, george,
        and r-pos.  $3, 21+ the elbo room, 647 Valencia.
Indonesia - DJ Dan, Kwashi, Ghost, Frank Nitty, Spinner  415.605.4242
        415.560.5314   510.667.4151   408.388.3883
the Velvet Shop - various house DJs - $3 b4 11pm w/invite, $5 after.  21+
        1984 Old Oakland Rd.  408.428.0329
the Underground Lounge - acid jazz & house w/DJs Corbin, James and David
        Casanova, 527 Valencia.  21+, $2.  415.281.8405

        525 Harrison @ 1st, SF - 9:30pm-7am, 21+   415.543.1300

        across from campbells soup, on Kiesseg blvd (Sacramento)

---- Info Lines ------------------------------------------------------------- 

Be-At Info Line - 415-626-4087.  Usually has 5-10 listings, updated daily.
Clubline - 415.979.8686
Fatline - 415.207.3668
the Global Party Network - 415.568.1338
Pre-Rave Warmup Line - Wondering what to do before the music starts?
        Events can happen at any time.  Suggestions welcome. Call 415-533-3848

---- Radio/TV Shows --------------------------------------------------------- 
Sunday night 10pm-2am - Ambience w/Michael Hayes & David X  KWOD 106.5 (Sac)
Sunday night 10pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 47 - Progressive house, 
        acid jazz and "alternative" music views. (415) 281-3377.
Sunday night mid-3am - "No UFO's" w/Adam from Silent Records
        KZSU 90.1 Stanford 
Mondays midnight-2am - "The Mix Show" KWOD 106.5(Sac) - lineup 916.551.0494
Monday night/Tuesday morning midnight-3am - "On the Astral Plane"
        ambient w/Galaxy Girl and guests, KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)
Wednesdays 10pm-2am - Belladonna, KFJC 89.7 (Los Altos) - last two hours
        are usually techno-tribal-trance and ambient
Wednesday night mid-3am - "Cataklyzmol Pixel" ambient, experimental & noize -
        w/DJ Unknown, KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)
Thursday evening 9:30pm-12mid - Minor Minor KALX 90.7 (Berkeley)
Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF 90.3 (SF)
Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix with Johnny K,
        Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
weeknights ~9pm - the Modern Mix w/Steve Masters KITS 105.3 (SF)

Hey Grey, Feels funny meeting you here.  I've never been to that 
gardening thing.  I'm a little reluctant to go to that 55 natoma location.
The last couple of times I've been there wasn't to good.  The last time I 
was there they had the place segregated with people over 21 able to go 
upstairs, and under only able to stay downstairs.  Then at 2am they 
turned up the lights and told everyone under 21 to get out.  Talk about a 
vibe killer.   But I've heard a few good things about the gardening there 
on mondays.

                             peter

Hi Folks,

If you read the calendar, you might have noticed the addition of the
Pre-Rave Info Line at the bottom of the list.  Unfortunately, I gave
Derek the wrong number (ack!).   The correct number is 415-522-3848.
(not 533).  

I have nothing planned yet, but on Saturday I'll setup dinner and
coffee 7-9 somewhere in the city.  

This line is a resource I'd like to share with ravers.  If you have
an event that isn't a rave but you would like to invite ravers, I'll
list it.  I'm also looking for a couple volunteers to help me with
the line.  I'll also list any post rave info that I come across.  

Finally, the line is attached to my pager.  If you need help, I'll
do my best to aid you.

Ciao,

Purple Tiger

Forwarding message by CAdrmr@ix.netcom.com
--------------------
From: CAdrmr@ix.netcom.com (Cyberslut)
Subject: Re: Great moments in Rave
Date: 19 Jan 1995 18:37:21 GMT
Organization: Netcom

In <3flv1a$s@klaava.Helsinki.FI> ppennane@cc.Helsinki.FI 
(Petrus Pennanen) writes: 

>
>Last spring there was a free party with Goa music in a forest 
a bit
>outside Helsinki. These parties and their organizers are 
brilliant, it's
>completely free, people bring food, drinks and other nice 
things to share
>with everyone, decoration and music are very beautiful and 
emphasis is
>on trance, like usually there's a colorful totem in the middle 
of the
>floor and everyone dances around it. This is great because 
everyone looks at
>each other while dancing. 
>
>At this party they had a four-way sound and lights which 
looked amazing in
>the dark forest. At some point the police arrived -- no 
permit, too much
>noise, stop the party! Everyone got a bit paranoid, the music 
was turned down
>and the cops went away. The music was turned up again and the 
cops came back
>to shut it down for real. This time one of the girls serving 
tea&cookies got
>up, went to the cops carrying a tray and asked them to sit 
down and have some
>tea and cake. Something a cop can't resist I guess. The cops 
sat there with
>everyone else and had a chat with the organizers. Then they 
got up, went
>to their van and drove through the dancefloor -- with all the
>flashing lights on! There was a BIG cheer and the party went 
on till 8
>or 9. I had a blast and was dancing till the very end, the 
mosquitoes
>didn't bother me when I danced.
>
>There are plenty of magic rave moments bouncing around in my 
head, it's
>gonna be a long thread I guess.
>
>Much love,
>
>Petrus
>-- 
>Petrus.Pennanen@helsinki.fi * Everything is perfect forever
>

With stories like these, it's hard to imagine being cynical...  


From sfraves-owner  Fri Jan 27 13:55:54 1995

Subject: generations of love
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Fri, 27 Jan 1995 13:54:40 -0800 (PST)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 1007      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Had a great time at generations of love at 1015 folsom.  There wasn't the 
amount of high energy as community but it had a more intimate feel, with 
a nice happy love vibe.  There wasn't quite the showing they were hoping 
for.  There was music in 3 rooms.  The couple of times I went downstairs, 
there was nobody there.  Most of the people stayed in the big room which 
made for a nice crowd.  The music was great, making it difficult to take 
a rest.  I was able to squeeze in a couple of short rests in the chill 
room.  There was a nice atmosphere there with the music volume being just 
right  for me.  Loud enough to drown out the other room and low enough to 
have a conversation without shouting, which I feel I have to do sometimes 
in there.  Had to leave at 4am, although it took me at least 15-20minutes 
to get out the door.  As I was walking out that music just pulled me back to 
the dance floor for another spin. 


                     


                         peter                   


From sfraves-owner  Fri Jan 27 16:06:26 1995

From: crunch@netcom.com (John Draper)

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Generations of Love report
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

The Generation of love
======================

This week,  Rick Bloom from Indiana came out to meet me for the very first
time.   He's been reading my reports in "alt.rave",  and came out to meet
me,  as well as return a car to one of his freinds in the bay area.

When he wrote me,   telling me of his intention of coming to visit me
and to rave with me,  I warned him that it might be difficult to keep
up with me,   but he held up pretty well.   So we made plans to head
out to Generatios of Love on Thursday.

So,  On Wednesday,  we head out to the Haight,  where I check into
AMEBA (Rave central) to visit Mark.   I Also picked up the Tracy
tape of her New Years party at Cyberlab 7.    WOW!! - Get this tape!!
You won't be dissapointed....

Thursday, January 26th - Generations of Love
        DJs Tracy, Solar, Tony Fader, Jim & Jeno
        Live: Hardkiss Music & DubTribe
        Ambience: Darkhorse  Charles Uzzell Edwards  Jason
        the San Francisco House Movement comes together to benefit Project
        Open Hand at 1015 Folsom, Planet San Francisco
        admission - 3 cans of nutritious food
        10pm-6am.  415.435.8675


Well,  for a Thursday "middle of the weeker" party,   this one really WENT
OFF.   Tracey spun the most insane set, and I entered a really deep trance
state that put this huge grin on my face,  as I was hopping around like a
mad man,  grinning with the biggest fattest smile all evening long.

I think the longest time I spent NOT dancing was about 10 minutes,   and
with the party going on until 6 am (I just LOVE these partys that go till
6 am or later....)   Rick was really enjoying himself,  then when we
talked in the chill area,   I said "Welcome home!!!"...

The party was at 1015 Folsom (My favorite venue).   Hardkiss and Dubtribe
doing live sets in the chill area downstairs.   For only 3 cans of food,   
What a bargain!!

It's parties like these that really restore my faith in the SF rave scene.

So,  tonight,  it's Venus!!  I just hope the rain stops before tonight...
Hope to see U there... and hope I can make it...

C. Crunch

new members; and if you join you can get paid to bring in new members.

Majornet), gopher, archie, telnet, USnet, LINUX, virtual slipp soon to be

networks. If you bring in i think like 8 people its free for you to use
the service; If you bring in more you get paid cash$$$$; a check each
month its really a good deal. Also local dialup numbers no Pacbell or

extra you can join a concertic network that claims to have no net lag; 
thats $30 a month extra.

all fixed now. I've been a member for 3 months now and i told them that

Hi all,

The following is the lastest transcript from the Pre-Rave info line:

Thank you for calling the Pre-Rave Info Line.  You can skip this
announcement at any time by pressing the # key.

Today, Saturday the 28th, there are no events scheduled.

Tomorrow, Sunday the 29th, there will be a pre-rave brunch around 11:30am at
Mama's Royal Cafe in Mill Valley. This event is scheduled before the 1pm
Dark Blue New Moon Rave located not too far away. Directions to Mama's Cafe
are as follows:

        Take the 101 north from the Golden Gate Bridge or south from the
        Richmond/San Rafael Bridge.  Exit at the Mill Valley/Stinson
        Beach/Highway One exit.  At the stop sign turn left and follow the
        road around the inlet through two stop lights.  After the second
        stop light, the road straightens up and changes its name to Millar
        Ave.  Mama's Cafe is on the right after a block or so. The address
        is 387 Miller Ave.

Look for me, I'm Purple Tiger.  On me, or near me, will be a flourescent
orange cap that sayz "Wired" on the front.  Sit down and enjoy the meal.

Leave a message on the voice mail if you are going to come even if you
decided to come at the last minute. If you get lost or need more directions,
call the voice mail with a number I can reach you at.  The voice mail calls
my pager so I can reach you pretty quickly anytime day or night.

I hope to see you.  If you have suggestions for future events or want to
help me organize events, please leave a message.

Pre-Rave Info Line 415.522.3848
New Moon Info Line 415.267.3076

PT

--
< Purple Tiger (ptiger@crl.com) >

From sfraves-owner  Sat Jan 28 16:32:29 1995
Return-Path: owner-sfraves
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id QAA15445; Sat, 28 Jan 1995 16:32:29 -0800
Received: from well.sf.ca.us by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with ESMTP id QAA15440; Sat, 28 Jan 1995 16:32:25 -0800
Received: (from phred@localhost) by well.sf.ca.us (8.6.9/8.6.9) id QAA21669 for sfraves@hyperreal.com; Sat, 28 Jan 1995 16:32:22 -0800
Date: Sat, 28 Jan 1995 16:32:22 -0800
From: Fred Heutte <phred@well.sf.ca.us>
Message-Id: <199501290032.QAA21669@well.sf.ca.us>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: On the decks at 1015 Folsom
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Well, apparently there was a big schedule shuffle this week for Sound
System since Dub Tribe is touring in the east coast.  I did get to play
but it was between 10 and 10:45 when the place was basically empty.
Nobody there complained too much about my mixing so I suspect I'll get
another shot at it :)  The Rane mixer they use is especially sensitive
in the higher range of the sliders, unlike the Numarks or Geminis, it
really cranks up with just a touch on the sliders at the high end, so
it was good for me to get a workout with that.

After me were weekly residents Corey and Keith, and then various Hardkiss
types playing some really good toonz, even venturing somewhat above the
125 bpm mark, which was good.

I played mostly vocal house (in fact, about half the vocal tracks I've got)
but I really want to go back with the system cranked up playing some of the
faster-trancier stuff!

Afterwards I went over to Il Pirata (16th & Utah) where Freaky Friday was
holding forth, I arrived right at the end of a set and right before Jeno
came on for a bit over an hour.  Neils was there too and will vouch for
the high quality of Jeno's set, it's been a long, long time since I've
enjoyed one of his that much.  There were only about 30 people up and
dancing but it was definitely a groove!  And a nice relaxed hangin-out
scene in the bar.  I think Il Pirata is definitely a good new spot and
all three nights I've been there I've had a good time.

My name *is* on the Sound System flyer for last night, after all, so I guess
it ranks overall as a positive experience.  Next week, btw, Rawno from XLR8R
will be there no doubt doing *really good* garage/vocal house.  If you're
in need of a Friday night outing, the Folsom/Il Pirata combo is a pretty OK
one.  

c u in the future
phred

Well folks, this is a warning so that none of you would go through what
I've been through last night... You see, despite my friend's warning, I
decided to show up at the weekly Indonesia... IT WAS HORRIBLE! That party
lacked good music and even though the small crowd had good vibes, it was
not enough to conceal how boring the party was. I mean, I was on e, and I
was still bored... Very bad in my book... The worst thing was that when the
music started to get good, the owner shut the place down... at 2:30 AM!!!
Sheesh... Talk about ten dollars wasted... Anyways, everyone, trust me,
don't venture into Indonesia, than again, I am sure everyone online is much
smarter than I am and have stayed away from it all along... Sigh... I need
a hug...

Anyways, hope to see you folks at Liquid Groove tonight!

Party!

I'll vouch for that, second, and even third Phred's opinion!

I fell sound asleep around 7PM last night due to eating a turkey
sandwich at a local deli (dat tryptophan thang you know)... woke up at
midnight and decided I had to rave. Called a few places and according
to my calculations, it sounded like Freaky Friday at 16th and Utah
would be the most underground event with a big-name DJ (Jeno). All the
other numbers I called sounded kinda questionable, I've had a good time
at "move" at 16th&Utah, so I decided to check it out.

Word. What he said. It was fun, and a very "different" Jeno from the
usual club fare. More interesting material, IMHO, than Jeno usually 
plays.

Has this happened to you before-
        I am not in SF nor was I when this happened but I thought it was
pretty groovy so I wanted to write about it. Some friends and I went to
Nebulous at Saltair (an old ballroom/dancehall on the shores of the Great
Salt Lake, SLC,Ut). Garth and Carlos were spinning along with some local
Mechanized DJ's. Anyway, really good music and then they did this really
groovy thing in the middle of it. While Carlos was spinning a live
saxaphone and trumpet player got on the stage and grooved along with what
Carlos was spinning. It was really coooooooooooool - o . Everyone got
really into it. It was great. I hope this is part of a new tradition.

        Just thought I'd share the input. Also watch for more great films
coming out this year from the Sundance Film Festival:
        "The incredibly true adventures of Two girls in love"-I'm straight
and I loved it.
        "Super 8 & 1/2" A gay porno, I had to walk out after 20 minutes but
seemed like a campy little  flick if you can stand the hardcore sex.
        "Little Odessa" Tim Roth - need I say more. Anyway good flick.
Check it out.
        "Before Sunrise" Cheezy even though it was by the same guy who did
"Dazed and Confused"

        Anyway - enough from me.
        Thanks

Hi All,

I moved the time of the pre-rave gathering back two hours to 1:30pm
accomodate the change in start time of the Deep Blue New Moon rave.

Here's the info line message:

Thank you for calling the Pre-Rave Info Line.  You can skip this
announcement at any time by pressing the # key.  There has been a
change in the schedule as of yesterday.

Today, Sunday the 29th, there will be a pre-rave brunch around 1:30pm at
Mama's Royal Cafe in Mill Valley. This event is scheduled before the 3pm
Dark Blue New Moon Rave located not too far away. Note that the time has
been moved back 2 hours from yesterday.  Directions to Mama's Cafe
are as follows:

        Take the 101 north from the Golden Gate Bridge or south from the
        Richmond/San Rafael Bridge.  Exit at the Mill Valley/Stinson
        Beach/Highway One exit.  At the stop sign turn left and follow the
        road around the inlet through two stop lights.  After the second
        stop light, the road straightens up and changes its name to Millar
        Ave.  Mama's Cafe is on the right after a block or so. The address
        is 387 Miller Ave.

Look for me, I'm Purple Tiger.  On me, or near me, will be a flourescent
orange cap that sayz "Wired" on the front.  Sit down and enjoy the meal.

Leave a message on the voice mail if you are going to come even if you
decided to come at the last minute. If you get lost or need more directions,
call the voice mail with a number I can reach you at.  The voice mail calls
my pager so I can reach you pretty quickly anytime day or night.

I hope to see you.  If you have suggestions for future events or want to
help me organize events, please leave a message.

Pre-Rave Info Line 415.522.3848
New Moon Info Line 415.267.3076

PT

Has this happened to you?

I think it was around 2:30am or so, maybe 3.... Harry Who had whipped the
crowd into steamy hotness with lots of fresh funky sounds.  King st was
looking very cheery.  Not cheesey but cheery.  The crowd was moving like a
runaway train.  Jeno did some solid energy surges... housey not housey
techno not techno fast and slow up and down back and forth and then
suddenly..... bleeps and blips tweaks and squeaks higher and higher harder
and harder and OH - My - GOD!! The musical orgasm!  A warming
sensation.... tingly all over... shivers down the spine and every single
solitary muscle struggling to somehow express the feeling of pure
happiness.  

Was it good for you too?

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: bywang@ocf.Berkeley.EDU ( Brian Yen-Shan Wang)
Subject: Liquid Groove was FABULOUS!
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hello all!
Liquid Groove was simply FABULOUS and I have to share the positive vibes I
got with everyone online! I got so much positive vibes and love, I just
HAVE to share it with others some how!
I arrived at the party shortly after eleven, and the crowd was GREAT!
Everyone was smiling and having a good time. The music was awesome, and as
the evening progresses, it got even better. As more people showed up, the
positive energy got greater! I met so many wonderful people, and I love
them all. This was definitely one of the best party I have been to in a
long time. It wasn't a big commercialized party, instead, it was intimate
underground sorta event. I candy-flipped and danced from eleven to six in
the morning. My joints are sore and possibly swollen, but I had a wonderful
time. The only complaint I had was that water was not readily available, I
mean, I am familiar with paying for water, but at one dollar a pop, I
quickly ran out of money, and had to ask for water from everyone on the
dance floor, but the cool thing was that everyone was willing to share.
Maybe Groove Trip should hook up a tap water hose for their next party...
However, over all, it was definitely worth the ten dollars I paid (and they
were giving away free candy! Yumm!)
Anyways, if anyone online was there and didn't get to meet me, I was the
one in the red cross/M*A*S*H long t-shirt and baggy skater pants, and
hopefully I'll get to meet other people online at the next party!

I LOVE YOU ALL!

**HUG**

Sincerely,
Brian "dragonfly" Wang

Subject: new moon party
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Mon, 30 Jan 1995 03:28:45 -0800 (PST)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

The newmoon party was really great for  a while.  I got there about 8pm.  It 
had a nice friendy laid back feel when I first got there.  Perfect to do 
alittle dancing and a good enviroment to talk and get to know people.  I 
was able to meet a few sfravers  that I never knew before.  I immediately 
senced a special bond after finding they were also on the net.  When 
Tracy came on the energy level took an incredable surge.  All that 
energy,and in a house, giving it a nice intimate feel, gave way to some 
indescribable magical moments.  About two and a half hours worth.  
Unfortunately there was a sound complaint, which brought about a sudden 
shift to a complete 
ambiant party.  With the drop in energy,  I knew after  a little while 
that it was time to go and hope to get some sleep so I could be in 
somewhat decent shape for work tommorrow.  Driving thru the dark wet 
roads I felt somewhat lost as I seem to has missed a turn.  Interesting 
and somewhat comforting  another car with ravers pulled up next to me and 
told me they were lost as well and wanted to follow me.
Later on we went our separate ways as we drove thru some town on the way 
to the freeway.  Starting to sence the upcoming freeway I suddenly see a 
cop 
flashing his lights at me.  He told me I was speeding, I told him I was 
lost.  After giving me a little lecture on driving safely, he gave me 
directions and no ticket.  He probably either felt sorry for me or maybe 
all the love energy I was carrying with me from the party made him feel 
good and not feel the need to give me the ticket. Probably a little of 
both.
                     
                            peter

From: Vladimir Katz <vekatz@ucdavis.edu>
X-Sender: ez053410@bullwinkle
To: SFR <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: ex,why, zzzzzzzzzzzz
Message-ID: <Pine.SOL.3.91.950130110520.6067A-100000@bullwinkle>

xyz at santa cruz auditorium was one of the more boring times I've had in 
my life. Seriously.  to start off, the $20 bass tickets were quite a 
downer.  Next, seing loads of gangsters getting drunk outside surely 
didn't help.  After standing outside and talking to my friends, we 
decided to go in anyway. outside of the dancefloor area several booths 
were set up (journees, boarderline, etc.) including one that I'd never 
heard of before called matrix.  They sold some pretty trippy alien stuff 
and were just overall friendly people.  The inside had some pretty cool 
visuals and lighting.  Unfortunately, the decks were set up on stage and 
way far away from the crowd which kinda sucks.overall the muzic was 
acshully pretty good.  Although Dan never played on four turntables (as 
promised on the flyer), Spun took his place (on 2).  Jon Bishop (at 
least I think that it was jon Bishop!) played a really cool set that got 
everyone groovin pretty good.After taking an extremely long break kickin 
back with my friends in the hall, I came back in to find rick preston 
spinning.  He spun a fucking incredible set!  Absolutely awesome.  He 
played that new Josh Wink song (yeah, that absolutely crazy, intense, 
insane, wacky one!!) and everyone on the dance floor went nuts!!  
	The fog macines in the place were on wayyyyyy to high and it was 
incredibly hard to breathe.  The fact that security kept the doors shut 
didn't help.  The ambient room was also pretty stuffy.  So, basically, 
the muzik, space, vizuals were all ok but.........the crowd just sucked.  
Pretty hard.  The gangster factor was just too high.  Wayyy too many 
people had a scowl on their face.  the atmospere was just pretty tense.  
The only reason I had an OK time was cuz I got to kick back ewith some of 
my close friends.


HAPPINESS IS BEING AMONG FRIENDS

-sly                          
vekatz@ucdavis.edu

First in a series: Raving as a subversive activity

How about non-stop rave radio in the Bay area? I'm sure there is more than
ample audience for a station that could program rave in all its subgenres
from ambient to gabber. And if it can't be done via usual methods, then why
not pirate rave radio? - all it would take is a couple of techies, some
radio widgets, local dj's and nerves o' steal. BTW the recent Free Radio
Berkely / FCC court ruling seems to have created a precedent for other's to
get in on the independant radio act. And then we would all have something
to listen to on those quiet evenings. A great project for a
telecommunications major or other subsidised individuals.

DD

when I arrived Tracy had finished and Sarah was spinning. People were 
unhappy with the intense deprogramming chaos which Sarah was sharing with 
us. If It was a boy playing those sounds they would have removed him 
quick, 
as it was the  vibe which Tracy had drawn out was unpredictably turned to 
another face of Eve. Ironicly It was a Diamanda Galas track that got 
Ronan 
Cyril and Galen to their feet. The predictably pleasant ambient beats 
which 
followed brought people to their feet again. I went to sleep with a warm 
sentimental glow in my heart, having finally witnessed the first public 
performance of Nurse w/Wound, Whitehouse, Galas, Current 93 and others, 
played to a drugged audience, which by my observation had never heard the 
gems of a period which I fondly recall
-------------------------------------
E-mail: ameba@netcom.com
Date: 01/30/95
Time: 12:13:27

salutations   allen@ameba

>The space (1015), the Djs (Tracy, Jim, Solar, then I had to go to school:(
>the security, the bartenders, all VOLUNTEERS. The "price" =3 cans of food

Yea!!  And did you know that the bar gave free refills of soda.   Now That
was nice.

David Dai writes...

>BTW the recent Free Radio
>Berkely / FCC court ruling seems to have created a precedent for other's to
>get in on the independant radio act. And then we would all have something
>to listen to on those quiet evenings. A great project for a
>telecommunications major or other subsidised individuals.

Well,  this is certainly going to be interesting.    But I doubt if the FCC
would allow this,   because almost ALL home transmitters send out signals
on other frequencys,  but I see a time when the FCC "May" allow low power
transmitters (10 watts or less) to be operated if the equipment is "Type
approved".    Hmmm!   That opens up a whole new market,   especially if
Steve can design a filter system to remove harmonics.

I've built many pirate transmitters in my time,  using Ham radio technology,
and even the best designed filtering system couldn't adequately reduce the
harmonics to a tolerable level.

Now,  if Steve can come up with a good filter design cheaply,  he could be
a very rich man,   especially if the FCC relaxes the technical standards
to allow them to be built cheaply.

My $.02

Chris Boumont says...

>How about non-stop rave radio in the Bay area? I'm sure there is
>more than ample audience for a station that could program rave in all its
>subgenres from ambient to gabber.

Getting an existing radio station to try out a new format,  is next to
impossible.    I've discussed this with my friend John who has part ownership
in a radio station,  and getting sponsors (Commercials and ads) to accept
that format is next to impossible.

CC

Dear Sfraves;

	As I was sitting here listening to a Yello CD; I had the most 
profound thoughts. That we; Net People, are Virtual Cybernetic Beings. 
Cybernetics being def. compartive study of electronic computers and the 
human nervous system. A cyborg is part organic life form part silicon 
lifeform. So with this information in mind that makes us; virtual 
cybernetic beings. The virtual part comes into play because we don't have 
computer chips imbedded in us yet; but with our daily use of these 
machines that our outside of us; & the fact that we grow more and more 
dependent on them; makes us VCB's. In fact our nervous system works much 
like computer logic. Current computer logic has two states on and off, 1 
or a 0; >=3.5vdc and <=0.8vdc; respectively. The human CNS(central 
nervous system) and the PNS(peripheral nervous system) also work in a 
similar fasion; meaning two known states only in microvolts. Also 
computer logic is extremely dependent on timing; making sure that a 
nanosecond wide pulse is where is should be within a few picoseconds wide 
window. Also with the human body the timing of pulses is also essential 
for good coordination. For exmaple MS(multiple sclerosis) is an 
autoimmune disease where things called mylen shealths which cover nerves 
are destoried by the bodies own immune system. These shealths speed the 
computer like pulse to the various organs and muscles. When they are 
destoryed the pulses are recieved in a chaotic state hence the lack of 
manual deterity lost by people suffering this disease; this sentance is 
mine own theroy; but the rest of the information is to the best of my 
knowledge factual. We are a lot like computer more so than most people 
think. In fact it's kinda funny and neat; that as create a machine that's 
more like us; I think we will learn a lot more about how we work. Like 
brain structure, memory and organization. I think is fasinating that the 
net is organize in a loss assoiative state. Like the blue words in a 
document that take you to things that are either close in topic or 
assoicated; this in some ways is how we remember thinks; though 
assoication; its sooo cool. I would like to end this with some profound 
prose of my own:

	What is; as a race of beings our fasination with these machines
	What do we see when we stare into that glowing phosphorus screen
	Do we see just computer generated images
	Or do we see the future; our next evolution as a race of beings
	Will we be cybernetic beings with helper chips built into us
	With computer controlled hydraulic limbs, and eyes
	Will Cyberpunk and Blade Runner turn out to be prophesy rather 
	than fiction
	You decide who and what you want to be

		Peace & Love
		aka Brian Darkness

		Internet:	brianv@liberty.com
		Alt. Internet:	brianvan@liberty.com
		Majornet:	Brian Darkness @LIB
		Worldlink:	Brian Darkness @LIB
		Chatlink:	System #48; Stop by and will chat

		Net Person & Virtual Cybernetic Being
			(FUKENGRUVEN:)

From: Brian Darkness <brianvan@liberty.liberty.com>
Subject: Re: Virtual Cybernetic Beings(VCB) (fwd)

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Mon, 30 Jan 95 20:36:48 -0800
From: Niels P. Mayer <mayer@netcom.com>
To: Brian Darkness <brianvan@liberty.liberty.com>
Cc: San FranDisco Ravers List <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Re: Virtual Cybernetic Beings(VCB) 


>That we; Net People, are Virtual Cybernetic Beings. 
>Cybernetics being def. compartive study of electronic computers and the 
>human nervous system. A cyborg is part organic life form part silicon 
>lifeform. So with this information in mind that makes us; virtual 
>cybernetic beings. The virtual part comes into play because we don't have 

I have a digital wristwatch -- what's that make me, a virtual clock? I
fail to find any reason to want to be considererd virtual, or
cybernetic. The biological is much more interesting. Something has gone
awfully wrong when we start alluding god-like capabilities to
technology rather than looking at it as a mere tool to help us
live/explore/learn. This is partially what sickens me about this whole
Cyberpunk thing, because it is teaching whole generations to become 
totally fascinated by machines/death/technology, at the expense of 
what is really important -- being/life/biology. I see this as  the
worship of "false idols" (or cargo-cultism) and it is antithetical to
my world-view. (Don't get me wrong I'm as "cyber" as the next computer
geek, but it's just my job/hobby, not a god.)
 
Yes, we become a "bigger brain" by virtue of being connected on the
internet. We also became a "bigger brain" when we learned to
communicate, to read, write, paint, to publish on paper, or "publish
electronically" etc. Ants and bees communicate through dance and
pheromones, yet nobody goes around calling ants and bees virtual, or
cybernetic -- it's just part of their social fabric. Similarly, maybe
we can use our improved interconnectedness to become more like
ants/bees and communicate better on a societal and species level.

Ultimately, however, we're still biological. Our interconnectedness may
hasten our ability to communicate and discover, and change the way we
socialize. It doesn't change us, it's just a new tool at our disposal.
I think maintaining this perspective is important.

>The human CNS(central 
>nervous system) and the PNS(peripheral nervous system) also work in a 
>similar fasion; meaning two known states only in microvolts. Also 
>computer logic is extremely dependent on timing; making sure that a 
>nanosecond wide pulse is where is should be within a few picoseconds wide 

This is useless and false analogy. There are plenty of neurons and
perceptual entities that work in a much more "analog" fashion. More
importantly, even if you can identify on/off states in some neurons,
the whole way the brain works is as different as you can possibly get
from computer logic. For one, it is more massively parallel and
massively interconnected than anything we can possibly conceive of at
the present time. The control structures are nondeterministic at best,
which again goes against anything we're used to in computers.

The brain and neural system operate much more on a "gestalt" level than
any logical system could ever hope to do. Logic is completely
irrelevant at the neural level. The whole reason why cognition seems so
miraculous is because our current mechanistic/reductionistic attempts
at explaining the mind are antithetical to the way the brain actually
works. That which we can't explain becomes magic....

>Current computer logic has two states on and off, 1 
>or a 0; >=3.5vdc and <=0.8vdc; respectively. 

Not to be a dickhead or a nitpicker (actually, I'm both), but this
isn't really true either. Bipolar ECL computers work with negative
voltage, MOS/CMOS/NMOS often have different sensitivity levels, as does
Gallium Arsenide. Many computer chips work at the TTL levels you
describe, but that's mostly an issue of standardization. There are
computers in operation that use light too. I fail to see the point
of your analogy.

>We are a lot like computer more so than most people 
>think. In fact it's kinda funny and neat; that as create a machine that's 
>more like us; I think we will learn a lot more about how we work. Like 
>brain structure, memory and organization. I think is fasinating that the 

This harks back to the old days of cybernetics and AI. In other words,
it is complete bullshit -- your time would be better spent counting how
many angels can dance on the head of a pin than following this 1950's
line of reasoning.

It has long been a goal-em :-) of human desire to be able to
mechanically create intelligence, it will be a long long time (if ever)
before we can create a brain-like machine ourselves. And if we do,
chances are, it'll be something that we pushed the evolutionary and
learning processes of, rather than something created, inna frankenstein
stylee. 

Can you even describe the things you know using logic? -- not a chance,
most everything you do and know is because you and your forbears
existed in the world and environment and learned how to respond to it
both through evolutionary and cognitive processes.This process took
millenia to bear fruit, and it isn't likely that humans will be able to
shave off even a few orders of magnitude in the time it took
evolutionary, learning, and social processes to create something as
complex as the mind).

We have no better understanding of how the brain works than we do of
how the AIDS virus works. Yes, we can look at the minutiae of the
chemical processes going on. THis is totally uninteresting, however,
because the important interactions are happening at a systemic level.

The interesting thing about biological systems are the emergent
properties that arise out of billions and billions of interconnected
units and interactions. THis goes completely beyond logic.

We can't even predict the weather, turbulence etc from the emergent
properties of billions of interacting molecules, let alone predict how
a brain functions from the interactions of billions of neurons. There
is little hope for rational science trying to be able to build a brain
until we can conquer infinite complexity and master time and evolution
control. At that point, we have become god, and it won't matter anyways.

(PS: I'm an atheist/Jew, so don't take "god" literally, please).

>The virtual part comes into play because we don't have 
>computer chips imbedded in us yet; but with our daily use of these 
>machines that our outside of us; & the fact that we grow more and more 

Actually, there have been neural interfaces created to the optic nerves
allowing blind people to see a very low-resolution (32*32 pixels, i
think) version of the world around them. Likewise, digital auditory
interfaces have been build allowing some deaf people to "hear" (of
course, since these people haven't learned to hear, it's just another
sensation, like someone stimulating a new nerve).

All this neural prosthetic work has nothing to do with science of mind
or intelligence. There certainly has been progress in neurophysiology
-- enough to know what connects to what, but not enough to know how the
whole system works. 

Scientists have the dreams and the hubris to think they can conquer the
mind. A few good years of bashing their heads against the walls of
reality usually takes care of the hubris part and leaves you with a
nice headache too. 

I'm not trying to dissuade you from your dreams/pursuits. Just don't
expect to see much progress on this in our lifetime, or our children's
lifefimes, or... Although it stimulates our flights of fancy, 
we shouldn't get carried away confusing science with science fiction.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==           Niels Mayer -- netcom!mayer -- mayer@netcom.com               ==
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

	I disagree; nerve's are basically wave guides. "A reflex arc 
consists of a receptor, a sensory neuron, a center in the CNS, a motor 
neuron, and a effector organ, and maybe defined as the shortest route of 
an impulse between receptor and effector. Receptors are basically 
transducers that take information from either internal or external 
sources and create neural impulses." By defination a impulse is a 
momentarty signal; much like a sqaure wave. When an impulse is triggered 
from whatever source, it sends a wave of negativeity down the nerve; much 
like negative logic. The number of impulses determines the magitude, 
level of control(fine to gross) ..ETC. Check your A&P Niel; I just quoted 
you verbatum out of my book; which is less than a year old.

X-Mailer: Z-Mail (3.1.0 22feb94 MediaMail)
To: Brian Darkness <brianvan@liberty.liberty.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.com

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Mime-Version: 1.0
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

This is partially what sickens me about this whole
Cyberpunk thing, because it is teaching whole generations to become
totally fascinated by machines/death/technology, at the expense of
what is really important -- being/life/biology. I see this as  the
worship of "false idols" (or cargo-cultism) and it is antithetical to
my world-view. (Don't get me wrong I'm as "cyber" as the next computer
geek, but it's just my job/hobby, not a god.)
-------------------

Thank you Mr. Mayer, I was getting that sickening feeling myself... not
that I mind fascination with technology, but I must agree about the
false gods.  Also, if I hear one more person saying they can't wait
until they get microchips planted in their brains/bodies, I might NOT
advice them against their foolishness.  Since raving is supposedly (and
largely I agree that it is) about life, affirmation and celebrating the
human being, I must agree with Niels' concerns.  We don't grow by allowing
ourselves to be subjugated by our own technology, we grow only when we
keep things like this in perspective, realizing that it is us that is
most important; it is us that we should have respect for, be fascinated
by, pay homage to, and most of all, it is us that we should keep as our
most important priority.  No life form, and especially no human life form
should ever, and I mean EVER be seen as less important than some random
technological entity, no matter how "wild", "high-tech" or completely and
utterly "profound".  Our world is full of pain and suffering because our
priorities are completely fucked up, allowing us to devalue the human
being.  So many things are seen as "more important" than some human; this
is simply not true.  In fact, there isn't much that is as important as
the LEAST important among us (i.e. the least important person, as if such
a concept even had any validity to begin with), but until this is clearly
understood, we run the risk of annihilation.  This is, of course, only my
opinion, however, I would like anyone interested to give this some thought
and respond if you like...

-=jack=-

(This text composed by voice)

Jack sez:
> Since raving is supposedly (and
> largely I agree that it is) about life, affirmation and celebrating the
> human being, I must agree with Niels' concerns.  We don't grow by allowing
> ourselves to be subjugated by our own technology,

I don't think Brian was talking about subjugation.  Raving is also
about transcending our limits, letting go, and going beyond our
origins.  I don't find worshipping the biological scum from which we've 
evolved any more noble than being enamored with the less organic 
aspects of the universe that we as living beings have been getting 
closer to.  Personally, I am more put off by people who are soley
driven (subjugated) by their biological urges than by people who aspire 
to a different set of ideals.  I'm sure, jack, that even you wouldn't 
claim to subscribe to the *Dogs' Philosphy of Life*.

It is a simple fact that ravers already have been enhancing themselves
with technology, and not everyone limits their definition of "life"
to exclude "inanimate" materials.  

Lee

Subject: dog days of february
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


i frobulate with dogs all the time

while I wouldn't recommend pentium implants
for just anybody - i do enjoy a little enthusiasm

seems premature to be worrying about a lost generation
of gloomy cyberpunks - isn't it nice to Go there and come back?
a bit of experience, perspective, fun and so maybe a few
will fall in and never return to the well rounded
earth/people loving folks we mostly seem to be
such is life

it is my understanding that if you include electromagnetic
fields in a semi-analytical treatment of black holes there is
the possibility of a surface of infinite energy 
inside the event horizon

i think the relevance to raves here is obvious

my friend, Gabe, has declared January 1995 to be boring.
he wants to see the family again.  i do to, but i also want
to go snowboarding sometime soon.  my point, of course, is what
we Desperately Need is a party in a Park on a Sunday afternoon
(Saturday would be ok).  I'm lookin outside this fine morning
and it is Beautiful ... 

Surely I'm not alone in wanting to dance under the fluffy clouds 
of a lovely February afternoon !!??

Now, don't go telling *me* to organize it.  I am way too much
of a flake to undertake such a resposibility.  I cherish my role
as happy party attendee.

I'll wax eloquently of last summer ... aaahhh, listening to KDIA
broadcast the Evergreen Baptist services on my little AM radio as
I tooled thru Berkeley enroute to Sunset.  Spiritual in a way
that is hard to describe.  Always dressed in my Sunday finest.
I Know The Power of Gods Love, Mans Love, Your Love
Feel the Love with ME ...  FEEL IT !!!
Amen, Brother Dave

In my mind, two groups could pull this off - Pacific or F&F
Do It
For the Love
For the Peace
To Celebrate this Good Year
Together


Dave

ok, i relinquish
i couldn't take the sunshine and fresh air
streaming through my window anymore

umm, yeah boss, i have to, uh, go do some paperwork
in Building 519 ... and I bolted for my car

farms in little valleys with lots of Green grass
wooden fences, old style phone lines, the road is 
a single common lane

Jackpot - 

I found a field with all these Sheep, Cows, and Horses.
I parked on the side of the road, popped in the sweetest
happiest house tape I could find, and started chasing the
Sheep around the pasture.  I'm sure the Sheep appreciated 
this.  Ya know, there's way more than just farm animals in 
this field.  There's alot of Mud.  I'm sure my new sneakers
appreciated this.

Naturally, my frenzied romp in the pasture is noticed by the
owner of the farm who drove up in his truck.  So I get to meet
a farmer.  His name is Junior and apparently he had a fine serving
of pork chops for lunch.  One of his two dogs is also named Junior.
Junior and I discuss the merits of Old Country vs New Country and
we agree that Charlie Pride rules ...

Dave

myself; I'm definately a catalist for thought provoking conversation. 
Eat your heart out and Rush, Howard and Obrap. I have never seen so much 
mail about anyone topic. A topic I never expected to get a reply on that 
was fiction and meant for entertainment only. A good friend of mine said 
take what you find on boards with a grain of salt. A lesson I think we 
all could learn from.

		Peace & Love
		aka Brian Darkness

the new moon went off really well, having the perfect vibe, in my mind.
it was all pretty chaotic.  people seemed to be having a really great
time, especially in the cavehouse.  gaven, wade, ronan played in there
and then phred in the morning.  the perfect ambient experience.  people
would get up and dance a little bit and then melt back into the puddle,
so to speak.  there was a fireplace and john kept burning cedar, which
smelled good.

oh yes, tracy did an incredible set. when it was over, everyone started
yelling:  tracy rules!  tracy rules!  one girl saw philip changing the
tape in his dat and wouldn't let up:  you have to give me a tape of this,
ill pay anything, ill give you money RIGHT NOW, you WILL send me a tape
of this...etc.  there were also these women dancing kind of in a circle
in front of the decks and they looked almost supernatural, they were
loving it so much.

er, then there was a noise complaint and chaos consensus decided to switch
to ambient...and the switch was HARD and can only be compared to an
emotional trainwreck.  much whining and complaining ensued and well, okay,
we can have some more beats if we just keep it down, or something.

not much later galen played, and then cyril, who does this fast trancy
stuff.  both were really great, i thought.  in the morning pollywog showed
up and played and then erik, who has this enormous afro and is french.  his
stuff was INCREDIBLE.  by then it was time to go and so i didn't hear anything
else.  it looked like ronan, cyril, erik and another guy were kind of 
trading off and stuff...

this one happened because alot of people came together and helped out:
john glevis gave the space..it was his house, mark and tracy and sarah
brought turntables and a mixer (check out the ew system at ameba and
ask what the plan is for it), philip and phred DAT'd, gavin, tracy, 
wade hampton, phred, cyril, galen, ronan, erik, pollywog played, ronan
brought his system and was there from the beginning and kept things 
together, pacific donated their system, mona planned the whole thing &
dreamed up the new moon in the first place.  

whew, what a night.  and at last i finally know who is the purple tiger!

love,

ann/thrax


ps i guess everybody's seen XLR8R with robbie hardkiss wearing a saucy
little number on the cover?  check out the hardkiss interveiw inside
where they talk about the "distance" between dj's and the people who
"love house music.." i gues that's the "fans" who don't buy the rekkids.
anyway, i thought they said some interesting things....
